I really like the taste! It is predominately a strong spicy flavor, mainly cinnamon, and quite malty.

This lager when poured from Tap has a half inch foamy head. Clear amber color. A sweet hop aroma. A Carmel hop sweet flavor with a slight bitter hop tase over the pallet to counter the sweetness . Great Lakes has a strong winner with Dortmunder Gold Lager!!

A - Pours out a clear orange. A white head, with a full persistent cap after the fade. Lots of fine line lacing on the glass as I drink.

S - Strong hit of sour grain, grassy hop notes, and a bit of minerality.

T - A lovely honey note over a soft, undefined apple or pear flavor, with steeped tea acidity and limestone as the sweetness washes away, then a bitter close that skirts the line between pith and aspirin, staying on the right side fortunately and finishing clean.

M - This beer is so drinkable, despite the fairly challenging flavor profile, because it lands light, closes dry, and leaves you looking for the next drink.

O - The style is not one I seek or particularly enjoy, but this beer illustrates why a good lager of this type can be an enjoyable experience that people want to consume while downing pretzels and sausages. Prost!

"Best by 3/3/22"; drank 2/16/22 @ the Yarchives.

See-though orange rust appearance.

A rough pour yielded a big off-white head; frothy lace.

Sweet corn, yeast & raw wheat notes in the nose.

Medium mouthfeel.

Sweet corn & dry wheat flavors up front; yeast & faint caramel notes on the finish.

A bit clashing, to this palate at least.

L- Pours amber gold with quickly dissipating head
S- Caramel malt and floral hop aroma
T- medium sweet malt followed by mellow bitterness
F- Medium body high carbonation
O- Highly drinkable and well balanced lager
Highly enjoyed this one as well, translucent gold on the look with a half inch of foam from Melt Bar & Grill. This went down easy for sure with that mild bread flavor

Poured from a can at fridge temp. Pours a nice murky orange with white head. Head sticks around for a few min and leaves a nice lacing. Nose is caramel malts, honey, mango, a floral note, and maybe a hint of maple syrup. Apple as well. The taste is super smooth and crisp. Malts, bread, grass, granny smith apples, honey, toffee, mango, pineapple, and a bitter leather note at the end. This is very nice and full of depth. Mouthfeel is fairly light and crisp. Overall, I love this beer. Great stuff.

On tap at Dulles airport

L: Pours a deep gold with an orange tint. Clear both a very subtle haze.

S: Bready malt

T: Bready malt and dry hops. More hop punch than most lagers. Complex, yet easy to drink.

F: Medium bodied, crisp, dry finish

O: First dortmunder so nothing to compare it to. I’d like to try more of this style.

Bottle into glass.

L: Deep golden, small but persistent head
S: Very bready, malty.
T: Lots of malt depth, a bit of sweetness and maybe a little fruit alongside the breadiness.
F: Crisp and drinkable
O: Solid entry in the genre. Good beer for summertime.

On draft at Lavergne's Tavern (Berwyn, IL) 12/30/2021

L - bright yellow, full foamy head
S - malt, bread, spicy hops
T - caramelized malts, sweet bread, a touch of noble hop spice
F - light and clean
O - Great beer brewed to style. This is a perfect sixer on the porch beer.

Grabbed a Great Lakes variety pack and this is the first one I tried.

It’s golden to amber in color with a limited amount of foam, moderate carbonation, and clear appearance.

The smell is not too strong for me but the malt does come through. There seems to be a hint of citrus as well.

It’s an enjoyable, easy drinking beer that packs a bit more punch than a traditional lager. It has a medium body with no hip bitterness. I’m looking forward to another one.
Golden-orangeish color. Fresh aromas. Excellent balance of bitterness and sweetness. Very smooth and creamy. I actually like it more on the warmer side, though not quite room temp. Super lager.

draught
Medium orange, with some caramel and amber overtones, in the appearance. Slightly sweet, medium caramelized malt aroma, with a touch of sweet spice and a tiny noble hop note. Very smooth, touch sweet, lightly spiced, moderately roasted and caramelized malt, with a very subtle, floral, noble hop aspect. Medium, creamy mouthfeel, and a caramelized malt and touch of hops, for the finish. Really good!
This beer brings a unique character to the style. It pours and smells similar to a pilsner. The body is complex, sweet and malty with a delicate finish. A definite regular drinker for lager fans

12oz bottle enjoy by 11/7/21 into a tall lager glass.
L: Pours pure rich gold with a 1" fluffy, bubbly eggshell white head that goes to thin. Low carbonation with some free-form lacing.
S: Sweet rich caramel, faint malt, esters, white bread, yeast.
T: Sweet rich dark caramel, butterscotch candy, light pine, orange zest, peach, orange cognac, caramelized toasted malts. Fruity hops weave through semi-chewy malt.
F: Extra smooth semi-randy med-heavy mouthfeel with a clean, high-gloss medium length finish. It is lightly drying.
O: Light bitterness stays on top of the broad malt wave to complete a very full flavored clean drinking and overall semi-sweet American Dortmund Gold Lager. Rich and smooth it is very excellent in it's style.

Pours a "beery" looking yellow with a white head that fades quickly leaving a lightly laced glass. Malty aroma with some mild hops, flavor follows with some "bready" notes. Lightly carbonated, medium bodied. I didn't think I'd care much for this one. I was wrong.

Flavorful and refreshing, a long-time favorite summer beer for me. A year round fav, actually. Clear golden color, low to moderate carbonation, nice head dissolves pretty quickly, pleasing lacing, not too much. Moderately alchoholic, high fives. All in all, a superb, restrained brew, that doesn't cry out for attention. But you realize that it deserves attention: perfect balance of malt and hops, (for a lager, that is). To me, the equal of some of the most enjoyable lagers I've had in Germany.
I tended to avoid this because I thought the style was boring compared to others but sometimes you learn to appreciate a well crafted beer of any style.

Drinking this at home.
Poured from a can into a pint glass.
Looks dark brown almost black with a nice foamy tannish head.
Smells malty, sweet, chocolate, coffee.
Mouth feel is medium for the style.
Overall a nice stout that I would definitely drink again.

RBESG 2006 Grand Tasting. Pitch black colour, low tan head. Very nice roasty and hoppy aroma, some sweetish bakery notes in the background. Nice roasty flavour, not overdone, notes of good coffee, hints of dark chocolate. A very good stout in my book.

On tap at Rogue in Newport. The color is opaque black, with a nitro head and huge frothy bubbles that are retained on a solid crown. The smell is super oaty, sweet, mollasses, cream, and dark rich malt, not much toast. The taste betrays the smell with licorice and rich oats up front, shifting into sarsparilla and rich toasted malt, finishing on a lingering hop notes and mollasses sweetness. Finish wise this is a dry stout for me, and the mouthfeel is thin for a typical stout and finishes moderately dry, which i find interesting.

This is a great oatmeal stout that stands out different from others that rely on heavy cloying sweetness so often. Great job!

A- This one pours a very dark brown color and is fairly hard to see through, but some light does pass. The head is rich and creamy, about two fingers in thickness initially and settles fast into a thick layer of foam above the brew itself. Carbonation appears to be about average for the style, while the lacing is tan colored, with very little in terms of cling around the inside of the glass. Decent looking overall

S- Lots of cocoa initially, which gives way to a slightly soapy tang. Underlying notes of black coffee, grassy/grainy oat flake, dark fruit remnants, dark chocolate nougat malt sweetness, and dare I say a piney quality that reminds me of the outdoors....interesting!

T- There is some citrus peel zest, piney resin and overall this isn't good for the style. Unfortunately, it overtakes the chocolate/coffee/char that I was hoping for. As for the more traditional flavors, they are there, but are all over the place, and are more noted on the finish than rather in the middle of the taste. There is a weird lingering aftertaste that is more of hops than anything. The oat dryness is present and I think this is enhancing what I am not liking about the flavors here, which is unfortunate, as I normally like a good Oatmeal Stout.

M/O- Medium bodied and the carbonation is fairly robust too, providing more of a pale ale vibe than anything. Drinkability is poor for this reason and overall this falls short in what I was expecting this to be. Rogue is generally a favored brewery with its offerings in my opinion, but this is about as interesting and enjoyable as a Shakespearean play. Not good.

Poured from a bottle into a stout glass.

Pours a very dark-brown (nearly black) opaque with a creamy dark tan head that lingers for the last finger, giving way to exceptional foam and lacing.

Aromas of bittersweet chocolate, dark coffee roasted malts, and dark fruits.

The brew hits the tip of the tongue with bittersweet chocolate and hints of coffee and roasted grain. And then---the main event arrives in midstream. BIg oat flavor rises above the din, with the grainy oats blending with some subtle but solid dark fruit flavor. Deceptively hidden grassy and earthy hops augment the coffee and chocolate bitterness and bring it all home.

The brew is just shy of full-bodied, with the grainy oats providing a drying finish. Very drinkable for the style.

Exceptional representation of the style.

From old, undated notes. Poured from the bottle.

Pitch black, no light passes.

Nice khaki head which dissipates but doesn't disappear.

Strong lacing.

Mild cocoa nose.

Medium thick mouthfeel.

Oats kick in with the taste; hops are clearly present as well.

A lot going on here; the oats & hops mixing creates an odd metallic effect on my tongue. For all that it's really drinkable and certainly unique.

If you like dry oatmeal stouts, you'll like this one. Rogue makes good stuff, but I expected just a bit more here. It's very oatmeal-heavy, with just a bit of creaminess but not as much as I'd have thought, and a bit of smokiness as well. Yes, it's very dry.

(12 oz bottle, 19559... poured into a nonic)

L: relatively high-rise dark tan foam stand on pour; collapses slow, holding a tight, creamy construct; dark brown liquid, reddish highlights... chunky collar and dark tone to foam remains; a few nice wide bands of lace

S: dark chocolate milk, chocolate cake; subtle toasty-roasty and char notes; earthy, woodsy/piney background hop essence... shows a lil old leather as it goes

T: smooth roasted barley wash up front, cakey malt middle, hint of dark coffee in the finish; big robust piney bitter afterburn humming with the charred roast in the aftertaste; back end is relatively dry - majority of sugars express burnt caramelization... roast and bitter last a long time; delicate toffee-ish sweetness builds

F: the bitterness, roast, and ample carbonation fray the ends, balancing out the husky milkiness of its body... alcohol plays real light... feels like a meal unto itself; soft oily, resinous residual film

O: takes me back!... this used to be a regular (bomber-size) swill of mine back in the early aughts - moved on to other breweries, styles... don't see this too often anymore; happened to find this at State Line, thought I'd take a trip down fuzzy-memory lane (1403)
From Labirratorium. In Teku glass. Playing Khimera. Dry and bitter,with soft roastyness and some chocolate and coffee notes.Nice but I expected more smooth and creamy body and stronger flavors

1 x 12 oz Bottle
Bottled on: 07.25.2022
Glass: Snifter
Serving Temp: 59.7 F
ABV: 10.0%


Look:
The color is a slightly darker than medium but bright copper with an off-white to cream colored head. The head starts at 2 fingers high (in a snifter) the quickly dissipates to a thick ring and solid island. Good lacing is left on the glass.

Smell:
Rich toasted caramel and toffee. Vanilla, some wood, and some notes of sweet cherries. The nose is sweet, but it is very pleasant. Hops cannot be detected.

Taste:
Toasted caramel and toasted bread are joined by nice whiskey notes along with faint woody and earthy ones. Very mild hops flirt in the background with almost undetectable notes of grass. Near the end of the sip a nice warming sensation develops. The sip finishes as it begins, but with that mentioned warmth added in.

Feel:
Smooth, creamy, and a tad chewy. The body is medium to medium-full.

Overall:
A very tasty beer that is nice for a chilly (or cold) fall night. This one is a slow sipper, not one that you'd fill a half-liter or liter Masskrug and down with abandon.

This a pretty good beer. But it really isn't an amber Marzen nor a golden Festbier. It does fill a niche where you don't quite want a Backwoods Bastard or a Curmudgeon variant (if those are still brewed) and a Marzen just isn't quite enough.

My ratings reflect my overall impressions of this beer, not how closely it hews to style. (It iwas listed as a Märzen) when this review was written)

Pours a clear golden copper color with a thin beige head , Smell has malts ,bread,barrel wood and caramel . Taste has caramel ,malts and baked bread ,followed by slight barrel notes ,woos and toffe. Mouth feel bready malty light on the barrel .

It is a rather chilly Friday evening and it is the first of 2022. I decided a barrel aged Oktoberfest might warm up this old tired body.

Poured into a 13 oz Snulip glass bottled on 7/25/22. Pours a very attractive clear amber orange with a 2 finger off white head that leaves a few streaks of lace with nice retention. 4.5

Aroma is the oaked bourbon hits the nose first, vanilla, caramel, toffee, fig, and warming alcohol. 4.25

Taste follows oaky bourbon, caramel, toffee, vanilla, fig, and a hit of alcohol warms the body. 4.25

Mouthfeel is little bigger than average, gentle carbonation, not sticky or dry, and at 10% ABV it goes rather easy. 4.25

Overall this is nice beer to sip on a cold fall evening. If you enjoy Oktoberfest beers and bourbon this one from Founders Brewing Co. 4.25

Look - great copper clear with a nice white head and some lacing
Smell - woody caramel grainy
Taste basically just like the smell
Feel - medium full body and creamy
Overall - interesting take on an Oktoberfest

Founders Brewing Co. "Ultimate Oktoberfest"
12 fl. oz. brown glass bottle "Bottled On: 07.25.22 1651 6" and sampled on 09.19.22
$5.29 @ Total Wine & More, Cherry Hill, NJ

Notes via stream of consciousness: So what makes this the "Ultimate Oktoberfest"? Is it the 10% ABV or the Bourbon barrel aging, or both? Let's find out. It looks like a typical traditional Märzen with a mostly clear deep amber body beneath a short head of white foam. Unfortunately that's dropped and I haven't even raised it to give it a whiff - not so "ultimate" in my book. The aroma is good but I don't get a lot of Bourbon or wood, I mainly get caramelish and toasty malt and alcohol. Hmmm, maybe the taste is better? ... ... ... Yes, definitely. It's malty with a light touch of fruitiness. I'm assuming that they've used some Vienna malt here as that'll give you a touch of berry-like fruitiness. It's also bready though so there's probably some Munich malt in there as well. Caramel malt, yes, of course, and mostly golden. It's not as toasty as I thought it would be given the aroma, and there's definitely more Bourbon and oak than I was expecting as well. The alcohol, unfortunately, remains fairly clear but at the same time I expect it to at least some extent and it's not harsh or anything, just clearly noticeable. Ahh, as it warms I'm getting a little bit of a coconut note which is unexpected but quite welcome, and the malt appears more honeyish. A hint of vanilla from the oak rounds it out and the overall maltiness is quite nice. There's enough bitterness there to balance the sweetness of the malt, and just a dollop lingers in the finish. As for hop flavor there's a mild herbal note and some spiciness (unless that's the alcohol), and that also lingers in the finish shortly. I don't know that I'd call this the "Ultimate Oktoberfest" but it is quite good. In the mouth it's full bodied and creamy-smooth with a moderate, fine-bubbled carbonation that at least partially explains the lack of head retention. The 10% ABV also explains some of that. In the end I'm thoroughly enjoying this.
Review #8,255

L - Copper with an off-white head that dissipates somewhat quickly leaving behind minimal lacing
S - sweet bourbon and caramel along with malt dominate the nose
T - Sweet, rich bourbon up front and throughout with full notes of caramel and vanilla along with some bready malts along with oak, slight hops
F - medium leaning on full bodied with light to moderate carbonation. Smooth, somewhat syrupy
O - This is pretty interesting. It's good, but the barrel aging really seems to dominate the overall marzen style. A good beer, but I'll probably be sticking to more traditional fest beers

Bottle. Clear bronze golden color. Head fades quick.

Vanilla, oak, caramel, bourbon. Hardly tastes like an Oktoberfest but I like it. Toffee and some bready malts, but all barrels. Warming, smooth, I like it.

Pours a reddish copper, clear, with a light head of foam. Aroma is caramel and some butterscotch with some bready overtones, though faint. Taste is clean and predominantly caramel with a very faint wood grain at the end of the throat. There is little bourbon, in my opinion. ABV is considerably well hidden. A solid Oktoberfest and perhaps my favorite.

Very good head production and decent retention. Body is a lovely reddish-amber color, crystal clear.

Very bready nose with herbal hints. It really smells like a classic Oktoberfest, except for the barrel influence - which isn't over the top. Honey, caramel, bread, bourbon, pepper, vanilla. I'm not really sure what to think of the nose, but it's certainly pleasant.

A beer like this runs the risk of being sweet to the point of cloying, but that's not really the case. The bourbon - and the high ABV, to be sure - does add a layer of sweetness, as well as tasting notes of vanilla, honey, and coconut, but there's still a bready, malty Oktoberfest here. Additional tasting notes include caramel, prune, white bread, and pumpernickel.

Fairly noticeable alcohol sting. Medium bodied. Very clean alcohol flavor that one normally gets from spirits, and seems out of place in a beer.

I can't really imagine pouring a Stein of this at an Oktoberfest celebration, but drinking a single glass at your own pace, on your own time, is a pretty rewarding experience. It doesn't all quite work, but it doesn't exactly not work, either. It's a worthy experiment, but it doesn't quite have its own niche, falling between two worlds: one of flavorful but clean lagers, and one of slow-sipping, full-bodied imperial beers. I don't know what mood I would have to be in to want another, frankly.

Pours a beautiful clear orange/amber with a thin off-white cap. that leaves spotty lacing. Aroma is caramel, malt, dark bread and bourbon. Flavor follows the nose, a bit sweet and not what I'd consider as an Oktoberfest, but damn is it tasty. Feel is medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Overall, again not what you'd think of when you think Marzan, but leave it to Founders to add some zip.

12oz bottle into a pint mug. Bottled 7/25/22.

Looks pretty good. Crystal clear dark amber body. Small white head shrinks to a ring and faint covering, spots of lacing.

The barrel is very apparent on the nose, but smooth.

On tasting, well, just too much barrel for this palate. It's certainly smooth, but every time the base Marzen tries to assert itself, the barrel is there to kick it back down.

Mouth full, finish smooth bourbon.

Overall, personally I don't think this is a style to barrel age.

Look blurs the line between a deep copper and ruby amber ale. Clear but not crystal clear. Very nice frothy head though.

Smell is kind of void. Whack. Honestly all I'm getting is faint sea water. A strange anomaly of a smell I've noted quite a few times before with always seemingly nothing else detectable. I wonder what the common denominator is in these beers that I smell this and nothing else. Or I'm just off?

Taste/feel. Very interesting. Definitely get the barrel right up front. Insanely, insanely dry. Flavors are very, very tame and subdued. It has tastes like a very light oktoberfest with an extra sweet element - butterscotch tbh, but not diacetyl. Apart from the overlapping barrel the beer is the farthest thing from complex ever. Its overall not that flavorful apart from the massive barrel that dick slaps you right upfront and lingers far after the finish.

Overall - and I immediately thought this as soon as it touched my lips but I wanted to jot down my notes before coming back to it - its a very nice barrel aged scotch ale. Yes, okay, it's a lager but this drank blind and 100/100 people will tell you its a scotch ale (which is an underrepresented style tbh). Overall score it tricky. I like it but don't love it. I'll happily drink the second I bought and probably buy a few more if im lucky enough to stumble upon them but won't intentionally seek out or trade for. Overall 4.25

Pours a clear copper color, small quickly fading white head. Snot factory gets some caramel and some bourbon. Doesn't have the typical Oktoberfest flavors, thin, no carb5to speak of. An interesting take on Oktoberfest beers, good, but a one'n done.

12 oz bottle from Mega-Bev in Battle Creek, Michigan. A bottling date of 26 July 2022 is stamped on the back label.

Appearance. Served in a Belgian snifter, this exceptional marzen has a fine dark copper colored body with high clarity and a very good white head.

There's a pronounced, but not over the top, BBA influence in this outstanding Oktoberfest beer. Good complexity, with quite a bit more in the way of woody notes in the flavor than in the aroma where whisky and grain notes are dominant.

Overall. Well worth seeking out, especially if a fan of BBA beers. Caution: this easy drinking Oktoberfest has high but fairly well hidden ABV>.

Bottled on 7/25/2022. Poured into a Seidel glass. It pours a hazy, honey-amber color with a half finger of creamy, ecru-colored head and lacing. The barrel really influences the smell; the bourbon notes are subtle but distinct. There is also an unexpected grassy aroma. Only as it warms a bit do I detect the nutty caramel in the nose. The bourbon taste is very unique. Again, the bourbon influence is quite strong. But as it warms the Märzen taste emerges. It has a good, creamy mouth feel with pleasant carbonation, and it's definitely big at 10% ABV. Overall, this is one of those "only in America" beers. To me, the notion of an "Imperial Märzen" is oxymoronic and while the idea of a bourbon-barrel aged Oktoberfest is intriguing, it's also a bit gimmicky. I guess Founders has achieved its goal with this beer but I can't help but think it's messing with something sacrosanct.

Light amber with a 3/4" off white head, which slowly fades to a wisp. Moderate lacing.

Aroma of caramel, toffee, spices. Whiskey like.

Taste is caramel, light toffee, spices.

Medium body, moderate carbonation. Semisweet finish.

One of the best Oktoberfest beers I've had.

August - September 2022 Barrel-Aged Series Release - 4 pack
12 oz. bottle dated 07/25/22 - 10% ABV / ? IBU
Brewed and bottled in Grand Rapids, MI
Poured into a Bell's branded tulip snifter glass

Look - Pours a thick and dense off-white head that dies down pretty quickly. Clear, dark amber appearance with a lot of streaming carbonation.
Smell - The scent is very faint, but it's mostly bourbon with some malt in the background.
Taste - The taste follows the nose with zero bitterness or alcohol taste.
Feel - Medium bodied with a slightly crisp mouthfeel and finishes dry.
Overall - Not as good as the regular Oktoberfest, because the flavors are more faint and not as wide ranged. That being said, it is a good beer and is easy to drink despite the high ABV.

Four pack purchased 9/1/22 from Wegmans. Date on bottle 7/25/22. Poured into a wilibelcher glass.

L- Clear amber color with a very thin head.

S- Sweet caramel nose with light bourbon
aroma.

T- Mostly bourbon flavor upfront, but not
overpowering. Not a whole lot of the
bready malty- ness from a Marzen.

F- Smooth mouthfeel.

O- I really like this take on an Oktoberfest!
Different, slightly boozy, but not in
an off putting way!

Bottle
L-clear light ochre with minimal head.
S-yes,bourbon but also caramel and bready notes
T-here the emphasis reverses from the aroma with malty flavors leading and faint bourbon and sweetness in the aftertaste
F-plenty of warmth as you’d expect from the abv, but overall medium bodied and smooth
O-a well composed beer that executes well on its style and bourbon barrel niche. In the end, the bourbon flavors complement rather than overwhelm a solid beer. I’d gladly enjoy this one again

A - Dark clear caramel color with thin lacing.

S - Caramel malt nose with some Bourbon mixed in.

T - Sweet caramel malt, Bourbon, and vanilla. That's it.

M - Big medium body with some alcohol warming.

O - This one is a palate twister.

12oz bottle. Poured out a clear, burgundy color with golden highlights and a small, khaki-colored head of foam. It left sudsy trails of lace on the glass. It smelled of bourbon, oak, vanilla, toffee and sweet caramel. Great bourbon taste with vanilla, oak, rich toffee and sweet caramel.

12 oz can dated 8/12/22 consumed from a tall tulip on 9/22. Beautiful deep gold/amber color with fluffy white head upon initial pour, very clear/no haze, but I was a bit disappointed at how little lacing was left and how short the head lasted. Smell and taste as advertised; pine resin, some grapefruit rind, classic west coast IPA profile. Pretty hoppy/bitter. Medium body, medium carbonation, but smooth mouthfeel. IMO, not nearly as nice as their 25th anniversary offering. At the price I probably won't revisit this one, unless I buy a single can to reconfirm my initial impression.

Can dated 8/9/22 into pint glass. Pours a gorgeous crystal-clear honey-gold with a big, blocky, cream-colored head. Great lacing! Initial impression is bitter citrus, pine resin, and grapefruit rind. Mouthfeel is clean and medium thick, with a good deal of carbonation. Alcohol is fairly well hidden. Finish fades to a pronounced pine and citrus bitterness. Overall, a fine old-school West Coast DIPA.

I appreciate this brewery, solid line up (maybe a little over priced at times) and good specials.
I'm generally a fan of the IIPAs and expect the same here.
Dark golden and very clear. Full white head. Rich earthy hop aroma. Nice full feels. Some hop excess in the taste and that moves to a prominent bitterness that last middle through a long finish. A touch of sweetness and a malt fullness in feel but otherwise this is a hop forward and hop dominant drink.
Not sticky and moderate feel. Quite smooth once the sharpness settles down as it warms.

Canned on 8/9/2022 so approximately 5 weeks old when reviewed. Poured into a pint glass. It pours a bright, clear golden honey color with more than a finger of creamy, eggshell-colored head and thick, soapy lacing. Lots of bubbles ascend the glass. The smell features floral hops with notes of lemon peel, grapefruit, and onion. This is a classic West Coast IPA with very bitter citrus and biting Centennial hops. There is also a strong malty backbone but there is almost no sweetness at first. However, as the ale warms in the glass I begin to taste some balancing caramel - although it never overcomes the stringent bitterness. This ale has a moderate mouthfeel with fairly lively carbonation and at 9.7% ABV it has great substance. Overall, if you enjoy an old school West Coast IPA with huge bitter citrus and modest malt presence, then you should seek out 26 Anniversary Imperial IPA while it's available. Really enjoyable! As a bonus, it should age fairly well in the can so don't be put off by the canning date if you haven't tried it yet.

From a 12oz can dated 8/9/22 (enjoy by 12/7/22) into my trust Fenway Park pint glass.

Pours a translucent golden orange with about two fingers of off-white head. Very good lacing and retention.

Smells are faint but picking up some citrus, citrus peel, apple and floral notes.

Taste is big, bold and bitter. Pine and resin up front and all the way through. Some citrus peel and citrus tagging along for the ride. Some alcohol, not surprisingly in there as well.

Strong bitter aftertaste. Sticky. Warming from alcohol. Medium to low carbonation. Bit of a chore to drink due to the alcohol taste.

This is good and it's what Stone does-big and bitter. Not their best work though.

Fairly dark coppery body, perfectly crystal clear. Excellent head production and decent retention.

Quite a bit of toasted malt on the nose, crackery and grainy, not unlike a massive amber ale. Naturally, it's dosed with a hefty ration of hops, with notes of pine, bark, candied orange, and grapefruit peel. I wouldn't say it's a dead ringer for a near-10% ABV version of Stone IPA, but the pedigree is certainly evident.

Flavor follows. It's a bitter bomb through and through, equally bold in presentation of hops and malt. Strong semi-sweet notes of caramel, bread, and brown sugar are balanced by orange, pine, honey, leather, and grapefruit peel.

There's some heft to the malt body that belies the boozy strength, and a bit of alcohol bite, but this drinks incredibly smooth. An excellent beer, insanely drinkable for the ABV. Nothing particularly new, but a near perfect reinvention of a classic style.

Can from Uptown Market.

Amber with a dense off-white head with excellent retention and lacing. The nose is a blend of crystal malt and plenty of hops, citrus, pine, resin. Pine oil. The palate opens oily and bitter, resiny and pine heavy with orange peel. Mildly sweet but with some caramel. Bitter, oily finish. Medium in body.

12 ounce can.

Bottom of can reads:
"CA 08/12/22 E1137
EJBY 12/10/22"

Moderate pour yields a 1.5 inch off-white head over a copper body with sticky lacing.

Nose of mostly pine with a bit of malt and citrus.

Taste mirrors nose closely with pine resin leading the way backed up by some citrus notes.
Finishing bitterness is almost all pine resin with a hint of malt sweetness.

Great mouth fulfilling mouthfeel. ;)

Overall, another wonderfully bitter hop bomb from Escondido, CA.

Cheers!

A-golden with a huge frothy head
S-melon, berries, pine
T-same as the nose, above average bitter
M-Medium full with oily sticky, above average carbonation
O-I hope that Stone keeps cranking this one out in spite of them being acquired by Sopporo

A dark but shiny amber brew arrived in a pint glass, yes a pint glass, after drawn from a tap. Its white head is modest, but enduring. Sweet malt and soft piney hop aromas merge above the glass. This drinks richly and smoothly, but there is an alcohol bite with it and the esophagus feels the burn. The balance between malty sweetness and hoppy bitterness is a great one. At the onset this almost tastes too sweet, as at the alcohol seems to exaggerate the maltiness. The wonderful balance is best noticed midway through. During the finish the alcohol manages to amplify the bitterness of the hops. The hopping can best be described as piney and resinous. As with many high octane ales, the glass lacing is sparse. Despite its qualities, one pint will be enough for one sitting.

Canned on: 08-09-22

A - Dark medium copper gold color with thin white head resting on top with moderate carbonation.

S - Light caramel malt, sticky pine, and citrus on the nose.

T - Citrus, grapefruit, resiny pine, some light biscuity malt, and ends with an aggressive and lingering resiny pine and citrus finish.

M - Big medium body and very dry on the back of the tongue.

O - This is one bitter brew. Enjoying it!

Poured from 12oz. can. Darker Amber, not much head, with mild, active lacing. It is mildly floral. There is a clear 'Centennial Hop' flavor here. Know that. It has some of your usual West Coast IPA suspects (pine, citrus, grapefruit, etc). In my opinion tastes a little dank. It has a medium body, not all malty and chewy. It goes down easy. It is not too boozy tasting, but the alcohol becomes very obvious about 1/2 way though the beer. I LOVE dry hopped (or double dry hopped) beers so I was excited for this, however I am not a huge Centennial fan. So for me, this is not one I will be buying more of. If you like a Firestone Double Jack, or a Bells Double Two Hearted, or even drink a lot of the regular Stone IPA, then you may love this one.

12oz can stamped Packaged 08/09/22 Enjoy By 12/07/22 10:37 R poured into a Spiegelau IPA glass at fridge temp 9.7% ABV. The beer pours bright honey colored amber with off white head. The head recedes to a rocky cap and leaves rings of lacing. The aroma is moderate in strength featuring caramel, candied citrus and pine. The taste is semisweet grapefruit with caramel malt and light pine coming through on the finish. Heavy bitterness. The mouthfeel is medium bodied with average carbonation and a semi dry finish. Plenty of slick hop oil presence, but not syrupy. Overall, excellent high ABV, West Coast IPA.

Pours a very effervescent gold with 3 fingers+ of fluffy cream colored head. Lovely head retention & lacing

S: Cakey, a little pine once warm

T: Cakey, piney, a little grapefruit up front. More dryness & pine as this warms up, some pineapple notes . Finishes a little dry with pineapple & cakeyness & a little bit of woody hops as well

MF: Fairly chewy, low carbonation; nice balance

Easy to drink, good no nonsense Imperial IPA, nose could be more

Pours into a snifter a clear amber/bronze with a thinner white head atop.Stone fruit and resin come thru with a tinge of hot alcohol in the nose.Resiny hops are the main play maker on the palate but they don't punch your taste buds too hard,nice in that old school way.It's really good,close to great.

On tap at Stone Pasadena. This here is damned good.
They did well for this Anniversary. Reminds me of Old School Stone IPAs. Bitter,Danky,Piney and Big ABV.
Reminds me why i love Stone so much.

Pours a clear amber color with a nice head and lacing
Aroma has generous malt and piney hints
The taste follows the nose with a generous malt and piney flavor
A medium bodied well carbonated beer
A good IIPA

Scaling up and scaling out, Stone gets a little retrospective as they head into year number twenty seven. Looking to the quarter of a century in the making of their flagship IPA, Stone Brewing goes and turns it up to 26.

Doubling down on that IPA, Stone 26th Anniversary Imperial IPA catches the eye with its finely hazy deep golden appearance. Glowing softly, the scent starts to grow with a peppery dankness laced with citrus and hints of stone fruit. All wrapped in a caramelized cocoon of malt, the scent soon gives way to a malty-sweet upstart of light toast, granola and floral suggestions of honey.

A quick transition toward bitterness happens as soon as the ale splashes the middle palate where its malt sweetness starts to dissolve and the floral potpourri and citronella of the nose turns crisp and fruity with pink grapefruit, bitter orange and a hint of jammy apricot. Turning the corner in the final frame, the fruits develop a bitterness of pith and peel while the resinous nature of pine, grasses and botanicals create a dry and bitter late palate.

Stone 26 is a dedicated bitter bomb that'll have the tastebuds crying for mercy. Full bodied, dankly resinous and gripping the gullet with its strong hop bite, Finishing decidedly on the bitter side of bitter-sweet the session concludes with a long and spicy bitterness of pinesol and peppery hemp. ...but in a good way.

On tap in Meridian. I mean, it’s fine, what did I expect? A little more Amber-colored than I expected, crystal clear though. Pine, malt, resiny bitterness shine, not quite a ‘Ruination’ of my palate but strong, for sure. It’s good but it’s also very familiar, not sure if that’s a bad thing though because I’m pretty sure that’s what Stone is aiming for.

Canned on 8-9-22. 12oz can poured into a tulip.

Pours golden with great clarity and transparency; small white head that fades leaving decent retention and sticky lacing.

The aromas are subtle. Some breads, caramel, and malts leading the way. Hints of lemon and citrus. Some floral notes as well.

The flavors are bolder than the nose indicates. Great hop flavors. Nice blend of floral and citrus. Lots of lemon. Some pine and earthy fresh grass. Hints of caramel. Really solid bitterness. Malts do their thing. Finishes dry. Mild warmth in the finish, but it's not hot or boozy. I guess I'd consider this one dangerously drinkable.

Mouthfeel is full-bodied with moderate carbonation. It's fluffy and smooth.

This is a nice DIPA. Great job of showcasing Centennial hops. The bold hop flavors really takes this one to the next level. It's really enjoyable and fun to drink. Well done.

Huge head production and fantastic retention and lacing. Body is black as ebony.

Very aromatic from the initial pour, with resinous notes along with candied orange, pine, and star fruit. Perhaps a touch of licorice and brown sugar, but very little else belying the dark roasty legs. That's not a bad thing, necessarily, as Black IPAs (IMO) should still feature the hops prominently, and this one does.

The malt base certainly makes an appearance on the palate, however. Immediately, it comes across kind of creamy and rich, almost - but not quite - like milk with powdered chocolate, or a tootsie roll. This provides a thick base for the bitter and expressive hop notes, including grapefruit, lemon, mango, resin, and pine.

The darker malt returns again on the back end, with a touch of licorice and perhaps molasses. The long-lasting aftertaste is all bitter hop oils.

This is an interesting Black IPA. It's remarkably balanced between the hops and malts. It somehow seems to emphasize the latter without coming across like a hoppy stout; it's still very much an IPA, but the hop flavors aren't quite as explosive (and certainly not as modern) as I would expect. I'm not sure which varietals are in play, but it reminds me more of SNPA and Founders Centennial than Tree House - so, I'm expecting classic PNW hops.

This is really delicious, even if nothing is screaming for attention. Lawson's made a big Black IPA verging on imperial strength that is somehow subtle and restrained.

Pours a a dark brown with a 2F stiff fluffy head and moderate lacing.

Smells of slightly dank grassy piney hops and toasted malt.

Tastes of toasted malt, molasses and coffee moderately bitter from beginning to end.

Medium body with light carbonation. Dry mouthfeel.

Nice. Like a hoppy porter.

Poured from a 16oz can stamped 08/20922 to a Nonic at fridge temp.
This pours black like a full stout. A really impressive tan head with hills sits on top and laces the whole session through.
The aroma is muted by the impressive head, but later on in the session there is caramel with fruity hops pushing through. Still subtle though.
The taste is all malt in the front. Chocolate, charcoal, Milard reaction. There is a hop finish (thank you). I dries things out and gives a little hint of fruit but frankly it's not enough to really call this a n IPA.
Mouthfeel is medium, with an illusion to stickiness, and carbonation is appropriate.
A little more hop hit at the finish would make this an amazing beer. As a lover of dry beers though, I like it.

Pours black with a creamy tan colored head; pretty vigorous and quick formation, as it settles there is plenty of lacing left behind, full film lacing on side opposite of drinking…some great retention too.

This is definitely a black ipa, the hops jump out of the glass. There is an underlying dankness to this beer with very pleasant hints of evergreen and damp earthy forest air and just the slightest hint fruity grapefruit; underneath it all is some roastiness with minor notes of coffee. Smelled a good 5 minutes before taking a sip…

Oh boy! What a shot of resiny hoppy goodness. This is like biting into a hop cone hugely grapefruit forward with a substantial sappy pine note. Much like the nose it’s all hops first; aftertaste and finish is very roast forward and comes off as more a bitter dark chocolate than the coffee expected from the nose.

Medium body; a smoother than expected carbonation, almost creamy. Huge bitterness on the finish both hop and roast driven. Lingering dry and resiny feel tingles on the tongue long after the sip is gone. Minor hint of warming form the abv.
Picked-up a four-pack of cans at Bradford's in Plymouth for about fifteen dollars. My nineteenth brew from these guys. Not a style I normally seek out, but I really liked this.

"Big Hoppy" can. Near black. Dense light brown head lotsa lace. Chocolate orange and pine aroma. Bittersweet chocolate and plum with assertive but not offensive long citrus and resin bitter finish. Beautiful medium-full body and creamy but not heavy feel. World Class. Extremely well made for style and overall. Way underrated IMHO.

Poured into a 16 oz Snulip glass canned on 8/23/22. Pours a very dark brown with a 2 finger sticky khaki head that leaves thin webs of lace with excellent retention. 4.25

Aroma is cocoa, coffee grounds, toffee, marijuana, and pine. 4.25

Taste follows chocolate, coffee, toffee, pine, and again some dankness in the bold finish. 4.25

Mouthfeel is above average, a tad dry, gentle carbonation, and at 7.5% big flavor but easy drinking. 4.25

Overall this one is worth a shot and a must if you like the style like me. 4.25

More like Big Roasty. Black pour with a tan head that stands tall. Exactly what you'd think a beer with 5 hop and 7 malt varieties would be. Big, bold and roasty with a pine bitter backbone. Not a complex beer, but certainly a beer in attack mode--in a good way.

Canned 2 weeks ago.

L -- Pours like a dark porter, allowing minimal light through the glass and producing a two finger light tan head. Great retention and lacing
S -- Chocolate malt, pine, dank hop character, candied orange peel, hint of char
T -- Really nice interplay between the hoppy onslaught of resinous pine, citrus pith, and earthy bitterness alongside a gentle bakers chocolate character that is quite porter-like. The malts aren't overly sweet, but they do cut into the hop bitterness just the right amount
F -- Medium mouthfeel, medium+ carb. Lasting earthiness and dark chocolate notes on the finish
O -- Very unique offering from Lawson's here. Has a real down-home feel to it

84/100

This was poured into an English pint glass. The appearance was a black color with a one finger off white to white foamy head that dissipated in rings at a nice pace. Clingy ringy lace. The aroma starts off with sharp roasted malts with a decent resinous bitter hoppiness coming across huge. Dark chocolate. Resinous pine come forth more as it warms. The flavor resides in the bitterness component of the resinous pine, sharp and embracing with a roasted to bitter aftertaste and finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a nice sessionable to sipping quality behind it. Resinous bitter edges hit hard enough to claim the style. Overall, damn nice Black IPA that I could have again.

This beer pours a nicely hazy orange-ish color with a substantial, dense oatmeal colored head that is a lacing magnet. Beautiful beer. The nose is pineapple, tangerine, and lots of berry aromas.

Those aromas directly are transcribed to the taste, with the berry flavors most enjoyable for me because that’s not a flavor profile typically seen in the hazy space.

The mouthfeel is medium and actually a bit on the dry side, which I appreciate. This is an enjoyable hazy in a literal jungle of hazy offerings. I enjoy it (and will enjoy it through the balance of the 6er), but this old beer nerd would’ve preferred to take a ride with an Oktoberfest collab here in the fall of 2022.

neat beer here for hot weather, its light in body for a hazy, very dry, but still sort of creamy from the oats, high white frothy head from the tap, pale straw color to it, effervescent, awesome looking pour of beer here, and it definitely drinks more like 5% abv than 7% abv, with its dry finish and excited feel. the hop profile is unique, no bitterness here hardly at all, and there is something past the familiar fresh pine that hits the nose first, lemon candy maybe, green pear, its not overly intense but it smells awesome, fruity and new wave, light and bright, summery for sure. some light spiciness on the palate up front, seems like its grabbed onto by the wheat in this and extended a little, could be the azacca there, maybe the cascade too, but its never all that intense, quickly juicy melon and clementine come in, maybe mango too, dehydrated, like its about to be sweet but it never goes there, and the dry cereal grain keeps it grounded. as it warms some white grape and lemongrass come out, but its not overly tropical, it holds that spice nicely to keep it drinking more like ip than juice, which i appreciate. its distinct but also approachable, hard to do, especially in this style, and the mouthfeel is right on. impressed with this, always fun to have new sierra beers, they did a great job making this modern but not derivative.

Hazy pale orange with three fingers of cream color head. Dense fine bubble lace shows as levels drop.
Smell is fruity with some bready malt.
Taste is tropical fruit orange mango and earthy herbal hops. Good amount of bready malt.
Mouthfeel is medium with plenty of carbonation. The finish is mildly dry and slightly bitter.
Overall a decent IPA. Canned on 08-09-22.

#1851.

"72522" dated 12 oz can.

Pours with less then a medium haze, looser and larger bubble cap that lasts a while.

A hint of wood, orange peel and tea on the sniff.

Middle of the road "juicy" IPA.

Some hints of oranges on the palate, also again some woody and tea qualities.

Meh, nothing special going on here....another attempt at the red hot style by one of the big boys in the IPA arena

Sierra Nevada Brewing Co. "Liquid Hoppiness"
12 fl. oz. can "PKGD 070622 03:57" and sampled on 091122
$2.79 @ Total Wine & More, Cherry Hill, NJ

Notes via stream of consciousness: I'm not really sure what to think of this. Another juicy IPA from Sierra? What makes it different? There's nothing on the label but it is 7.0%ABV. It's poured a very hazy golden body with an orange sheen beneath a finger's width of white foam that's holding well. There are both larger and smaller bubbles in the head which is a good sign, and I can see very fine bubbles rising through the particulate in suspension below. The aroma offers tropical notes of orange, mango, distant pineapple, and some woodiness, a light grassiness, and a hint of pine. The taste offers much more woodiness, grassiness, and pine within a fairly wide maltiness. It's not exactly rich, there's not enough there, nor really complex, but it's more complicated than the basic malt that a lot of brewers are using for juicy IPAs. I don't think it's wheat but I could be wrong, and I'm thinking there's some rye there but I think that's because the woody, grassy, and piney hops are suggesting that. I definitely believe are some oats involved as I can taste them. It's an unusual maltiness but I'm not sure how well I actually like it. I think I prefer the more basic malt that lets the hops do their own thing without interference. Anyway, there's less fruit than I thought there would be, and I'm thinking that mango is the dominant note. Of course people taste things differently from each other, and even different from themselves on certain days so who knows. A firm bitterness balances it and it finishes mainly dry with the woody, grassy, and piney hops lingering. It's almost spicy; the woodiness is kind of like cedar. That makes me think of either Sorachi Ace or Sabro hops but neither of those check out in terms of what else they bring to the table so I'm confused as to what they might be using. It's a little floral as well, which I get in the finish. Meh, I'm not blown away by it but it is well brewed. In the mouth it's medium bodied and gently crisp-then-smooth. All in all it's decent enough but I'm just not a fan of the recipe. I thought it would be more "juicy" as it's labeled as a "JUICY IPA" but I do like the spicy woodiness.
Review #8,247

12 oz. can, PKGD 07/05/22 stamped on the bottom of the can. From the 12 pack case; my first review on BeerAdvocate in over 5 years, but i digress.. and alas,

Poured into a Piraat snifter.

A - Pours a crisp fruity orange juice color, with little over a finger of frothy head with lingering lace. Looks excellent.

S - Smell is fresh, fruity, tropical, floral. Very miiiild alcoholic scent is present when you look for it, as are some pale bread malts. Stone fruits. Smells fresh, above all else.

T - Taste brings in much of the same: citrusy orange juice, acidity, & a mild warming alcoholic bite.

F - Smooth, crisp, easy-drinking. Bitter & dry in the finish, which beckons you for another sip. Highly drinkable stuff for sure, one could easily crush three or four or five of these in a session.

Overall, a nice drinkable sessionable beer; though typical of the style. I'd call it a slightly above average though not amazing beer. 7/10 would drink again, which will come out to

Sierra Nevada Liquid Hoppiness IPA -----3.5/5

Poured from a 12oz can stamped 07/20/22 to a Nonic at fridge temp.
This pours hazy light gold but not hazy enough to hide the many many rising bubbles near the glass wall. Despite an average pour I got a large pillowy white head. I had to be patient to get the full 12oz in a 16oz glass. The head lasts quite long, though not the entire session. Lacing is impressive.
The aroma is a little musty and fruity, but almost goes away completely after a few minutes. Sniff early with this one.
The taste is somewhat fruity, but not amazing. Alcohol makes itself known on the finish, this may be a reflection of the almost 2-month age of this can.
Mouthfeel is light for the style and carbonation is on the other end of the scale.
Not bad, but not impressive. Hopefully I will come back and edit this review if I catch a fresh can.

12 oz can from a 6pk poured into a pint glass.

L - Pours a slightly hazy straw-orange color with carbonation and some murkiness throughout. Almost a bit of sediment present but maybe the glass isn't 100% clean. A good finger of bright white head that dissipates leaving a moderate lacing.

S - Faint citrus, honey, malt, slightly hoppy, mostly orange and pineapple coming through with a typical SN Pale Ale aroma. Nothing overpowering or standout.

T - Follows the nose with lots of citrus rind and pineapple. Slightly astringent alcohol in the middle, a decent hoppy bite, not one I'd consider "juicy" compared to others but on the sweeter IPA side. Finished with a little bready malt to balance it out.

F - Light-to-medium bodied, lightly moderate carbonation, slightly wetter finish but drinkable for a 7% ABV.

O - Picked this up as a big fan of SN's offerings, the design, and interest in "juicy" IPAs. While I wouldn't classify this is as particularly "juicy", it's drinkable, fairly balanced, and decently priced for a 6pk. Not sure I'd pick it up again but a valiant effort from Sierra Nevada.

Hoppy, citrusy, some astringency, plenty of bitterness. Not a wow beer, but something I'll gladly repeat, especially given the price point, in a world with too many average hazies on the shelves. I'd like this more with better clarity, assuming it's at least unfiltered given the light attenuation.

Enjoying my first poured into a pint glass from a 12 oz. can. Gentler in the body and the hoppiness when compared to Sierra Nevada pale ale and their Torpedo strong IPA. Lighter in the mouthfeel than both as well and, as such, is more drinkable than both, in my opinion (and I like both). They label it a “juicy IPA” but I don’t find it overly citrusy and, in fact, picked up on interesting spice notes in the aroma. You don’t have to be a hophead to love this beer which is refreshing. I don’t mind aggressively hopped IPAs (usually) but I prefer a cleaner finish with less lingering bitterness at the back of the tongue (Stone IPAs) like I find here. Would love to try a draught pint of this brew. Pleasantly surprised by this blind purchase. Nice job, Sierra Nevada!

12oz can.

Pours clear yellow with a chill haze. Moderate retention and lacing. Mild aromatics of pineapple, melon, and apple. Medium bodied with a crisp mouthfeel. Pineapple with grapefruit on the palate with minimal malt and a balancing bitterness. Finishes dry but not juicy.

Picked up a 6 pack of this from the guns, ammo, liquor and porn store that is Mormon owned. No lies.

Pours a slightly cloudy (not really hazy) yellow color. 1/2" white head. The aroma didn't really display the commercial tugjob re: juicy ipa. The Cascade and Centennial seemed to dominate with just a little input from the other proprietary varieties. Grapefruit is the biggest component, but without the usual Sierra Nevada caramel hit.

Taste is fine. Right away I'm like "Another Sierra Nevada 3.75". There is more influence from the Azacca/Sultana hop set, indeed giving the beer a light pineapple and cranberry like edge. Some more varied citrus, candied orange like impression sets in. Shows off the lighter more nimble malt body than many of the old school Sierra Nevada hoppy beers have. Its a pretty easy drink, nothing in terms of abv or ibu is abrasive.

I don't think it will be around for a long time, it won't become a "classic" beer in their portfolio, but so what, its not here for a long time, its here for a good time, and at $9/6 pack, it definitely provides an affordable good time.

First saw this when i received an email from Half Time. Looked really interesting to me as I like both brewers. My highest rated beer was a collaboration between Toppling Goliath and Tree House. I would think that this brew would be a similarly great collaboration. Was please to learn that it was available at Empire liquors. I walk into “the good beer section” of the cooler and I cannot find it. The beer guy walks in and points in me in the direction of the last 4 pack. It is mine!

Brewers Notes: King AL uses a mashed-up grain bill from MC² and Toppling Goliath’s King Sue before introducing Equilibrium’s absolute biggest dry-hop to date with an all Citra Incognito, Citra LUPOMAX, Citra Cryo and Citra T-90 hop bill. Pouring a milky opaque yellow with aromas of mango sorbet and orange creamsicle, we get chewy saturated flavors of tropical smoothie, fresh squeezed navel orange juice, dank grass, fruit salad in syrup and lime gummies with a thick and custard like creamsicle finish and a huge blast of EQjuice rainbow melon flavors. King AL is dangerously soft and smooth and may have you questioning the laws of physics, space, time or just how we got a melted orange creamsicle fruit bomb into the can.

Chilled can poured into a spiegelau ipa glass . Pale hazy honey colored liquid topped by a creamy white one finger foam cap , reduces to a thick layer and leaves some spotty lacings.

Aroma is orange citrus, faint whiff of mango

Taste is juicy orange citrus, cantaloupe, papaya, apricot, fruit salad, hint of lime

Mouthfeel is smooth, even, flavorful , low sudsing, hop taste, no bite

Good beer , recommended

Poured into a 13 oz Teku glass not sure when it was canned. Pours a hazy milky yellow with a half finger sticky white head that leaves plenty of thin lines of lace, with excellent retention. 4.75

Aroma cantaloupe, passionfruit, papaya, dragonfruit, and apricot. 4.5

Taste follows cantaloupe, passionfruit, papaya, dragonfruit, and apricot really balanced and awesome. 4.5

Mouthfeel is above average, not sticky or dry, soft gentle almost creamy carbonation, and at 7.9% loaded with tropical flavor but really easy going down. 4.75

Overall I trusted my BAs and went and found this. That is the main goal of this thread. Really a great beer experience. 4.5

Pours a hazy golden wheat color with excellent white head and lacing. Smell is definitely EQ its dank herbal juicy and tropical. Taste has lemon spritzes with mangos,melon grapefruit and herbal berries. Mouth feel dank and tropical juicy and herbal ,really good .

Canned on 8/29/22; consumed on 9/21/22

Pours a turbid, baby food-orange body capped with just shy of two fingers of rich, white foam; decent head retention leaves a vague, paper-thin layer of cap, thin, frothy collar, and healthy spatter of soapy, webby lacing sprayed across the walls of the glass.

Aromas burst with a ripe, tropical overload, bringing guava, orange, grapefruit, and tangerine juice into subtle dankness with boggy resins interspersed; lemon gummies accent mango, while shreds of onion deepen an oncoming herbaceousness through the close.

Taste shows orange zest, guava, and juicy papaya upfront, with a slight onion interlude over the mid-palate easing to sweet malts countered late by a delayed, earthy prickle of resins and grass as onion continues to linger through notes of citrus zest on the finish.

Mouthfeel brings a body on the fuller side of medium with a subdued, moderate carbonation, leaving an almost soupy density and gritty resins for contrast; briefly taut through the mid-palate as a juicy build leaves a silky back end and finish.

A sampling of the purest variety across the hop spectrum; diverse, intriguing, and complete in expressing myriad tropical undertones atop a resinous, quasi-bitter base; a sippable coalescence for the hop-inclined senses.

The color is perfect. Golden sunflower honey sunshine yellow. Just how I like it. Minimal foam, which quickly disappears. The smell is strong. Mango, orange, papaya, and honeydew scents are clear. The flavor is a true hybrid of Toppling Goliath Brewing and Equilibrium Brewery at their finest. It has the electric butter of Toppling Goliath Brewing, with the mango candy of Equilibrium Brewery. It tastes like a sweeter version of King Sue. It is delicious. Flavors of mango, orange, papaya, and honeydew come through, just like with the scent. The mouthfeel is soupy, juicy, smooth, and full. The carbonation is light. Overall, this is a very delicious NEIIPA. One of the best.

12 ounce bottle, freshest by 11/26/22 stamped on the label. Thanks to Brutaltruth for this brew! Served in a dimpled mug, the beer pours a clear orange/amber color with not quite an inch off-white head. Head retention and lacing are both decent enough. The brew smells like bready malt and floral/grassy hops. Taste is similar to the aroma, but with the addition of grainy/sweet malt, apple and some caramel flavors. Mouthfeel/body is medium, it's coating and easy to drink with a moderate amount of carbonation. I liked this brew, certainly worth trying if you get the chance to!

Glassware: 0.5 L Festmug
Temp at Pour: 50.4


Look:
Nice medium and clear copper. Initial 2-finger off white head appears creamy and dissipates very slowly to a thickness of a single finger.

Smell:
Nice toasted bread notes along with earthy grains and hints of toffee and a touch of caramel. The noble hops provide notes of grass with a touch of fresh hay and some light floral notes as well.

Taste:
Sweet bready malts and toasted toffee/caramel start things off and are quickly met by the grassy hops that provide a very mild spice and balance the sip out. Some note of pumpernickel or rye float around in the background with a faint nuttiness. The sip finishes dry, a tad toasty, and mildly spicy. The flavors might be toned down compared to some other Märzens but they are impeccably balanced. The high ABV (for the style) is not noticeable.

Feel:
Clean and smooth. Almost creamy. Body is medium-light.

Overall:
I was looking forward to trying this and am glad that I did. Troegs did not disappoint. This is a nice, very easy-drinking amber Märzen. It is going down very quickly. Is it as good as the German staples (Paulaner, HP, Ayinger, Spaten)? Nope. But it is quite good regardless. This will become part of my annual Oktoberfest rotation. I am glad that I picked up a six pack (so far). I'll be going back for more.

The use of Pilsner and Munich malts w/o any Caramel malt was an interesting choice. I think that it works. The lack of Caramel malt is likely what contributes to the toned down flavors (esp malts and toastiness) but it does make the beer more quaffable and lets the dryness come through more distinctly.

12 ounce bottle poured into a dimpled mug.
Freshest by 11/30/22

Very clear copper pour with a decent off-white cap. Moderate strength malty nose, bread and honey mostly. Flavor wise, it’s toasty and somewhat spicy but more herbal, some caramel, only mildly sweet with like bitterness. It strikes an overall balance right through to the finish. Aftertaste is earthy /woody. Mouthfeel is medium weight and a little slick but not creamy.
I could certainly drink more than one of these and believe it’s better than the average American example.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle, dated "freshest by" 12/03/22, into the test mug
A - Beauiful clarity, in the copper colored background. An aggressive pour yielded a pillowy white cap.
The cap slowly dissipated to ring after ring clinging to the glass.
S - Hints of caramel, a grassy noble hop, earthy grains
T - Toasty grains, again hint of caramel, not to sweet.
M - Clean, dry, beautiful grain expression without being overbearing
O - Its as if they best of a tradional festbier , mashed up with a light marzen, just on the line between the two.
Excellent texture, lovely attenuation feeds that near perfect dry finish.

Appearance - golden bronze body with white head

Smell - toffee, caramel

Taste - toasted toffee, caramel, brown bread

Mouthfeel - slight toffee/caramel, pumpernickel bread, some kind of an odd rye spice effect going on at the end

Overall - Pretty nice take on the marzen style, not too sweet nor too hoppy. Worth a shot

Price Point - $2.29/12 oz single

Full disclosure, I poured a 12 oz bottle into a liter stein, so my notes may be off. Troegs' Oktoberfest entry pours a transparent amber with a white head. The nose is of no surprise, malt. I was disappointed with how light the flavor was. The body is smooth and inoffensive. Again, I'm thinking the pour may have something to do with my results.

Poured from the bottle into a Libbey style pilsner glass.

Beautiful looking festbier, with light visible carbonation and a khaki to orange mixed colored head which is superfine. Body color is a golden amber, nearly orange bronze mix which is shiny and glimmering. Very good looking brew.

Quite a neat aroma. Clean sensing but a distinct emphasis on malt that goes with a mix of caramel and distinct milk chocolate as well. Light touches of herbal hop and even a bit of nutty sensations too. Very nice.

Palate fits real nicely. Milky sensations of cream and caramel, with a toasty aroma and hops to match. Light herbal presence not just in the finish but in the mid palate too for excellent malt contrasts. Creamed caramel and milk chocolate seem to be even more pronounced as well, with a robust mouthfeel. Superior clean finish, and even manages to stay dry.

Great brew.

The pour is copper colored with a fair amount of carbonation. The taste is caramel, roasted pine nuts, & a soft earthy herbal note. If I never heard of Troegs brewing I would have could have easily confused this with a Wartsteiner or Hacker Pschorr Oktoberfest beer. Cheers! B

12oz bottle into a pint mug. New release, dating too difficult for these old eyes.

Looks splendid in the glass. Crystal clear amber body with a decent white head. Only a little lacing.

Caramel malty aroma.

On tasting, clean, sweet, malty, no aftertaste. Could drink these all night long. Hop an afterthought here.

Mouth medium, finish a crisp clean sweet wash.

Overall, it's a well made product. Hope Troegs makes it an annual release.

(12 oz bottle, freshest by 120122; purchased single off shelf at Total Wine... poured into a 14 oz mug)

L: polished-clear, tawny-amber liquid; finger-high foam build on pour, collapsing into thin cap... only a thin, crescent collar remains; very little lace

S: lightly-sulfured, herbaceous pretzel crust; a malt aroma rich in depth and dimension; grainy up top, doughy below... nutty and apple-y highlights... slight accent of noble hops; little alcohol presence, just an overtone

T: doughy, moderately-toasty foundation, big and round malts unfloding with each sip... grassy bitter top note in the aftertaste, accompanied by some salty pretzel crust at the back and sides... lingering chewy bread crust essence... missing a small amount of lasting depth or nuance

F: near plush in its texture, mildly inflated core; little latent carbonation... I did drink this relatively 'warm', so maybe it gassed off too much... the alcohol and hops team to stoke a mild heat at the back of the palate... despite its faintly flabby feel, it drinks really darn quick with a soft touch of residual malt sludge

O: they did not disappoint with this; it's pretty much how I wished a few of the other 'big-name' local breweries would've made their O'Fest... worthy of purchase in bulk (2012)

Poured into a wide mouth shaped glass: color is copper, transparent, slight head appears with an off white color then dissipates to a thin ring on the glass sides.

Smell is munich, vienna malt, toast, bread, light fruitiness, pleasant hoppy crispness.

Taste is on the maltier side for style but really well done: notable German malt, toast, bread, slight fruitiness, hoppy crispness to finish.

Mouthfeel is crisp carbonation, moderate sweetness, lower bitterness, lingering crisp sweetness.

Overall a really well done Marzen/Oktoberfest style - sweet malt, moderate crispness/hoppiness.
This Marzen is also really good but fairly typical and not mind-blowing. It's just a really good well executed. I am liking Troegs overall a lot more as a whole though.

Better than I was expecting.
I was expecting this to be overly hoppy for the style as most Tröegs beers are, but I would say they cut off just at the right time. Any more and it would ruin the beer.
Pours the usual color with the usual Märzen flavor, albeit on the higher side of the hop schedule.
Overall, better than I expected but not as good as the German staples.
I'd get it again, but there are others I enjoy more.
Worth a try.

6 pack of bottles from Jungle Jim's
Clear medium to deep amber color with a thin white head, good retention.
Aroma of toasted malts
Taste is malt forward with sweet caramel character and a subtle hop note.
Medium body with good carbonation.
I Like it!

12 oz bottle. Pours amber with tall, long-lasting, fluffy white head and lively carbonation. Aroma is of grassy hops and bready malt. Body is medium and crisp. Grassy hops, grain and caramel malt nicely balanced on the palate. Finish is long and almost dry. Nice brew.

Appearance: Clear, deep amber, large off white head, good lacing.
Aroma: Earthy, toasted malt, some graininess.
Taste: Moderate sweetness. Maintains the toasted malt flavor. Low hop profile. Clean aftertaste.
Mouthfeel: Creamy. Medium bodied. Modest bitterness.
Overall: Malts rule. ABV is a bit high for the style but hardly noticeable.

The body pours a beautiful amber. Good fluffy initial head and lacing throughout. Good looking beer.

Nose is malty with a touch of sweetness.and a passing hop note. Taste follows nose with a good dose of malty goodness. Sweeter than the nose, but not overly sweet. Hallertau hop notes balance the beer providing a nice crisp finish.

Good mouthfeel and solid carbonation.

Freshest by 11/26/22. 12oz bottle poured into a tulip.

Pours a deep burnt golden with nice clarity and transparency; fluffy white head that fades leaving nice retention and lacing.

The aromas have lots of toast leading the way. Lots of caramel as well. Grains and malts come through.

The flavors follow the nose. More toast and caramel leading the way. There's a nice little sweetness coming through. There's also a subtle earthiness as well. Mild bitterness. Solid malt backbone. Alcohol goes unnoticed.

Mouthfeel is medium-bodied with moderate carbonation. It's very fluffy and slightly creamy. Very smooth and easy to drink.

This is a nice Oktoberfest. It's a nice traditional example of the style. Really nice aromas and flavors. Well done.

Pours a beautiful amber with a cream colored head.

Smells of fresh grain slightly piney, grass hops, and homemade bread.

Bread, malty with a slight pine grass hop with herbal undertones.

When poured from a bottle this Octoberfest has a lacy head. A dark Amber slightly clear color. There is a sweetness of malt aroma. With a smooth texture that hits the taste buds with a bit of sweetness and malt flavor. A subdued Maren style German body over all!
At 6.1 abv a very nice fall beer!!

The look is a nice sunset orange/breaded chicken color. The is a 2 velociraptor finger foam top, which is slowly and digested into eternity. The smell is sweet and fruity. The are scents of pear, grapefruit, apple, orange, and cherry. The taste is sweeter than it is juicy, but there are fruit flavors of starfruit, guava, pear, apple, and cantaloupe. There is a touch of bready bitterness. The mouthfeel is soupy, thick, rich, and full, with medium carbonation. Overall, this is a good NEIIPA, but I don't think I would seek it out again.

Poured from a can dated 8/15/22
orange thick orange color, white 1 inch soft head, nice lacing and veil

Aroma is tropical with pineapple and melon notes

taste is tropical fruity and well layered

mouthfeel is thick and creamy, finishes a bit tingly but low carbonation.

overall a nice easy drinking fruit bomb.

On tap.

White head, hazy sunset golden color. For how high the abv and this being a TG beer, I expected much more. This was light and lacking flavor. Very weak ipa that I won’t be drinking again. It wasn’t bad, just not good.

Pours a hazy wheat color with a 1 finger fresh white head. Smell is fruitty and tropical . Taste pineapple berries oranges,melon and papaya . Mouth sweet and juicy more so than dry ,its fruity hoppy very drinkable

Pours an effervescent & hazed gold with 3 fingers of fluffy cream-colored head. Good head retention & lacing

S: Guava, mango, strawberry

T: Follows the nose, green melon & dryness, plus passion fruit & a little pomelo up front. Green melon, passion fruit, tangerine & a little dryness as this warms, just a kiss of pineapple as well. Finishes a little dry with guava, green melon, passion fruit, lime & green melon

MF: Medium body, fairly soft carbonation; lovely balance

Another super solid Hazy IPA from these guys, drink this fresh, I don't think this flavor will hold up over time, but the 3 week old version is lovely!

A somewhat NEIPA look. Light gold and very cloudy. A huge pillowed white head that retains forever. Excellent lacing.

Great aromas. Melon, pineapple, peach, grapefruit, mango, chive, grass, white pepper.

Juiced but not juicy. The bitter and mildly grassy/herb hop notes are more aggressive, lending welcome balance. Orange, grapefruit, peach, mango, and white grape in the front of the palate. Citrus zest and pith in midstream. Grass, chive, and peppery booze (but not boozy) at the finish.

Medium to medium-full bodied but it doesn't feel that heavy. Not sweeet or sticky, but drying on the palate.

An excellent DNEIPA that doesn't feel cookie-cutter, despite the familiar notes. The stepped up bitterness keeps this one balanced.

Canned on: 8-12-22

A - Opaque medium golden orange with very dense sticky white foam resting on top and sticking to the sides of the glass.

S - Mango, passionfruit, tropical fruit, citrus, and peach.

T - Juicy citrus, sweet grapefruit, peach, passionfruit, mango, some tropical fruit, a little juicy floral, and a little bit of fruit rind ending more on the sweeter side with light bitterness.

M - Big soft medium body with prominent chewiness.

O - Yup...this is rock solid. Definitely worth a try.

16oz can. Poured out a cloudy, golden orange color with a small, pillowy white head of foam. It left sticky rings of lace on the glass. It smelled of grapefruit, melon, guava and citrus fruit with some caramel sweetness. Great tropical fruit taste with toasted caramel/toffee and a piney bitterness.

Poured from pint can into proper pint glass. Stamped packaged on 08/12/22.
A: Pours a very thick and hazy orange-yellow hue with 2-3 inch frothy white head with excellent retention.
S: Orange pith, sweet grapefruit, soft pine, tangerine, lime, and some mango cream.
T: Mango cream, orange rind, sweet grapefruit, sweet lemon/lime, soft pine resin, mildly bitter tangerine, and a hint of honeyed melon.
M: Medium body. Thick and juicy feel. Layers of citrus sweetness with some melon. Mildly bitter, especially toward the finish. Lingers nicely on the palate.
D: Such a wonderful hop expression and balance. This is right in TG’s wheelhouse and comes out as one of their best. Super collab brew.

Canned on 8/12/22, consumed on 8/22/22. Head is so dense and pillowy - the platonic ideal. SRM is creamed honey-esque. Haze is perfectly moderate. Smell is so bright and juicy with plenty of pine to back it up. Flavor is a perfect juice/bitter mashup that TG nails so frequently. No booziness, eminently drinkable. Overall fabulous. One of the best I’ve had lately from TG and one of the best overall in a while.

Glad to have found this, the last of the Weihenstephaner's with good Chicagoland distribution that I have not had. (This is my 9th unique.) This review is summarized in my post on this year's O-Fest thread.

This Festbier Looks only slightly above average compared to its style: a beautiful bubbly blond, but very short hair (I mean foam.) Smells open as a malt-head's delight, but end more mediocre. Tastes are balanced, remain sweet but never stay too sweet. Refreshing and medium-mouthed, I want this Fest next year.

Weihenstephaner is one of the great originators underpinning the Bavarian tradition and continuing it one millennium later. And for that, I give them pretty good Overall Hugs.

11.2oz bottle into a 0.3L mug.
L: Pours crystal clear golden caramel w good carbo, 1/4" white head goes quickly to a skin & edge foam, very light lacing.
S: Lightly caramelized malts, warm white bread, grains, very clean.
T: Extremely clean, rich, pure, unmolested caramel malts, a light hop fizz, a fazz, a fizz-fazz, a suggestion of bread, a very light honey glaze, fairly rich and moderately sweet. There's a slight bitter citrus zest tang at the end that lingers but after a minute the tastes just vanish.
F: Gently brisk, clean, glassy& smooth, med to med-light feel with a linger then a sharp drop off. Fairly dry at the finish w good carbo until the end.
O: This beer has a little bite up front then is quite malty w a lighter bodied feel than many. Very clean & well carb'd. An absolutely gorgeous beer with a beautiful blend. It is excellent in it's style.

Nice foamy head and lace, with golden color. Aroma is bread. Taste is toasted malt and bread, with a crisp, clean finish. I rate this one a little higher than the other festbiers I have had. Very drinkable. I could definitely knock down a few of these and listen to an oom-pah band, I love this brewery and buy the Helles often, which is one of the finest beers in the world in my humble opinion.

pour is crystal clear, moderately deep golden yellow with a moderate cap of chalk white foam.
nose is immediately toasted bread crust, nutty, hint of caramel/toffee, lightly browned biscuit
Taste is nutty, toasted malts, biscuit, bread crust. hint of grassy hops.
Wonderful. Very easy to drink.

Definitely aGerman beer, has this bread like taste. Has a slight citrusy zing to it. Light color, sort of light carbonation, body also on the light side. This is very easy to drink! But it isn't that special for me, I wouldn't go out of my way to get it.

Imperial Pint
Look: clear straw yellow, pouring a 2 finger head which dissipated into a sustained cap
smell: doughy malt, zesty and some hops
Taste: Bright and vibrant. Zesty tartness lights up the mouth followed by floral hops with light bitterness leads carrying light wheat grain note. Finish has a hint of malt and lemon zest
Feel: Light mouthfeel, with a crisp and clean finish thats a tad bit on the dry side. Moderate carbonation as well

[At a local Oktoberfest]
vom Fass (on/from Draft)
Glass: 0.5 L Festmug
2022-Sep-18


Look:
Clear and bright golden yellow with a 2 finger rocky head. The head quickly faded to nothing, likely due to the glass not being clean (it was my 2nd beer at the 'Fest)

Smell:
Spicy and floral hops that almost come across as citrusy. Almost. Light bready malts are hiding in the background but are definitely there.

Taste:
Follows the nose/aroma. The light malts are biscuity and even a tad cracker-like. The finish is on the dry side.

Feel:
Crisp and clean but also soft. The body is light-medium or even a shade lighter.

Overall:
A decent Festbier that is insanely quaffable and perfect for a warm day (like today was for a time). This brew is very much like a (slightly) amped-up Helles with some Pilsner hops/bitterness.


-------------------------------------------------------

1.5 x 333 ml bottles
Bottle Date: 1261 => 28 June, 2021
Consumed on: 25 Aug, 2022
Glass: 0.5 L Fest Mug


Look:
Clear golden yellow with a 4-finger frothy and pillowy white head. The head very slowly fades to about a 1 finger of bubbly foam. Lacing is excellent.

Smell:
Mildly Bready and slightly grainy. There is a very light touch of lemon and also of uncut grass. A mild zest is present as well.

Taste:
Very similar to the nose with an extra lightly tart note in there. The sip finishes slightly dry but nowhere near bitter.

Feel:
Crisp and soft. Body is just about light-medium

Overall:
A light, mellow, and easy drinking Festbier. This is very much like a (slightly) amped-up Helles. I prefer Festbiers with more flavor and body, like Tucher, or a Dortmunder like Augustinerbräu-Munchen Edelstoff (which has been served at the Munich Oktoberfest in the past) but this is nice for warmer weather. I am drinking this one in the evening of a 90-degree late August day and it is just fine.

I would have rated this beer perfectly, however, perfection only exists in dreams, so in a rational sense I rate it nearly perfect.

I've been drinking German beer since 1977, and this by far is arguably, in my experience anyway, the best Lager period... It is important to ensure it's fresh.

I'm a fan of Marzen type beer, malty lagers that pack a punch, but are smooth and balanced. I've tried most of all the offerings by European brewers since about 2000 (when I discovered Marzens) and this beer repeatedly beats them all! Hofbrau's Marzen several years ago was also OUTSTANDING...on par or better then this, but last year they cheapened it, and the carnage is again the theme with Hofbrau's version this year. I will never understand this! Hofbrau if you are reading this BE ASHAMED! If you need to charge more because your costs have risen DO SO! Don't make it cheaper!!

The beer is crisp, clear, maintains a nice head ALL THE WAY down in your glass.
