Alas, let's not forget the flavor is IN THE HEAD, hence why when beer performs like this it retains it's crisp, carbonated flavor all the way down. This beer also leaves generous lacings on your glass, and it's a beautiful beer to behold,. Simply near perfect! If you're a fan of the Marzen style, I invite you to try it out. Just be sure it is fresh.

Pulled from fridge and allowed to sit at room temp ~ 10-15 min, before pouring into a round-bottomed stein.

Look: Golden, straw-colored, with a 2-finger, white head. Lots of effervescence

Smell: Light malts, slight fruitiness, some sour notes on the nose

Taste: Light, mild flavor profile. Some initial malty sweetness, followed by light, herbal hops. Lingering sweetness on the aftertaste.

Mouthfeel: Medium-thin, with good effervescence to help bring it body. Very light feel & weight overall, finishes clean, with minimal residue

Overall: Bright, semi-sweet, with herbaceous notes. A very easy, sessionable drinker, and one that is suitable for a multitude of occasions. Definitely worth the buy and worth the diversion from my usual ambers, browns, and darker ales

While very complex, they get it right. There is a lot in this bier, but it all works. I think if I had to drink one beer the rest of my life.... So far this would be it. (Wouldn't be the best for a day on the beach / water / boat when your are looking at a long day and most likely over a 12 pack per person; But I would try)

Look: Clear light orange-yellow with a frothy white head that builds up, holds, and then recedes, leaving sticky lacing clung to the glass’ rim
Aroma: Freshly baked bread, raw bread dough, floral hops, a little honey, and biscuits
Taste: Kicks off with bready malt and a big bouquet of floral goodness – black locust, flowering cherry, and yellow azalea amongst them and followed by a rich doughy punch. Bread, honey, biscuits, and flowers play tug-of-war until floral hops regain dominance on the close
Mouthfeel: Light but full, extremely clean throughout, medium-high carbonation, and a clean and crisp but slightly soft finish
Overall: This is some tasty stuff. I love this beer and am totally biased towards it but it’s hard not to be with how well-made and delicious it is. A Festbier through and through and one of the gold standards at that with plenty of malt, bread, and dough along with a floral hoppy side that shines in these lighter-styled Oktoberfests. Recommended

A wiesen style beer vs marzen. Light crystal clear malty lager with a bit of citrus and hops to balance the sweetness. You can drink this all day in spite of 5.8% abv. Fresh and highly drinkable. Get some.

Sampling a lightly chilled 11.2 oz bottle poured into my .5L dimple mug. Been meaning to get to this since Oktoberfest, just havent opened it. Date code is 0201 16:55:09.
The beer pours a bright clear golden straw color with a fizzy bleached white head of 1 cm foaming up. This foam fades to a sturdy surface layer soon after the pour. Several active streams of carbonation rise to the surface to feed the foam.
Aroma is some cracker malt and a bit of light honey note. Nose is very mild overall.
First sip reveals a light body with smooth texture and very mild carbonation.
Flavor is some bready malt and crackers, a bit of honey again and here I get some spicy or black tea hops that linger with a little bitterness after each swallow. Finish is sort of dry and the beer drinks very easy.
Nice easy drinking beer, pretty mild flavor and nose, but enjoyable for a Sunday night.

Poured from 12 ounce bottle into a pint glass
Look: Clear yellow with 1.5 fingers of head with average retention.
Smell: Extremely faint aroma of bread.
Taste: Clean average lager taste. Nothing more, and nothing less. Definitely goes down easily.
Feel: Light bodied with moderate carbonation.
Overall: Not bad, but also not overly impressive. Whereas I would go out of my way to buy a six-pack of Weihenstephaner hefeweissbier, I would not do the same for this one.

Got on tap at Brick and Porter in a 20 oz glass.
Appears the color of iced tea with a light manilla head.
The aroma was faint for me (chemically damaged nose) but mildly sweet malts did present themselves.
The flavors were biscuits and a slight sweetness that was reminiscent of caramel but not as sweet. Munich hops round out the taste.
The feel was ideal for the style, the 20 oz went down with no issues at all.
OA, not the best Märzen style I’ve had, but I could easily drink a couple liters of it if that was what was available.

Canned on 7/21/22; consumed on 9/20/22

Pours a clear, orange-copper body topped with a finger and a half of fluffy, off-white foam; mediocre head retention leaves a paper-thin layer of cap, a large, frothy collar, and a modest array of splotchy, webby lacing strewn along the walls of the glass.

Aromas show sweet caramel malts laden with honey-soaked toast and bits of more toffeed malt as corn flakes soften the otherwise taut edges of minerality prevalent throughout.

Taste of caramel and taut minerality feed into more passive honeyed dough as shreds of corn flakes past the mid-palate leave a stuff sweetness while simultaneously unable to shake the metallic tinge lingering through the finish.

Mouthfeel offers a medium-light body and moderate carbonation, dispersing a clean, fluffy prickle to a crisp mid-palate drying quickly with minimal grit through a swift finish.

Detailed sweetness belies a largely clean presentation, leaving a readily apparent lack of cohesion in a rough fusion of disparate elements and choppy lager threads; the lazily saccharine base instinct of the American Oktoberfest is prominent in this particular take on the style.

Competitive price point on the 12 pack, considering it was shelved next to various variations ; most of which i have tried, the best in the style imo being Von Trapp. Pours a lighter than your average marzen copper color, little head retention or head. about average. light on the lacing. taste seems to style, nothing to jump for joy about. picked up because of the better price point for a 12 pack of cans, would purchase again. pretty mediocre and perhaps even lower in quality when compared to yuengling. I'd pick another up thoiugh, as its definitely a good beer.

Canned 7/1/22; drank 9/17/22 @ the Yarchives.

See-through golden appearance.

A rough pour yielded a nice off-white head; a frothy, tree-rung lace.

Sweet corn, mild caramel & acorn notes in the nose.

Creamy medium mouthfeel.

Sweet corn & caramel up front; acorn, mild booze heat & a hint of marshmallow notes on the finish.

A lot going on here; overall, a flavorful, interesting Marzen. I'd have another!

Can. White head with a little lace. Clear dark golden color.

Biscuit, honey, toffee. A bit of sweetness. Grassy hops. Little bitterness in the finish.

Easy drinking. First sips were light in flavor, then it got better.

Had this from a can.
A: pours dark amber body with a thick white head with excellent retention and lacing.
S: sweet, caramel toffee malt with sweet vanilla notes.
T: sweet, caramel toffee notes with a dry, cereal finish.
M: medium bodied and smooth.
O: nice feel and taste; pretty filling beer.

Founders really hit it out of the park with this one. The smell, the taste, the feel, are all on point. Such a smooth and very drinkable beer. Just the right amount of sweetness too. Reminds me of a lot of the Marzen style beers that I've had at Oktoberfest and with a 17.99 price tag at the store, It's definitely worth the purchase. I would rate this a five out of five but I'm like Dave Portnoy. I don't want to give perfect scores lol.

Found this one today at the local beer store and they let me get a single to try before deciding. Poured a golden color with a small white head. The taste was "Magnifico". A really good tasting German-type of Oktoberfest beer.

I was pumped to see an Oktoberfest beer available at the grocery store as it’s only August (2022). Checked beeradvocate for scores and decided to give it a go. Got a 12 pack of the cans.

Pour was slightly lighter than what i usually see with Oktoberfest style beers. Looks/feels like a blonde ale but copper color. Taste is fantastic. Clean with a great balance of malt and light caramel.

Cheers to fall beer!

Pours a nice amber with a cream colored head.

Whole grain bread, candied malt, lemon herb hop, and sour wood in the nose.

Taste follows nose, full bodied and complex. A solid beer.

Did they alter this?? I had it last year and it was good, but this 2022 version is crazy good! In fact, it’s great! Listen, we all know a marzen/Oktoberfest lager can only be so much. What makes great lagers great is how well they do the simplicity. Are they staying true to the original style? Are we getting the traditional aromas and flavors? Does it feel the way a lager should? Is it smooth with the right carbonation? etc… etc… A great lager has you wanting to take another big sip.. It doesn’t have you bored… thinking to yourself, “should have I went with another offering?” This is arguably the best American made marzen I’ve had outside the one from the American lager masters in Cleveland! This has Founders written all over it and it’s freaking delicious! Idk, but this is different than past offerings. Beautifully festive artwork on the can and packaging.. looks like a German marzen.. smells and tastes like a German version.. drinks and feels like one. A+ From Founders Oktoberfest in 2022! Exciting even.

From the 123 oz can in a snifter. This solid fest pours a nice dark
amber with a nice head of white foam that settles to a thick ring, thin
wafting layer, and displays some nice light lacing. Nose of caramel malt,
bread crust, honey, and light floral hops. Flavors follow but surpass with a
fine presentation of bread malts, light biscuit, honey, caramel, and lightly spicy
and floral hop notes. Nice mouth feel; medium body, smooth, light subtly
effervescent carbonation, and a smooth moderately sweet finish.

Overall---excellent!

Cheers

Deep golden brew with huge yellow-white head. Is this a fest or a marzen? The taste will tell. Nose is extremely muted; eventually I detect notes of yeast & sweet malt. Carbonation is slight. The body is surprisingly full for a beer of 6% ABV. There's some complexity to the malt flavors. It is a marzen.

12oz can poured into a snifter

A- pours a golden/copper color with a one-finger foamy white head that has good retention

S- smells of toasted bread crust, caramel, forrest floor, honey and some spicy floral hops

T- toasted biscuit and caramel malty notes up front, followed by notes of bread crust and sweet honey. The finish gives some spicy German hops, along with more toasted malt. Lingers of Bread crust and caramel

M- medium body with medium carbonation leads to a foamy mouthfeel that continues into a crisp, slightly creamy finish

O- full flavored and highly drinkable, very good

2022 Update: Very mild aromas. Flavors are malty, but once again muted. I'm not sure what happened to this one. I used to think it was great, but now two years in a row I'm starting to second guess this one...


---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2021:
Appearance: Pours a deep, clear, orange color with a soft off white head. SRM of 12-13. (4.25)

Aroma: Mild aromas of toasted bread, sweet caramel, honey. A little spice. A strong alcoholic and phenolic permanent marker aroma on the finish. (3.50)

Flavor: Also mild flavors of sweet German bread glazed with baked caramel, light cinnamon, syrup & rye. Bready and caramel fullness. Mildly sweet, but also well-toasted malt with some moderately hefty spice. Adequately toasted. Mildly spiced though and not overly so. Smooth. (4.00)

Feel: Medium mouthfeel with a moderate carbonation to finish fairly clean, but mildly sweet. Finishes into a full body. (4.25)

Compared to Great Lakes Oktoberfest 9/20/20: Pours a similar color. More caramel aromas/flavor. Less red apple, cherry, and pear. Slightly more bready, honey and less tart. More authentic and less roasty. Winner: Great Lakes
10/31/20: Pours an identical color. More honey/caramel malt aroma/flavor. Less flower, fruit, and cherry spice.
10/8/21: Slightly darker. Stronger phenolic and caramel flavors. Less citrus and hops. Sweeter and more phenolic.

Compared to Lake Time Oktoberfest 11/10/21: Pours a lighter color. Milder aromas. Less floral and brown toast. More smooth and sweet caramel malt with a heavier body. Larger and sweeter.

to Odell Oktoberfest 11/18/21: Pours slightly darker, but similar. More toasted malt, crumbs, and toasted bread on the aroma. Less syrup, sweet bread, and toffee. More spice. Winner: Founders

Overall: Malty and smooth with honey and caramel. A decent amount of spice. Sweet bread, caramel, and malty flavors, but the spice is muted. Malty, but not overly roasted like you might expect from some. Still, shas that phenolic and alcoholic flavor cloying sweetness. That said, it's pretty good, but not what I remember from previous years. (Final Rating: 3.73)

To me this a odd tasting Marzen. Has a weird artificial flavor and dryness in the middle before finishing slightly sweet. If I didn't know better I would say this had a lot of crystal malt in it. Has a pleasant Noble hop flavor and bitterness is enough.

Solid stuff here, very impressed when I tossed this in the mix with some perennial favorites of the style. Beautiful dark copper pour with a great pillow of white foam and great lacing. Both aromas and flavors are well balanced malty/crackery goodness with a just slightly dry finish. A bit much on the carbonation level is my only complaint. Well done.

For a brewery that enjoys moving the needle and pushing boundaries when it comes to beer, Toppling Goliath shows tremendous restraint in making a time honored, classic and traditional fest beer.

Their Oktoberfest pours with a frothy deep gold with strikingly bright clarity. As a stark white froth builds toward the brim, the nose fills with a light and savory scent of fresh bread, nuttiness, crust and a bright and floral bouquet. Leading with malt flavors, the initial sip is juicy with bready sweet flavors accented with bread crust, cashew, croissant and biscotti.

With the malt sweetness staying ahead of the pack, the flavors are met with a light hop fruitiness that develops into a spicy and light bitterness that simply takes an edge off of the lingering malts. Lightly grassy, peppery and bright, the hops take the session into an even keel balance and a snappy finish.

Medium-light in its body, the beer trends drier than most with a brisk mineral bite and a racy sense of carbonation that gives the beer a pop on the late palate but doesn't settle with the elegance or smoothness of more classic Germanic varieties. Still, its a delicious American rendition to America's favorite fall beer style.

Pours a gorgeous copper color with a creamy oatmeal colored beer that sticks around as a cap and provides moderate lacing. Beautiful beer, IMHO.

The nose features sharp caramel notes and biscuits as soon as the top is popped, and a nice wheat bread component that works really well.

The taste is led by the caramel flavor, and there’s a nice biscuit flavor and some bread that tamps down the sweetness. The mouthfeel is medium, but a bit soft and watery, which is a bit of a miss, IMHO.

This is still a worthy fall beer that I’ll enjoy through the 4-pack, but if that mouthfeel had been a bit more dialed in, this would be a “run back to the beer store for more” Marzen.

Canned on 7/19/22 (best by 1/15/23); consumed on 9/13/22

Pours a clear, ruddy orange body capped with two fingers of fluffy, off-white foam; decent head retention yields a tinge of creamy cap, a large, frothy collar, and generous display of webby, soapy lacing strewn across the walls of the glass.

Aroma features a tinge of earthy spice into toasty honey and a brown bread undercurrent as spritzy minerality leans into soft bread dough over time.

Taste offers toasted malts and a prickly minerality, with a blunter burnt honeycomb mid-palate engaging flaky bread crusts on the back end as delicately charry bread dough finishes.

Mouthfeel brings a light body and a fluffy, moderate-high carbonation; cleanly textured into a pillowy peak through the mid-palate, a slight prickle trends dry into a refreshing finish.

A softly dispositioned Märzen, finding honeyed malt easing a light sweetness across a vaguely mineralic, largely airy foundation; a solid overall take on the style nonetheless.

Coppery-orange with a white head.
The smell is an Oktoberfest smell with some light spice.
The taste is much lighter than I'd expected but overall, a really decent Oktoberfest beer. I'd gladly drink it again if offered to me.

poured from a 16oz can into a new glarus dimpled mug. a pour straight down the center of the mug yields a three finger off-white foam head atop a light amber liquid. dark bread with a touch of caramel sweetness on the nose. taste follows with a slightly floral hop finish. hefty, full mouthfeel. lower on the carb, which i find appropriate for the style. really well done oktoberfest. drinks light than 5.2% but still has the amped up, autumn feel and flavor to it. i figured this would be decent because TG is a solid brewery, however, probably not one known for their lagers. here’s hoping there’s more where this came from as i’d take more seasonal lagers from these guys in cans.

Canned 7/19/22; drank 9/5/22 @ the Yarchives.

See-through orange appearance.

A violent pour yielded a big off-white head; a thick curtain of lace.

Fresh bread, mild oak & faint caramel notes in the nose.

Creamy, medium mouthfeel.

Caramel, oak & mild autumn leaf flavors up front; spring water notes on the finish.

Substantial, malty and easy to drink...I'd say this is well above average for American marzens. I'd have another!

From a 16 fl. oz. can with a Best By date of 1/15/23. Sampled Sept 3, 2022.

The appearance is handsome with its copper-amber heady look. Inviting.

The aroma emits caramel malts, butterscotch, and toasted dark bread crust. Malts are really what this is about.

Medium mouthfeel. Creamy.

The taste is sweet roasted caramel malts and dark bread crust with a mildly dry finale. Easy quaffing. I thought they did a nice job with it.

Pours crystal clear and copper with modest head. However the retention and lacing are solid.

Firm bready aromas mix with judicious grassy hops.

Well balanced on the palate. Malty sweetness, but not over the top. Grassy and earthy hops for bitterness but not out of whack. A little fruitiness.

Medium mouthfeel.

Glad they made it; glad to have tried it. But this one is only "decent" not "really good."

L-Pours a deep gold color..good clarity

S-A touch of spoiled eggs, a little fruity (apples)

T-Overall very thinly flavored with fruity notes of apples and pears...light toasted malts...sharp finish...

F-Thinnish and lacking body.

O-Very poor effort on this by a brewery I generally respect.

From a pint can marked PKG 07/19/2216:23:48 BEST BY 01/15/23

Poured into my pint glass this lager is a clear brassy amber shade with a cake like ecru colored head. Streams of bubbles rising.

Scent is caramel, bread dough and crisp herbal hops.

Taste is dry and spicy. There is a hint of caramel and some crackery or biscuity malt but the peppery earthy spice and herbal hop notes take center stage. Considerably more dry than sweet. Some tart apple notes appear as the beer warms.

Mouth is crisp and bracing. Surprisingly refreshing.

This is really an interesting marzen. Very dry and much less malty / sweet than most examples of the style. Refreshing and very easy to drink with a classic German style hop profile and nice clean finish. Very high drinkability. I love the subtlety and the crisp nature of this lager. Still think Ayinger and Hacker are my favorites but this is pretty high on my list .

A: The beer is crystal clear light amber in color and has a moderate amount of visible carbonation. It poured with a quarter finger high off white head that left a large patch of bubbles on the surface, a narrow collar around the edge and lots of lacing down the sides of the glass.
S: Moderate aromas of caramel and toasted malts are present in the nose.
T: The taste follows the smell and has a light to moderate amount of bitterness.
M: It feels medium-bodied and a touch dry on the palate with a moderate amount of carbonation.
O: This lager doesn't seem to be as malty compared to others in the style and is quite easy to drink.

Serving type: can

Poured from 16-ounce can into a 0.5-L glass boot, because Oktoberfest. Clear, slightly dark amber in color, with a couple of fingers of long-lasting off-white head. Malty aromas greet you as you pop open the can. A little dark bread, lots of caramel, dried fruit, and hints of tart apple on the nose and palate. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness, good carbonation from start to finish, and a crisp finish with a lingering hint of tart fruit on the palate. This is a good one, and an excellent pairing with all sorts of food. Highly recommended. Prost!

In my continuing quest to try pretty much every Oktoberfest on the market, I found this one at my local liquor store, so I was glad to try it and knock another state off my list at the same time. I'd never heard of this brewery, but this is a solid beer, so I'd try other stuff from them in the future. This one is pretty bready and malty, which is how I like my Oktoberfests, but might be a touch too sweet for some. Still, it holds up well to ones I can get from my local tap rooms.

16oz canned 7/19/22 (1 month ago) poured into a mug at fridge temp 5.2% ABV. The beer pours bright light copper in color with light khaki head. The head recedes to a thin cap and leaves a few spots of lacing. The aroma is mild with mostly caramel malt and baked bread in the background. The taste is semisweet caramel malt up front with more traditional bread and noble hop notes coming after the swallow. Moderate bitterness. The mouthfeel is medium bodied with average carbonation and a semi dry finish. Cleanly lagered. Overall, good. I'd prefer way less sweetness and no caramel malt.

Definitely a bit lighter than some of the heavier amber marzens. Packs a nice crackery wallop with a handful of zesty, earthy hops. Super refreshing and what I look for in an oktoberfest. Love the lightness, grassiness, slight bitterness and overall cracker flavor.

Very close behind Penn brewery oktoberfest as my favorite per style.

Appearance: Pours a clear, golden-hued body with an inch of so of white foam.

Smell: Sparsely grainy, bready with a subtly herbal bent.

Taste: Soft, lightly bready barley with a modest hint of honeyish sweetness. Herbal hops, a skosh spiceful and with a tiny touch of mint leaf. Lightly bitter. Lightly herbal, grainy on the finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Medium carbonation.

Overall: Tolerable.

Clear, dark golden color, nicely carbonated, decently sized white head dissipates at average rate and leaves no lacing. Nose is very muted all around. This is the same with taste, very light but also clean. Not much to complain about. Average feel. I would definitely drink this lager again.

Clear golden-yellow, no head. Smell is lightly sweet with a touch of spice. Taste is heavier on spice: black pepper, clove, touch of hops. It's very sweet but easy to drink. I like it okay, easier to drink then their awful pumpkin brew... still very middling
12 Oz bottle. Pours amber with white head. Aroma is of piney hops and caramel malt. Body is medium and crisp. Taste is similar to aroma. Long dry finish. Ok brew.

12 ounce bottle poured into a dimpled mug.

A little less than expected from Boston Beer, representative of style but average at best and falling well short of the best examples. Seemingly brewed not to offend making it another decent gateway beer from Sam but disappointing to my palate after drinking two German Festbiers earlier today.

Clear gold appearance with an average size white head. Grainy, malt focused aroma that does a good job of whetting my appetite with limited input from the hops. Taste of light toast, a tiny bit of yeast early on and more of a hop presence in the latter stages. Finishes on a spicy note. Medium bodied, decently carbonated mouthfeel.

12 ounce bottle poured into a pint glass. This Bostonian Festbier pours a bit more deep golden than typical and offers a light and brief cap of foam. Nose is grainy yet lacks much in the hops department. Touch of lemony hops with a spin.

Taste offers a malty yet subdued delivery for the style, lacking the depth of a typical malt bill. Decent feel yet not much depth as the malt is singular. Bit of spice on the finish. Just...bland.

Overall I usually like the Sam seasonals but this seems to be a work in progress. Good to see more festbiers in the States but this is undercarbonated and lacks malt depth and ends overly sweet and simple. Festbier like Pils is so simple to make yet nobody wants to make it Stateside without forcing two row into the mix. It doesn't work. Respect beer and respect beer styles.

Average out of respect. It's really not........
Poured out a little golden color with a small white head. The aroma is of some malt, some barley, and possibly something like caramel. Overall, it's a very drinkable beer
Straight 4.25s. Very nice beer. Much less caramel than their oktoberfest. Dryer and more crisp, definitely prefer this between the two but I do enjoy them both.

Brilliant brass color, finger of dense white foam, excellent retention, spotty lace
Deep, bready malt, hint of toast and caramel aroma
Tastes like it smells, a bit of spicy/herbal hops. For some reason I'm getting a weird ginger/pepper flavor that seems out of place.
Medium light bodied and appropriately carbonated
Can't get over the weird flavor

Pours a nice brass yellow from the bottle.
It's not bad at all but feels a bit restrained.
Just a bit more of everything and it would be stellar.
As far as Festbier made domestically, I'd say it's a winner.
I would get it again this year and probably next as well, it they are making it again.

L-Crystal clean light amber color

S-Light aroma...Not much malt...a little earthy hop aroma and a bit of lemons perhaps?

T-Malt more evident here...breads...grainy...herbal/earthy hoppiness...comes together subtlety but nicely.

F-Clean, light side of medium bodied.

O-This is pretty enjoyable and a nice drinking beer. I wouldn't compare it to the German versions in this style but it's a good beer in its own way.

12 ounce bottle poured in a SAPP glass.

Rich, see-through deep gold color with an amber tint. Lively big bubble carbonation. Thin white cap, modest lacing.

Mostly caramel malt aroma mixed with some fresh green grass. Eurohop touch.

Malt forward that starts sweet then there’s some dry grain. Herbal grassy hop flavor.

Light and sweet to start. Hops and dry grain finish. Pungent and sharp lager feel.

A good look turns into a good drinking lager.

Light amber, golden color, with off white foam head that diminished after 2 - 3 minutes. No lacing or foam left except for around edges of beer in pint glass. Malt forward, but not overly so,. Finish was as smooth as one could want. i liked this over SA's Octoberfest beer. Recommend and will purchase again.

Sweet, bready, hoppy with a slick finish. 5.8% provides nice body and punch to it. A nice robust lager to get loaded on during fest season while having something with additional quality flavors above an AAL.

12 oz Can
Consumed on: 19 Aug, 2022
Glass: 0.4 L Fest Mug
Serving Temp: 54.1


Look:
Golden yellow with a 4-finger (!) frothy and pillowy white head. The head slowly fades to about a half finger of bubbly foam. Lacing is good.

Smell:
Bready dough with a hint of lemon. Noticeable grassy and earthy hops.

Taste:
Lightly toasted bread and biscuity notes with touches of lemon. More malty than the aroma suggests. Notes of grass and earth are in the background. The sip dries a tad at the end. Nice.

Feel:
Crisp and clean. Body is medium-light.

Overall:
A decent and drinkable Festbier that is a nice companion to SA's Oktoberfest. This isn't my favorite Festbier but it is nicely done.

Appearance: A large, moderately coarse snow-white head with good retention. The medium golden body show a bit of haze, with clouds of fat bubbles drifting lazily to the surface. Scattered bits of foam adorn the glass wall.

Aroma: The aroma offers bread dough notes, cracker malts and pleasant noble hops.

Taste: At the opening, bready malt notes appear, soon followed by grassy and peppery hop flavors. A bit of sweetness presents later in the taste. Towards the finish, there is a mild wave of herbal bitterness, bringing the taste to a graceful close.

Mouth feel: Soft and full, very pleasant, with just a bit of soft carbonation.

Drinkability/notes: A fine example, perhaps a bit out of season for December, but, nonetheless, well done.

Presentation: Packaged in a custom twelve-ounce brown glass long neck bottle with a pry-off crown, served in a La Fin du Monde tulip.

12oz bottle

Pours about a finger of dense white head into my Boston Lager glass. Retention is very nice, with most of the head remaining after a few minutes. Initial lacing looks pretty nice as well. Body is a brilliant golden orange. Looks great so far.

Nose is a nice blend of cracker, and doughy-toasty notes, with a bit of malty sweetness. Smells great.

Flavor follows suit, although maybe even cleaner, and definitely fuller. That dough comes through wonderfully. Super clean, great flavor.

Even after a little while in the glass, the carbonation is still holding up well, medium-light. Body is pretty light but there is a small sweetness that adds a little depth. Bitterness is low, but definitely shows itself. Really a lovely, soft mouthfeel that accentuates that doughy sweetness.

Drinkability is super high, this is tasty and very well balanced.

Appearance turned out ok, the head faded and the lacing was subpar, but not bad all around.

This is what I want out of a Festbier, this has that extra doughy sweetness you need to separate the style from a more generic lager, something many Festbiers fail to do. Overall a great beer.

A deep golden color, darker than the previous Weihenstephan Festbier, but quite good looking - clear with plenty of tiny rising bubbles below a tall white thick head that has good retention, receding below a domed top.

The aroma grassy, bready, and earthy.

The taste is much better. Malty with a bit of brightening from the hops. Bread and a touch of caramel. It is, as the label says, very smooth and mild. Eminently drinkable, malty but not too sweet. It seems to me to be a bit of an in-between styles beer (i.e. between a Märzen and a Festbier rather than a true Festbier). I would guess Sam Adams was not wanting to stray too far from their very popular Oktoberfest.

The mouth feel is substantial, smooth, and creamy.

Overall, an enjoyable beer, one I could have several of in a "session", but lacking the crispness of the best festbiers I've had. Nevertheless, and we'll see how I feel after trying (for the first time) the Sam Adams Oktoberfest tomorrow, but I could see buying 6 packs of this. At this point, I'm sorry to have only 2 left. (The rating doesn't reflect very well how much I am enjoying drinking this beer.)

Pours a toasted straw color with honey highlights. Thin white head that settles quickly into a sparse cap.

Light grainy aroma. A bit of biscuit/dough.

That taste has that distinct Munich malt characteristics; a bit doughy with pepper spice. The hops sit in the background and provide a light grassy bitterness.

Light to moderate feel with tingly carbonation. Starts sweet on the palate but finishes with a dry grassy bitterness.

A good representation of a festbier. I like that it is a bit toasty.

From a 16oz can, dated 07/25/22. Served in a willi becher pub glass.

Pours a crystalline caramel-copper with two-plus fingers of rocky suds. Retention is good, leaving robust streaks of foamy lacing. Colour-wise, it's sort of midway between what I'd expect a märzen and a festbier to look like.

Nose is bready-malty and somewhat reminiscent of a caramel apple.

Taste has more of a sharp, earthy bite to it than what I'd smelled. Tasting brown bread and apple, caramel, nuts, tea and tobacco. There may be a subtle, slightly sweet, pine needley aftertaste that’s hard to account for but only mildly discordant and really more of a curiosity than anything else.

Feel is smooth and slick, somewhat full bodied relative to the style with fine, tingly carbonation. A little more carbonation would have been welcome considering it’s heft.

Overall, a credible Oktoberfestbier. A somewhat Americanized take on the style - despite the claim of being ‘brewed with all German ingredients’ - but not outrageously so. It’s probably a little too thick if it were my intention to drink all four cans in one sitting. Not that that’s ever really my intention. It just sort of seems to happen.

From the bottom of the can: "2 B CANNED ON 08/2/22 14:25"

Appearance: The body is a golden-brown color with hints of burnt orange. It has good clarity with a light opalescence. The head is medium-large and has an off-white eggshell appearance with a fluffy and creamy textured surface that borders on rocky. It has pretty good retention. Not much in the way of lacing aside from a few spots.

Aroma: The aroma is of malts that are slightly bready with a light maillard character and a touch dusty. There are also hints of herbal hop notes.

Taste: Up front there are nutty and bread crust flavors. There is a touch of acorn and some light moss towards the middle with hints of tea leaves. Somewhat bitter tea leaf towards the back of the mouth. A bit of a charred note in the aftertaste which is a little odd.

Mouthfeel: It has a medium body with a semi-dry finish and a medium hop bitterness. Carbonation feels good. It is easy to drink.

Overall: For the most part the beer is good. I has a bit of an odd aftertaste and the aroma is a bit muted, but otherwise the flavors and aromas are good. The beer is very drinkable and that is one of its strongest suits. As a whole the beer was enjoyable and I could drink it again. I would recommend it, especially if you are building a mix-a-six or if you are at a festival where you can try different beers.

Poured from a can into a “can-shaped “ glass. Can date 7/26/22.

L- Slightly hazy amber color.

S- Sweet roasted bready smell.

T- Caramel sweetness followed by yeasty
dark bread flavor.

F- Medium carbonation with a decent
mouthfeel.

O- A solid Marzen!

Always happy to see the end of summer and the beginning of fall and with it Oktoberfest lagers.

From 16 ounce can with illegible canned on date.

Pours into my pint glass a clear copper with two fingers of fluffy khaki colored foam. Head drops quickly to a ring leaving no lace.

Scent is warm bread and spicy/herbal hops. A hint of apple.

Taste is on the dry side. Spicy and herbal hops. Tart apple. Bread and bread dough. Caramel. Possibly a suggestion of toffee.

Mouth is medium with a dry finish.

Decent solid Marzen. Finish is not as clean and crisp as my favorite German examples of the style. Though dryer and spicier this lager's tart apple, caramel notes and bready malt balance the spice.

Reliable brewery, reliably beer. Don't be put off by the Marzen categorization. I've bought this at least 4 or 5 years on the trot now and it's really more truly a middle ground between pure marzen (in the chewy, malty vein) and festbier (in the hoppier, spicier style). That said, it's a very reliable take and a good option at a good price point for a nice session.

There's some herbal bitterness to accompany a firm malt body, which is somewhat pronounced but well balanced. The nose is all Bavarian malt and hops, smells so wonderful. Taste is even keeled, nothing pulling one way or the other. Have to compliment the exceptional fining and conditioning - sharp clarity, fluffy head receding to a sort of pool of copper, looks wonderful.

Nice take and one I enjoy at least a 4 pack of each year.

16 oz can. Pours orange with tall, long-lasting, fluffy white head. Aroma is of herbal hops and caramel malt. Body is medium and smooth. Grassy hops and caramel malt nicely balanced on the palate. Finish is long, almost dry. Nice brew.

16 oz canned on 8/20/21.

Light amber with the slightest of hazes. Frothy white head that leaves patchy lacing on the glass. Grainy caramel malt aroma with a trace of toffee or chocolate. No hops of note. Sweet malt flavor that finishes slightly dry. Medium bodied, clean, easy to quaff.

L - poured amber with quick dissolving head. No lacing.
S - biscuity malt and light toffee.
T - follows the nose.
F - medium mouthfeel. Fairly smooth with semi-dry finish.
O - Disappointed by the look of the bear but overall it was good.
Crisp and clear, almost like an ideally malted lager. Wish they released it earlier, this would *definitely* be a very refreshing summer brew. Lightly hopped, a little spicy as well.

Hazy cost orange with a tab short lived head and a faint bread and caramel smell with a hint of grass or flowers

The taste is light toast with a little caramel, malt and a hint of graham cracker on top of a subdued hop pepper

Overall this is an above average Oktoberfest märzen. Not great, but not too bad; a 4 pack is just the right amount.

Poured from a can, dated 8/24/21, about a month ago.

Looks great, clear orange amber with a thought white foam that persists all the way down the glass.
Smell and taste are of toasted bread and honey graham cracker, caramel malts and mild herbal hops.
Feels a bit on the sweet side, malt-forward with a fine carbonation and mild bitterness.

Overall very tasty, glad I picked it up in a mix-your-own pack at the local bottle shop! Definitely an American take with bigger malty heft than most German festbiers, but a solid and very enjoyable beer.

Sampling a 16 oz can poured into my .5L dimple mug. Picked up the cans recently at the local beer shop. Canned on date is 8/25/2021. Pretty fresh!
Pouring a slightly chilled can, the beer pours a rich chestnut to copper color. Very clear and some lazy streams of carbonation rising to the surface. The fizzy beige head foams up about 2 cm and fades to nothing very quickly after the pour.
the aroma is mild on this one. I get some toasted grain and bready malt notes with a little caramel sweetness. not much hop character to be found on the nose.
First sip reveals a light to medium body with smooth texture and fine and very tingly carbonation. The beer drinks very easy.
Flavor is some caramel up front followed by a bit of bready malt and some light toasted notes. The toasted grain flavor lingers after each sip.
I dont get any ABV hints and the hops dont show through much of the malt profile on this beer.
I enjoy this one and find it to be quite the enjoyable brew to start off the BA Oktoberfest with this year.

A: Med amber, brand new penny. Bright clarity. Moderately sized,dissolved quickly.

S: biscuity with faint floral hops.

M: High carbonation, takes from taste

T: Oat toast, fairly grainy… woodiness with slight grassiness.

Ok, nothing I’ll be looking for in the future.

Pours a rich, caramel-amber color with a couple fingers of dense, yellowed head that leaves messy lacing.

Full, bready aroma with light hints of caramel sweetness and a slight toasty quality.

Unusual taste of caramel sweetness with a distinct herbal character up front and a fairly dry back end. Just a hint of that toast shows in the finish.

Medium bodied with tight carbonation.

The sweetness mixed with the herb in this one is a bit of a head trip, but the beer does have nice dryness in the finish.
Decent "light" beer, but not what I'm looking for in an Oktoberfest marzen or fest bier style. Too light to enjoy on its own, but fine with a pub meal.

Clear light copper col;or with a substantial ivory head that stays around and produces some very nice lacing.
The aroma is toasted fresh bread with hints of floral hops.
The taste is malt forward, lightly toasted bread, slightly sweet, balanced by some nice floral hops and some tannic notes and trace of vanilla from the oak. The finish is somewhat dry with some toasty and tannic notes lingering.
The body is light/medium, carbonation is moderate making a very drinkable brew.
Altogether this is a very nice take on the oktoberfest style and makes you look forward to several more.

poured from a 12oz bottle into a tall new glarus pilsner glass. pours a light amber with almost three fingers of flimsy, soapy light tan foam. lager yeast, a bit of malty caramel and earthy oak and hops. taste follows with a drier finish. it’s not overly oaky but it definitely compliments the beer, which seems a little light for a marzen. it’s not bad and quite drinkable. i like the oak aspect but the beer itself needs a little beefed up.

6 x 12oz bottle from Roth's West Salem market, Salem OR.
$11.99
Pours a beautiful crystal-clear copper body, with a lovely beige head. Great lace.
Aroma is mostly honey and light toffee malts. delicious.
Taste is the toasty caramel malts but some well-placed floral hops to break up the sweet. Getting a little woodiness in the end..hopefuly from the oak.
Mouth feel is near perfect..light yet still full of interest. Very good.
A really beautiful lighter marzen..almost festbier.

1.5 x 12 oz bottle
Glassware: 0.5 L Festmug


Look:
Clear very golden copper (more gold than copper). Head was initially 2 fingers of creamy off-white foam which then dissipated slowly to about 1/4 inch of the same.

Smell:
Light and almost crackery malts that is more in line with a helles (or pilsner) than a Marzen. There is a touch or 2 of grassy hops hiding in the background. No oak is detectable.

Taste:
Same as the nose. There is also some breadiness and a very very slight fruity note along with a metallic one.

Feel:
Smooth but wet and also watery. Body is light-medium (at best)

Overall:

I was curious about this one but I am let down by it. I was expecting a Märzen, but this is much more akin to a Festbier. I was surprised by the lack of detectable oak. The bottle was from last year (2021), so perhaps that is a factor. On the plus side it is quite drinkable. As a Festbier, this would actually be quite good and I would rate it higher - my ratings reflect this beer as an amber Märzen.

For reference, some of my favorite amber Märzens to date are Ayinger, Hacker-Pschorr, and Paulaner.

12oz bottle purchased off the shelf as a six-pack for $10.75 plus tax. Bottled on 07/15/22, so this is almost two months old.

Look: Pours a nice light copper color with perfect clarity. There was one-finger of off-white head that gradually reduced to a thin rim around the glass.

Smell: Nice aromas that you would expect from a Marzen - toasty, bready notes with spice and floral, earthy hops. It smells very clean and crisp. Overall, the beer smells malt forward and it also smells balanced.

Taste: Really delicious. Up front, it's bready and malty as suggested by the nose. The beer is light to medium bodied with gentle carbonation. I think the finish of this beer is the most distinctive part due to the oak lagering. The very subtle tannins and spice character of the oak barrel, along with the hops, really help to temper the maltiness of this beer so that it is a balanced and drinkable product. The finish is slightly chewy with lingering notes of bread crust, caramel, toasted oak, cocoa, and spice. I think that the oak barrels and the hop character help to make this beer finish relatively dry too. Very drinkable and enjoyable, I wouldn't mind knocking back a few of these in a row.

Feel: I would say that this has a slightly lighter body than most other Marzens that I have had recently. While I think that other Marzens tend to be closer to medium bodied, this one is light to medium bodied with gentle carbonation. At 5.2% ABV, I think that is a fitting body and mouthfeel for this beer.

Overall: This is probably one of the tastier American-made Marzens that I have had in a while. It's easy to drink and presents a nice combination of malty, hoppy, and drinkability.

From the website:
BREWED FOR CELEBRATION
A seasonal Firestone Walker classic, matured in oak barrels to deliver smooth, rich and biscuity flavors.

HOPS
Tradition, Spalter Select

FERMENTATION
Stainless Steel, Finished in French Oak Barrels

MALTS
Weyermann Pils, Vienna, Munich, Cara Hell, Cara Red

Oaktoberfest is our oak-inspired homage to the great German tradition of Oktoberfest. We go the extra mile of maturing this beer in French oak barrels to create an amazingly smooth mouthfeel. The result is a classic German Fest Bier with a hint of West Coast hoppiness. Grab your stein, don your lederhosen and enjoy!

Bottle. White head. Little lace. Autumn gold color. Clear.

Malty, honey, toasted crackers, biscuit. A bit of sweetness. Grassy and zesty hops. Not really picking up much oak.

Solid flavor and done to style. Very enjoyable.

The pour is straw colored with a moderate amount of carbonation. On the taste I'm getting a well pronounced lemon note, some white pepper, along with some white bread. I'm picking up on the oak as the beer warms up a bit, this was an interesting version of a marzen & would pair well with mild/medium strength cigar. Cheers! B-
More hops and less sweet than 99% of märzens, which is a huge plus in my book. Not sure where the oak enters, but I'm even less sure if I care. This is great

12oz bottled 07/22/22 (1 month ago) poured into a mug at fridge temp 5.2% ABV per label. The beer pours bright golden amber with off white head. The head recedes to a thin ring and uneven cap. Sparce spots of lacing. The aroma is mild with rich malt and a hint of oak. The taste is semisweet caramel malt with a quick hitting, mild oak and earthy hop combo that knock the sweetness right down. Mild to moderate bitterness. The mouthfeel is thin bodied with average carbonation and a mostly dry finish. Cleanly lagered. Overall, good. This is a clean, straightforward American oktoberfest. Not too sweet and quite drinkable.

Don’t really detect the oak so much. Very smooth. Not as sweet as most Märzen’s. Super drinkable though,nice color. Overall very pleasant and not overly sweet, or over hopped like many West coast takes on European beers.
It’s Good!

Clear golden ale with a big head that slimmed but persisted as a foamy cap... Oaky and slightly sweet, medium-bodied, with ample chewy grains and mild hops... Thought it was really enjoyable, perhaps a bit off for a purist, but very smooth and woody with a honeyed edge... Got two for trying, may pick up more... Certainly worth a try if you like the Octoberfest beers and their like...

A thin, off-white head floats above the almost clear, dark golden amber beer. Minimal to no lace forms on a Pretentious Glass Company dimpled mug.

The aroma is sweet with light graininess. There is a faint suggestion of oak against light toast with honey.

This is more bitter than I had expected, however, the bitterness is far from strong. Sweetness follows. In general, the flavor is less interesting than I had expected. In particular, there are no wood flavors. The finish is mild and long.

The body is medium to full with a hard, smooth texture. Slight metallic notes accentuate light astringency. Alcohol is as expected, barely noticeable. Carbonation in light and fizzy.

While this is a decent beer, I found nothing shines. Octoberfests do tend to be less flashy than other styles. However, I had expected the oak would be more pronounced and add some excitement.

Look: Clear amber-orange with a lively off-white head that builds quickly and eventually settles to a lid, leaving good lacing behind
Aroma: Warm brown bread, melanoidin, oak notes, some earthy hops, and toffee
Taste: Toffee, melanoidin, and earthiness kick it off and quickly followed by waves of bready malt that pile up and join into the mix. Oak is present throughout and closes with the duo of bread and earthy hops
Mouthfeel: Full, very clean throughout, medium-high carbonation, and smooth, clean and soft but crisp on the finish
Overall: This is a delightful beer. This is my second time with this beer and didn’t see it last year but I feel like this is better than what I had two years ago and I liked that one too - apparently this year’s one is now actually oak-aged so that is probably why. The oak adds a nice layer to the Okto base and I’m a huge fan of using oak in/on/with beer so not too surprised I liked that aspect as well. Overall, a tasty Marzen that hits the spot on this cool evening
This one is a little more delicate than I expected, restrained. Balanced but I get a bit more hop than malt which for me throws this one a bit off from expectations.

Clear golden amber body with a white head. Aromas of oak with toasty malts, flowers, and bread dough. Taste is much the same, toast and oak naturally pair, dough, caramel malt, german yeast, and flowers round out well. Moderately crisp, decent carb, malty and oaky through out the whole sip. Nice twist with the oak
Bavarian-style marzen with an oakey twist. Deep gold pour, biscuit nose and grain flavor. Malty at first and throughout. This brew captures Bavarian simplicity and grace.

Poured from a bottle into a pint glass. Pours deep orange yellow with a small white head. Smells of caramelized grain with slight fruit notes. Tastes of sweet caramelized grain with a tad bit of fruit. Beer is light bodied and easy drinking, good carbonation. Overall, a very good beer.

12 oz bottle, dated 7/20/21. Parish Pint Glass.

Has a beautiful light amber glow, skewing strawberry-blonde, with a creamy buttered head of 1 finger. Leaves lace as it recedes. Marvelous!

Aroma brings me back to the days of reviewing my first beers on here. Same time of year, too. Wet mash, toasted grain, some hop sharpness rounding it all out...some deeper descriptors I wouldn't have picked up on back then would be apricot, caramel, crisp apple, and flower bed.

Man it's been awhile since I've had a good Marzen. This one was a great re-entry. Lots and lots of toasty, crisp munich and caramunich malts open this up, creating a bed for herbal hops and dry grass. Lemon peel and slight citrusy brine wrap up the finish.

Carbonated feel with slight parch and moderate to strong resins. Alcohol is detectable at only 5.2% but it's permissible as appropriate warmth since certain areas of the world would be experiencing colder temperatures already at the end of September.

Overall, a very delightful take on the Marzen and one I'd be glad to have again. I wish we got Firestone Walker here in South Dakota, but I suppose like all other breweries their stuff would sit and rot as very few people buy beer here.

I would buy it again should I be within FW distro around Sept-Oct.

$1.66 @ Binny's in Peoria, IL

Poured from a bottle. Golden in color with a white head and a little lacing. Smells of malt, bread, caramel and honey. Flavor follows the smell and all comes together nicely. Flavor is very good, exactly what you want in an Octoberfest beer.

Poured into a tulip pint. This looks really nice.

L: 4. Light marzen coloration. Polished copper. Ample carbonation with a lingering head.
S: 3.75. Give it a few minutes and it really opens up at you. Malty. Spicy. There's a honey like sweetness to it but that dissipates as it breathes.
T: 4.25. My favorite of the season so far. It has a nice spicy bite to it.
F: 4. I think the oak aging worked wonders. Nice and smooth. Light and mellow mouthfeel.
O: 4. A solid 4. It doesn't fill you up like other Marzens might. Very good oktoberfest lager.

Brassy gold tone, ample foam and spotty lacing. Aroma is malt forward and grainy.

Taste is malty and easygoing, light crackery grains and a hint of apple. The oak is very understated, but it’s there. Lighter feel but still fairly substantial. Good carb level, smoothly textured. Overall pretty solid, lighter and less sweet than most American Märzens.

500mL can purchased off the shelf as part of a 4-pack for $11.99.

Look: Pours a crystal clear golden color with a fluffy white head. Looks like a "textbook" beer.

Smell: Subtle fruity/estery/floral aromas balanced with grassy hop character. There is a crackery, doughy malt presence too. Notes of a pale, floral honey as well.

Taste: This is very crushable. It has a very pleasant flavor and a nice body. You would expect a beer that is this pale to be relatively light in body. However, this beer is probably closer to medium bodied because it has a rich maltiness akin to a Helles lager. It has a lovely toasted grain flavor. On the finish, which is mildly to moderately bitter, I get notes of white grape must. The beer is super crisp and clean. It's hard to believe that this beer is 6.0% ABV. It would be very easy to drink a lot of this beer.

Feel: The mouthfeel is really nice - it's perfectly carbonated and it is close to medium bodied. The beer is crisp, clean, and very refreshing.

Overall: This is my first time consuming a beer in the Festbier style. It's fitting that my first one is from Paulaner, who popularized the Festbier style. This is very different from Oktoberfest Marzen, which I am much more familiar with. I enjoyed this one and look forward to trying other Festbier examples from other breweries!

Very solid representative of the style. Looks exactly as it should, with its big fluffy head and clear golden color. Smells pleasantly of noble hops. Flavors are very well balanced between doughy malt, hops that are assertive but not aggressive, all supported by the yeast. Mouthfeel is a shade heavier than I expected, satisfying without overwhelming. Overall, a highly drinkable beer that doesn't get boring.

This is a very nice beer. What can I say that haven’t been said about it yet? Smooth, yes we know, hoppy, sure, well, balanced, hell yeah!
There is something about its taste that you could drink again and again and again - guess that is why they made this the Oktoberfest Bier. Some lagers might have strange hops, excessive yeasty overtone or are too heavy on malts and therefore are too sweet - and these make a beer less easy to drink. But when it comes to the Oktoberfest, it is all about drinking beers by the gallon so it had better be a good one and an easy drinker! Well, THIS is that one! Now all what is missing is a plane ticket to Munich, the timing would be right though… A legendary, amazingly drinkable beer.

Golden straw colour, slightly on the darker side with a three finger white head. Smell is big, rich, bready malt, fresh cut grass, a nice peppery note, with some alcohol presence. The taste begins with that nice doughy, bready malt, then gives way to quite noticeable ethanol, and finishes with gentle but interesting grassy and subtly spicy hops and more liquid bread. The carbonation is quite gentle for a lager, which makes it smoother and easier to drink, but the alcohol is noticeable in the smell and taste, which is a slight complaint for me. Overall a tasty, drinkable Festbier, with nice flavours and a smooth medium body. My only minor gripe is the ethanol note is not hidden as well as it is in some other beers that have just as high or higher ABV, but that's forgivable and it's not that bad anyway. Solid beer, recommended.

Appearance: Brilliant, clear gold. Frothy thick head with excellent retention

Aroma: Floral and grainy

Flavor: Spicy hops. Sweet start to finish. Low bitterness. Short semi-dry finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium to full bodied, soft and creamy. Medium carbonation.

Overall: Has lower bitterness than most German Festbiers. Also comes in a little lighter. Plenty of malty flavor and floral hops aroma. Moderate level of carbonation. Very soft and creamy on the tongue. Very conducive to drinking in large quantities.

Fresh liter can poured into a half liter glass mug. Pour is a clear light golden in color with a rich cap of white foam. Hazes up a bit after the pour then clears again. Good retention and soapy lacing.

Nose of light spice and lemon hop notes muddled with some bready malts. Taste follows and with a long simple but pleasant bready malt finish. Touch of citric sweetness permeates, touch oily on the finish. Second half poured into the liter 'stein' as intended. Feel is a bit thinner than expected but still a good festbier. Overall a bit of false sweetness and lighter bodied than some you might find at Therese's meadow. I preferred the Lowenbrau, cheers. Yet then, with some warming, it does seem to fire on all cylinders......

Poured into seidel. Fine Munich gold body, white sudzy head.

Nose is cracker malt delight.

Taste follows. Bready but light, grassy hops snuck within.

Feel is exactly what you want with a fat cheesy pretzel bite.

Classic Festbier. You see this pint in the wild get it and drink.
The taste is all malt with just a touch of spice (maybe hops???) while the *aftertaste* is sweet baked bread along with a bowl of mixed nuts, very malty - I said M.A.L.T.Y.

Big ass liter can was poured into its respective stein. That looked really cool. This definitely tastes good and is typical for the style. I wouldn't say it stood out though other than maybe a "spiciness" as it warmed. Overall fun beer.

500 ml Can
Consumed on: 14 July, 2022; 30 Aug, 2022
Glass: 0.5 L Fest Mug
Serving Temp: 45.5 F


Look:
Bright golden yellow with a 2-finger frothy and foamy white head. The head lasts ands lasts. And lasts. As is slowly dissipates it leaves excellent lacing on the sides of my fest mug.

Smell:
Bready and biscuity malts. Touch of sweet but slightly zesty lemon. Mild floral and grassy hops.

Taste:
Things start off with some tingly and zesty hops, then lemon and lemon rind shows up followed by sweet bready malts with a touch of honey. The hops provide a mild bitterness throughout the sip which dries out as it end.

Feel:
Soft and clean. A tad chewy. Body is light-medium.

Overall:
A very easy-drinking and quaffable Oktoberfest beer that is actually (and, to me, surprisingly) refreshing. I can certainly see this beer being consumed in great quantities at festivals. I am having this in the evening after a bit of a hot day (in the 90s) with some humidity and the beer is drinking very well. I haven't had many Festbiers to date, but this seems a pretty solid representation of the style. And, if I recall, it was one of the first Festbiers that I ever came across.

I have seen some comparison of this beer to an amped us Helles. I disagree. To me this beer is more like a slightly amped up Dortmunder Export.

Purchased a gift set on sale after Oktoberfest. Import from Germany. Liter-sized can poured into the big mug included in the set.

Appearance: Bright, straw yellow, with a huge, foamy, and tenacious head.

Smell: Banana bread, Wheaties, malted milk. Mild-mannered and sweet.

Taste: True to style, as expected. Malt is the main focus here. Initial sharp bite, but then sweet. Dinner rolls, unsalted peanuts, creamed corn, Twinkies. No bitterness, just a warm, almost buttery finish and a delicious aftertaste, again with those buttery notes.

Mouthfeel: Thin body, but pleasantly sticky and remaining on the tongue.

Overall: Great, mellow beer, just what you want from an Oktoberfest brew. Goes well with anything and is easily, happily consumed in large quantities.

Poured from 11.2 oz bottle to a .5L stein. Color is clear gold. A white head falls quickly to a light cap. A lot of carbonation bubbles rising up through the body. Smell is malty, bready, a bit of honey. Taste starts with a balance between bready, doughy malt and herbal hops. Middle leans a bit more toward hops with a nice bitter kick that transitions to a finish with more bready, almost yeasty, flavors. Feel is medium-light body, good carbonation that cleans up your palate. Overall, this is a great beer that goes down easy during Oktoberfest "season". Pairs well with all the classic Oktoberfest foods too. Really enjoyed.
Can pour- clear yellow/gold straw color with thick white head leaving significant frosty lacing. Nose is sweet malt with grassy floral notes Taste follows with a crisp almost dry finish.

.5 liter can poured into a dimpled mug.

Clear light gold color. Three fingers fine white head.
Bread, pepper, grassy, light floral scents.
Honey, light citrus, rye, light mineral flavor notes.
Smooth, strong carbonation, dry finish.
Delighted to see this in cans. Very enjoyable.

Appearance: Pours a clear, light golden color with a moderate white head. SRM of 7. (3.75)

Aroma: Moderate aromas of pale malts, bread malts, only hints of toast. Smooth and somewhat bready. (3.50)

Flavor: Strong flavors of upfront of toasted pale malts and honey. An earthy and floral flavor of Munich malts. A pale bready malt finish. (4.25)

Feel: Medium-bodied and low to moderate carbonation. Leaves a sweet feel on the palate. (3.75)

Compared to Paulaner Oktoberfest Marzen 10/28/21: Pours a lighter color. Milder aromas. More bready, pale malts. Less toasty and woodsy Christmas tree pine.

Overall: A fantastic and authentic festbier. This one nails the toasted pale malts, honey and earthy Munich malt flavors. Allows the flavors to shine through since this one is in a can. Sometimes these are bottled and often light-struck and skunked. However, this is excellent. (Final Rating: 3.99)

This is Paulaner's second Oktoberfest offering - see Oktoberfest Marzen for the other one. This one is a bit less malty I think, which was a surprise when I saw that it was 6% ABV. I like my Oktoberfest beers to be very biscuity and malty, so this one was a little light for me in the flavor department. Not bad, just not as much oomph as I prefer.

500ml can into a pint glass. Canned 3/22/21, best by 3/22/22.

Looks decent in the glass. Crystal clear pale golden yellow body. The initial big white head shrinks to a ring and faint covering. A little lacing.

Strong aroma. Malty, grainy, even a little caramel.

On tasting, malty, bready, a little dry. The caramel lingers around. Somehow crisp but not clean.

Mouth medium, finish malty and drying.

Overall, not bad, just a little odd when compared to other recent festbiers. Perhaps 7 months in the can is the issue here.

Bought the gift pack with a Maas glass and 1l can of Oktoberfest bier. Note to Paulaner, please sell this in the can at retail, I hate wasting three bottles for a Maas. This is rich, malty and sweet taking you on a nice journey. The hops have bright floral notes that balance the sweet malt without the bitterness desired by hopheads. Really drinkable at 6% and really nice for the style. Get some and make the darn cans available already.

Appearance - clear golden body with white head

Smell - slight toffee, spicy hops, toasted grains

Taste - toasted grains, white bread, slight toffee/honey, biscuit

Mouthfeel - medium plus bodied, medium carbonation, slight sweetness upfront, malty, toasted feel in the back, easy to drink, crisp and refreshing


Overall - really good representation of the Weisn style of octoberfest. Definitely worth a try.

Price Point - $7.99 4 pack 16.9 oz cans

500ml can poured into a dimpled mug.
Canned 3/22/21

Pouring crystal clear and rich gold, @6 SRM, it is topped with near two fingers of white persistent foam that leaves lacing. This is a lively pour with masses of tiny, rising bubbles replenishing a head that lessens but never disappears. The moderate strength nose is also persistent featuring sweet bready malt along with spicy Noble hop aromas.

Delivering big but clean and balanced flavor front to back, it is semi-sweet with mild bitterness. Tasting bready with sweeter grains, spicy and light floral flavors. Mouthfeel is medium weight, soft and mildly creamy with lightly crisp edges coming from medium carbonation. Well rounded, easy drinking and very enjoyable. Great Festbier.

Pours a clear yellow with soft, soapy head.

Smell is bready and a bit grainy with notes of citrus, crackers, rye bread and a floral hint.

Taste is bready and a bit grainy, clean and crisp with a solid bitterness. Notes of citrus, rye, toast and some spiciness.

Mouthfeel is medium, smooth and well carbonated.

Overall, a very well made, tasty lager.

Poured from an enormous can at fridge temp into a giant Paulaner mug. Pours a nice golden transparent yellow. Good amount of white head that goes away within a minute.

Nose: Oranges, wheat, grass, crisp corn,

Taste: Super smooth. Sweet upfront, but a definite hoppy bitterness on the back end. Orange peel, grass, bread, a touch of spice, and a floral note. Very enjoyable.

Mouthfeel and overall: Light and crisp. Very refreshing. Overall, a very nice drinkable beer. As far as Oktoberfest beers go, this would land somewhere in the middle for me.

Gold in color with a hazy complexion and some moderate sized sediment suspended within the body. There’s a quarter inch of dishwater white on top. Moderate soapy lacing. The aroma is of citrus. I’m tasting sharply bitter orange. The mouth is smooth and there’s a pronounced hop burn that lingers after you swallow.

I made an account JUST to comment on this DISGUSTING brew. This is the most horrendous flavored beer I have EVER tasted! Who on EARTH thought this was a good idea???Each gulp I had to fight gagging, and wound up pouring the entire 6 pack (or eleven bucks) down the drain. DISCONTINUE THIS BLEND. IT IS VAPID! YUCK! Voodoo can be a bit bitter to begin with, but mixing with orange like that was a poor tastebud choice. You aren't BLUE MOON. IT IS HORRID!

Very surprised at the extreme citrus flavors, but it's an IPA with Natural Flavors.
Nice white head that lasts, no grit (grit doesn't bother me, this didn't have any) for a smooth feel. And 9.5% ABV.
I'll have another, please.

Hazy straw color with a creamy white head that clings to the glass, this beer smells like an orange creamsicle. Literally.

It also tastes like an orange creamsicle, with no hint of alcohol, quite the feat in a 9.5% ABV beer. The mouthfeel is medium and on the softer side.

I wouldn’t want two pints of this (that would become cloying, IMHO), but one stovepipe of the beer works just fine.

Poured into a tall clear pint glass. Hazy yellow with more than a finger's worth of fluffy white head, good retention and lacing.

Tropical and citrus notes come to mind firstly. Notes of orange sherbet, Hawaiian Punch, orange, mango, pineapple, papaya, multi-grains, corn, and resin.

Tastes pretty much like what the aroma suggests. Body is medium light to medium.

its crazy how bad voodoo imperial is, i mean relatively speaking for what these guys are capable of, so i didnt expect a whole lot from this one, given it plays in a similar space. i was lucky enough to have to on draft rather than from the huge can where the bottom half is almost always assuredly rough unless you just blast it down, so that might be a factor here, but this is actually impressively good, even if i kind of hate to admit it because ive held a grudge against voodoo imperial for some time now, one of the worst beers in that single serve strong ipa space, despite tearing it up some how in terms of sales, who drinks more than one or two of those ever?! anyway, this is a different breed, thankfully. its almost nuts how strong it is, because it drinks light. its got some light unfiltered sort of chill haze to it, not big and starchy and thick, nor is it amber, like a lot of these are, not over malty for balance, smart call, seems like maybe some white wheat with the pale barley, real simple, big enough in stature but dry and light in flavor, even uplifting, it accentuates rather than balances out the hops in the taste too, cool. the hop profile rules, and tastes about as good as it smells, juicy is an understatement, with ripe mango and cantaloupe to it, but shockingly not sugary, love how clean the ferment is, not metallic, fusel, or even all that warm to me. playful hints of coconut, papaya, and sweet orange, really fruity, almost seems like it has to be fruit, but lots of new school hops in here, southern hemisphere maybe, and seemingly a lot of strains, no expense spared? good for these guys, especially because this is still affordable. no bitterness, but i dont miss it this time around, and i think this has great flavor, freshness, and dangerous drinkability, summer but good for any time, a good morning beer, mimosa vibes here too, just really fruity and good. high carbonation makes it quite light to drink. i dont know why i expected to dislike this, i used to love everything these guys made, its only recently my impression has turned, largely thanks to the imperial voodoo, this is totally redeeming. really tasty and well made, a standout in an increasingly crowded style space and format. call a spade a spade, this rules.

It looks like a killer hazy ipa, but smells and tastes like an alcoholic V8 splash. If that sounds good at all you will probably like this one. Also the 9.5 abv makes this a good bargain beer. It almost feels wrong calling it a beer though.

19.2 ounce can into tulip glass, canned on 6/1/22, best before 12/4/22. Pours moderately hazy golden yellow color with a 2 finger dense and rocky off white head. Great spotty soapy lacing and streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Amazing juiced aromas up front of candied orange slices/juice, vanilla, lemon, passion fruit, pineapple, mango, melon, white grape, apricot. The taste follows much of the same suit with mandarin orange slices, vanilla, lemon, peach, pineapple, passion fruit, papaya, mango, melon, grape, coconut, berries, citrus peel/rind, pepper, pine, wheat, white bread dough, herbal, floral, grass, yeast earthiness. Light-moderate pine, citrus rind, herbal, spicy bitterness on the finish. Medium carbonation and medium-full body; balanced creamy/bready malts and sticky/resinous hops in the mouthfeel. Long drying resin finish, with a bit of spicy alcohol that gets a bit boozy after the finish, warming 9.5% is well showcased. A pretty wide variety of hops with Mosaic, Chinook, Pahto, Galaxy, Strata, Lotus, and Sabro. I have never had Pahto or Lotus. The creamsicle nose is pretty wild; everything comes together so well in the nose, as I was almost certain fruit was harmed in the making of this beer. The taste has more dank/earthiness on the hops, with the alcohol being a bit harsh, but certainly not too out of the ordinary for the gravity. It was very smooth for the ABV. I'd totally get more of these stovepipes or a 6 pack.
Looks fine, on the dark size for haze. Aroma is overripe citrus. More overripe fruit in the taste, with the high alcohol also pervasive. Medicinal and difficult to drink.

straight boozy orange juice with a dash of grapefruit juice; very little hop bitterness to it, and the high abv is totally hidden, but there is a slightly medicinal tinge to it which may slow you down a little.
makes for an interesting entry point for those who typically dislike IPAs and want the benefits of a high abv brew.
as an IPA lover, I kinda hate it, and feel like it sets the style back a tad, imagining a future which sees more "IPAs" like this saturating the market. on the other hand, this is nothing short of a great party beer, making for a cheap ticket to buzz town.

not really the hill I'll choose to die on, but would be pretty sad to see the popularity of this brew take the shelves by storm.

This ain’t your hipster’s IPA! It tastes great without the slightest hint of pine cone hoppyness. It’s has a great grapefruit citrus flavor. The take is more astringent and light. This is the IPA that you want to get drunk with. There’s a depth and a full bodied flavor; not over powering the other. It goes down easy and you need to watch out for that! Classy from New Belgian!
Quite possibly the worst "juicy" IPA or rather any IPA I've ever had. Tastes like children's orange-flavored aspirin. I'll reluctantly finish the 6'er and never go back.

Purchased a 6'er and have tried this twice. Both times I could not finish it. It tastes like pulp free pineapple/orange juice with a 9.5% ABV. The second time i tried it I did a side by side with another imperial pale ale - 90 Minute by Dogfish Head. There are no comparisons that can be made between them. I paid the same price for the 6'er of Juice Force as I did the 4 pack of 90 Minute, but will say the quality and value of 90 Minute far exceeds that of the Juice Force.
This was hard to drink. Had to pour out remaining 1/5th if it. Tastes like it was made in an artificial flavoring lab. For the price ( $4) there are better options.

The Voodoo Ranger Juice Force is not just a silly beer, with an eye popping ABV and a name that is reminiscent of a poor drum and bass MC freestyling their way down a tricky couplet. No, it's a way of life.

That way of life is regret of missed birthdays, fearful of calls from the bank manager and lack of recollection of lifes wonder moments. Yes, it certainly packs a punch, akin to Mike Tyson, and with similar disregard to concepts such as consent, gut health and clarity of value judgements. As Britney Spears once sang, It came in like a wrecking ball. A shame said wrecking ball, also resulted in colleteral damage to my marriage. I can only see the kids every other weekend, but I am a Voodoo Ranger of the Juice Force 7 days a week, and for that, I am grateful to New Belgium Brewing Company. A highly satisfactory beverage and would reccomend to friend and foe.
This is such a great tasting beer, it really surprised me. Smooth and refreshing, fruit flavor and fragrance is what hits you first and it is gooood. I could drink it everyday.

Smells good and then it goes downhill. Fast. Like a bobsled.

Looks - Clear orange/yellow body / bubbly.

Smell/Taste: Cinnamon, ginger and spice that hits the back of the throat with a burn.

It’s odd and not in a good way. It is literally spicy beer. Maybe a good taster but not a pint.

Not impressed.

I poured a 12 oz. can into a pint glass. nice amber orange color, a one-inch head that receded quickly, typical of the style. The nose is nice, pumpkin, caramel, and vanilla waft above the fainter smell of cinnamon and allspice. This taste is initially as expected... some evidence of pumpkin mash, vanilla and caramel, cinnamon allspice, cloves, ginger.. but then the taste grows hotter. It is peppery, and seems perhaps heavy on the ginger, and after several sips, you realize it's time to call the fire department, and start looking for water. I'm not sure why they have gone so spicy on the taste, but for me it is truly unwelcome. As for the mouthfeel, I am never comfortable when a campfire has been lit in the middle of my tongue. Overall, if you have a taste and passion for hot spicy dishes, this may be right up your alley. For me... it's not happening here. This was my first and last New Belgium Voodoo Ranger Atomic Pumpkin.

Notes as Written 09/17/2022
clear orange/yellow body, bubbly half finger head which dissipates fast, bubbley, takes coaxing to stir up aroma which is very subtle ginger, very strong cinnamon/ginger flavor which immediately hits the back of the throat with a burn, tastes good and is literally spicy, spicy beer not really my thing, but I can see the draw, smooth mouthfeel that develops a hard kick

"Enjoy by 8/6/23"; drank 9/13/22 @ the Yarchives.

See-through orange appearance.

A rough pour yielded a nice, noisy eggshell head; decent lace.

Pumpkin & chili pepper spice notes in the nose.

Medium thin mouthfeel.

Mild pumpkin & hot chili pepper bite flavors; as the drink progresses, the heat builds & you can't really taste much.

Not sure why chili beers exist, but this isn't an argument for them.

Pours a clear pumpkin orange with a tinge of amber and mild effervescence. Scent has clear notes of pumpkin and cinnamon (almost smells like cinnamon Life cereal) , but the spicy notes are pretty muted. Taste is pretty smooth pumpkin and cinnamon before a transition to a strong spicy burn. Feel is on the lighter side with most of the aftertaste consumed with the spicy (presumably haberno) flavor. The individual parts are fairly hit or miss but dang, do I enjoy the overall combination and the interesting twist on the pumpkin variety.

Voodoo Ranger Atomic Pumpkin from New Belgium. 12 oz can from Shangy’s, Emmaus, PA, from 18/09/21. $ 2.11 (including tax) ($ 0.176/oz). Stored at room temperature in store and at 40 degrees after purchase. Reviewed 14/03/22. Note that I use DD/MM/YY protocol.
Can stamped on bottom “16 JAN 2022”. Served at 40 degrees in a hand washed and dried Jester King snifter. Final temperature 42.4 degrees.
Appearance – 3.5
First pour – Pale Gold (SRM 4), clear.
Body – Deep Gold (SRM 6), opaque. When rear-lite, translucent, and chill haze apparent.
Head – Average (Maximum 3.2 cm, aggressive center pour), white, creamy with average retention, diminishing to a 0.8 to one cm undulating crown and rocky cap.
Lacing – Good. Wide band of impending torn curtains, with many medium bubbles.
Aroma – 3 – Vegetal with no hint of pumpkin, no hops, no malt, no yeast, no cinnamon.
Flavor – 3 – A bit sweet with instant pepper mouth burn, no flavors of malt, yeast, hops, nor pumpkin. Any cinnamon present is lost in the assortment of chilis. No ethanol (6.4% ABV, as marked on container) taste or aroma; however, there is no gastric warming. No dimethylsulfide or diacetyl.
Palate – 3 – Medium, watery, soft carbonation.
Final impression and summation: 3. Looks good but aroma and taste-wise, it’s just another chili beer.

9/16/21.,..pours bright clear orange, no foam. Faint vanilla pumpkin smell. Faint. Thick pumpkin taste, background nutmeg/cinnamon. Spicy. Kicky. The chilis start to kick in and really drive some heat.

12 ounce can poured into a tulip.

L: Amber and clear, one inch white creamy head, leaves a little lace and fades to a perpetual ring in a couple of minutes
S: Big malty bread at the pour, this fades leaving a mostly spicy aroma, cinnamon, coriander, yeast, after warming a pastry bread aroma comes out
T: Malt and spice forward, coriander, clove, hot pepper, bread, wheat, hot peppery bite to finish, not getting any pumpkin
F: Medium body is smooth and creamy, finish is dry and rather clean for a spicy beer, has some warmth
O: Not bad, too much pepper for my taste, more like a chili beer than a pumpkin/seasonal spice beer

Single can from Kroger Mix & Match shelf
Pumpkin taste is actually tones down. Good notes of cinnamon and a spicy hot kick in the finish.
An interesting beer but probably nothing I would buy again.

A- clear burnt orange with a half finger head that dissipates quickly.

S- cinnamon, clove and anise with dominate of malt

F- clove and anise. i dont get much pumpkin spice per se

M- spicy and almost like a hot spicy.

O- not bad but the clove is too dominate for me.

I'm not going to bother writing up a full breakdown of this beer as there isn't much to say besides why? It's pretty much a run of the mill pumpkin without much complexity. But yet your throat burns like you are dealing with a cold. I have to wonder if NB decided to toss in the peppers to distract you from the fact on how mediocre this is. I just don't get it as the chili's add absolutely nothing to the flavor profile. I mean if you want to make this "something" make it hot enough to make you sweat. That way you can give it to your buddy's in a glass without warning.

Anyhow I love NB's lineup, in fact they make some of my favorite beers (Trippel). But this is just depressing.

Appearance: Pours a clear, medium golden to orange color that is madly bubbling and a strong and creamy white head. SRM of 7. (3.75)
