Aroma: Moderate aromas of fall spices upfront including cinnamon and cloves. Then it follows with some sweet apple pie and pumpkin pie crust malty aromas. (3.75)

Flavor: Moderate flavors upfront of fall spices including cinnamon and cloves. The malts are apple pie and pumpkin pie crust. Then in the middle the spicy pepper comes through. It doesn't stop. The spicy pepper carries through the end leaving a spicy bite through the finish. (3.75)

Feel: Medium-bodied. Strong carbonation. The spiciness comes through the middle and wipes through the end scorching any flavors in the beer and leaving them with a spicy pepper note. (3.50)

Overall: Not a huge drinker of pumpkin/flavored beers and cautiously headed toward this one given the words "atomic", "spicy", and "pumpkin". I can say the beer drinks quite well. The spices and malt flavors are well done with nice fall flavors of apple and pumpkin pie. The spiciness is definitely interesting and not subtle by any means. Cleans through the end and rips the palate. I can say it's better than many flavored/pumpkin beers I've had but sort of like a jalapeno, I don't think I would/could have more than one. (Final Rating: 3.78)

Drinking this at The Parting Glass Pub in downtown Andrews NC.
Poured from a tap into a pint glass.
Looks orangish with a nice foamy head that dropped quickly to a very thin ring.
Smells lightly cinnamon, bready, spicy, pumpkin.
Taste follows the nose, WOW! Pepper, pepper, pepper on the back of palate.
That being said, there's a lot going on here, very complex. Pepper is all over the place some sips pepper, some sips more cinnamon. However the pepper builds on your palate and if you don't like pepper? You won't like this beer.
There is a bit of vanilla as well.
Mouth feel, falls short here, this is a beer that would've benefitted from a stronger malt base.
Overall this is a Pumpkin beer unlike any I've ever had, unusual, complex, spicy. A little more malt would've made this the greatest pumpkin beer ever.
Cheers!

On tap in a standard pint glass.

Orange copper color with a thin white cap that morphs to heavy lacing.

Cinnamon, nutmeg, crisp pumpkin Autumn aroma.

Liquid pumpkin pie flavor. Lots of cinnamon loaded malt.

Light and sweet and spicy. Then the lasting peppered finish, spicy hot.

As pumpkin beers go, it’s a cut above the norm for me. I enjoyed its easy drinking at 6.4% abv with the habenero kick.

This one smells like cinnamon first and then pumpkin and beer. The spicy cinnamon is strong.

So much cinnamon flavor with a little pumpkin all in a really malty beer.

The body is thin and the carbonation is moderate. The finish is mind blowing. Cinnamon and heat from chilies. It's so good.

Wow this is unique to me. It has some pumpkin but it's more of a spicy cinnamon beer. Overall I give it a 4.7 out of 6.

I was really excited about this one, I love NB and always seek out a few pumpkin spice beers every year when the seasons are changing. Also- I’ve been brewing spicy beers lately and really love them.

This is one of the worst beers I’ve had in a long time. The feel is thin and unsatisfying, and combined with an overwhelming sweetness it feels like drinking a soda. Pumpkin spice flavor completely overwhelms, so the flavor becomes completely one-dimensional and really leaves almost nothing recognizably beer-y in terms of flavor. As for the spicy notes, they’re almost non-existent except as an annoying tingle in the back of your throat. I actually forgot it was spiced until I read the can again. Color is fine, nice amber but the head is so weak as a result of thin sugary consistency.

Overall, I’ll never buy this or probably any other pumpkin spice beer ever again. I could only stomach one of the 6 and gave the rest to a homeless man.

From the can, it pours a clear orange amber color with a nice off-white head that lasts and leaves lacing. In the nose, fall spices and peppers predominate. The mouth gets some pumpkin spice goodness, along with the bite of the chilies. Interesting interpretation.

Look: amber with orange tint, near white head that dissipates quickly.

Smell: fall smell with pumpkin spices, peppers interestingly intertwine with the spices giving off a spicy scent. Overall a fall hot tamale is the best way to describe it.

Taste: starts off like a regular spiced pumpkin beer a la Schlafly Pumpkin Ale lite, then turns up the heat with the peppers that singes for a few moments until creamy pumpkin pie filling cuts through the peppers for a smooth finish.

Feel: medium body that is fairly smooth. The peppers do offer a throat hit akin to smoking a cigar or more accurately a juul. The pepper throat hit does build up if you drink quickly so keep that in mind when consuming. Has a pepper/squash backbone so if vegetables in your beer weird you out this probably isn’t for you.

Overall: unique and delicious. Moderately spicy, good for the average person. People who eat peppers daily or avoid spicy food like the plague shouldn’t expect to see this drink in the same light. Definitely going to be a staple in my fridge every fall from here on out the spicy fall combination is something I never knew I needed in my life. Best served ~10 degrees below room temp imo.

Nice big head, direct pour into pilsner urquell .5l mug. Clean, clean, and clean. Almost too clean. Pretty good but i just don't appreciate the high price for the small shipping size. Haven't had a beer outisde of the celebrator that was "WORLD CLASS" from this brewery. And to add something to a reviewer below, if this beer aint got good head retention or lacing, the glass aint clean or the tap line is dirty. OR another of the various ways individuals can alter the product.

A dark, but bright and somewhat translucent amber brew, drawn from a tap and delivered in a clear pint glass has arrived. The head is white, spotty and minimal. The malt dominate aroma is complex and not overly sweet. Is it vaguely nutty? Well, there seems to be a nut-like quality here to taste, likely a combination of the hops and malts. This drinks richly and incredibly smoothly malty, but not close to being overly sweet. The lack of a head and subsequent lack of lacing doesn’t indicate anything, as this is just about perfectly carbonated. The finish is wet, but clean. This will be one of the best Marzens you'll ever have.

Nice amber color with light head. Smelled of a toasted yeast bread. Feels light and smooth with good malt flavor typical of a German Marzen. This a very good Oktoberfest and stays true to the German style.

Notes from 8/29/2022.
Poured from a 11oz bottle into a pint glass.
The body is amber with 2 fingers of tan head. Retention is good leaving a fluffy cap.
The intensity of aroma is low. There are notes of malt and yeast. This has one of the lowest aroma levels I've experienced.
The intensity of taste is somewhat above medium. Very malty. Wow. A lot of delicious complex malt flavor. Although subtle, the flavor has a long transition from being malt forward and then a light hop bitterness that comes in and continues to develop. I like the slight alcohol flavor at the end. World class.
The feel is almost thick. It's fairly creamy with light carbonation that prickles the tongue. Astringency is medium and balances the malt forward flavor.
Overall, the appearance, flavor and feel more than make up for the very low aroma. As far as Oktoberfest beers go, this is hands down the best I've had.

500 ml bottle poured into a Czech brewery pilsner glass, at fridge temp. Great foamy head that lingers just a bit.
Bought the say it went on sale, it’s very fresh!
So good, so balanced and rounded - sweet yet bitter, great flavors - this is just a beautiful European Fest beer.

16.9oz can purchased off the shelf as a single for $3.49. Lot code L2039. Not sure what that means but this must be fresh as it must have been bottled recently and then imported to the US.

Look: Beautiful orange/copper color, crystal clear. Small tan colored head that slowly reduced to a very thin layer. Tiny bubbles rising up the glass.

Smell: Malt forward with notes of toffee, caramel, and bread crust. Throw in some spice, floral aromas, along with earthy and soil-like notes on the finish. Interesting mix of aromas. After drinking several ounces, I make a comparison of the aromas to cream soda. Subtle note of baked apples with cinnamon.

Taste: This is really delicious. It's super drinkable and really well-balanced. Some of those lager funk notes come out on the palate, and they are welcome. Up front, this is definitely malty but it's restrained; it's malty without being sweet, which I appreciate. The carbonation is slightly spritzy, and the finish is smooth and pleasant - relatively dry considering how malt-forward the beer is and with a very gentle bitterness. The lingering perception of the beer is earthiness and a bit of spice (allspice?).

Feel: Slightly chewy mouthfeel, medium plus body. Carbonation is just right. It's not heavy or cloyingly sweet, just very balanced and drinkable.

Overall: My first Ayinger beer review. This has got to be one of the better Marzens out there. Considering that this is a mass-produced, widely distributed beer it is super impressive. They must have got their brewing process down to a science. If you could take a sourdough or Bavarian hard pretzel and make a beer inspired by those flavors, that's kind of what I imagine this beer to be.

A really beautiful octoberfest beer. Dark and rich in color and the nose will transport you straight to Germany. The flavor is a rich, dark marzen with a flavor punch all the through to a delicious long lasting finish. A must have for fans of this style.

Copper color, minimal head that faces quickly. Some lacing left. Tastes heartily malty. Nice pretzel like after taste. Not very bitter but there are some metallic notes here. Basically what I expected.

0.5 L bottle
Bottle Code
Glassware: 0.5 L Willibecher
Temp at Pour: mid 40s F


Look:
Dark and burnished copper that is hazy and somewhat opaque. I can see my fingers on the other side of the glass (and not very clearly) but that's about it. Makes me think of a Kellerbier. Initial 3-finger head dissipates to a thin covering with good lacing.

Smell:
Malts, malts, malts. Freshly baked whole wheat bread. Biscuits. And also bread dough. There are also notes of a darker honey such as basswood honey or wildflower honey. Yum.

Taste:
Follows the nose but with some toasted caramel notes added in. There is a malty earthiness present as well. Everything is balanced very well. The finish is a long slowly fading toasted grain note along with a slowly increasing dryness.

Feel:
Super smooth with little carbonation. Body is medium, with a nod towards the full side.

Overall:
An outstanding Marzen-style Oktoberfest. It has all of the qualities of a Marzen with the drinkability of a Festbier. This is my favorite Marzen and favorite Oktoberfest beer by far. Too bad it's only available once a year near me.

Gem-clear amber (SRM 9-10) with an orange tint. One inch of almond cream lasts a few minutes, leaving patchy lace. Tiny, lazy bubbles of carbonation are magnified in the dimples of a Spaten mug.

The malt is sweet with no roasted or toasted notes. Light honey adds character to the scent of wheat bread dough. The aroma is mild, yet has distinct notes, similar to macadamia and almonds.

The balance is excellent, with sweetness up front and bitterness at the end. Unlike the aroma, toasted malt is strong. Wheat bread and light honey come out late. The finish is long and mild, carrying the toasted malt, and none of the other flavors, as it lingers.

The texture is velvety smooth, with a medium body. Residual sugar builds on the lips, while light alcohol and soft, tingling carbonation enliven the tongue.

This is a pleasant and easy-going Autumnal beer. I enjoyed it on a cool, sunny afternoon in the early Autumn. My only wish is that I had a salted, toasted pretzel with mustard to go with it.

Look: Really deep amber, large foamy head that persists, looks like an ideal beer! Kinda like pee from someone really dehydrated!
Smell: Very yeasty (like i could get a yeast infection from just being around it!), hints of spices? like cinnamon and clove, kinda like pumpkin pie?? a little bit like persimmon...
Taste: Pretty bitter upfront, but mellows out into some burnt caramel notes, a bit bready, has some fruity notes like apple cider. also some fig jam flavors and some molasses
Feel: Kinda leaves your mouth a little dry, very little carbonation, like tiny bubbles that make it almost creamy in my mouth
Overall: This is a really good beer! When I take a sip of this, I feel like im in the middle of a fall festival, surrounded by big breasted ladies serving beer to Men with beer guts in a giant hall and I'm hittin on one of the hot BABES but shes like nah bro i ain't gay and im like its ok dude im not gay either i just think women are great and shes like huh? how does that even make sense are you ok? and then im like no... and start crying and she feels bad so she ends up sleeping with me anyways. AND THATS HOW YOU PICK UP GIRLS :)

I figured the new year would be a good time to try the Ayinger Oktober Fest-Märzen. It pours a copper/amber with a white head and a malty nose. The flavor is typical of a märzen, full of grain sweetness, usually found in a tent. The mouthfeel is just a little off, but it could be a little old.

Sunday, November 28, 2021 9:08 PM
500 mL/1 Pint 0.9-ounce bottle poured to wine glass
Sight: Brownish, dark amber color, small foam, appears clear
Smell: aroma of malted grains
Taste: very good, low bitterness, some sweetness
Mouth feel: low carbonation, sticky, good follow through, dry finish, slightly bitter aftertaste
Overall: very good beer, ok to repeat, not to look for BA RB

L: dark color light carb, nice frothy head that dissipates
S: nice subtle buttery smell
T: good taste, again buttery
F: amazingly smooth
Great beer, very nice light smooth feeling märzen!
This has to be one of the best oktoberfest beers out there. Very traditional, but also with a lot of depth of flavor. It has that beautiful orange color and malty aroma. Perfect for fall.

Slightly hazy copper orange color with1/2 inch of slightly off white head. The nose is malty and earthy with whole wheat toast and honey. The taste is fresh baked biscuits, pepper, cheerios, and closes with a hoppy floral note. It is clean and dry with pleasant carbonation. I could drink this anytime. Seems like I need a ham and swiss on rye with this. Very good beer!
Quality European marzen, great brown flavor for the fall season. Flavor has depth but not overdone and this one is smooth. If in to Marzens, put this on your pick-up list.

Notes from 8/30/2022.
Poured from a bottle into a Pint glass.
The beer is clear copper with less than a finger of off-white head. Retention is average.
The intensity of aroma is low. There is a crackery malt smell, an earthy smell and a slight yeast aroma.
The intensity of taste is medium-high. The flavor follows the aroma with more bitterness and dryness than the aroma suggests. The long bitter hop note is moderate, spicy and creates a layer of flavor over the crackery malt, earthy flavor and slight yeast.
The feel is slightly above medium in thickness. Carbonation and astringency are low. It's quite dry. The carbonation prickles the tongue.
Overall, it's an outstanding beer. The quality of taste is noticeably better than the Marzen beer brewed in the US that I've had.

1.5 x 333 ml bottle
Bottle Date 06 2022
Glassware: 0.5 L Festmug


Look:
Nice deep but clear copper. Initial 2-finger cream-colored foamy head dissipates very slowly leaving quite good lacing

Smell:
Quite malty without being sweet. Lighty toasted grains and bread. A lot of bread, mostly brown variety. There are notes of grass and fresh cut hay drifting around in the background

Taste:
Very much similar to the nose but with the grass and hay notes more prominent. This really does taste like liquid bread. There is some earthiness as well. Things finish dry and toasty with a slight spiciness.

Feel:
Smooth and a tad crisp Body is on the lighter side of medium.

Overall:
A very nice Märzen-style Oktoberfest. This is one of the standard-bearers of the style and rightfully so. Things do change slightly year-to-year for this brew (not by much though). Some years I prefer this brew, other years I prefer Hacker-Pschorr's. The 2 are very similar and are owned, if not brewed, by the same company. Between the 2, Paulaner always seemed to tend to being more 'grassy' or even spicy.

If memory serves, this was the first German Okto that I ever had and it helped make the amber Märzen Oktos one of my favorite styles.

Everything about this beer is outstanding. Beautiful color, smell of malt and caramel with hints of fresh hay. The taste has everything you’re looking for in an Oktoberfest beer- balanced bread, malt, and hops with a dry, clean finish. This is probably in my top 3 beers overall and I would advise everyone to give it a try if you haven’t.

Bottled beer purchased from Costco

Appearance: clear copper with small off-white head
Aroma: malty, fresh alfalfa hay
Taste: toffee with a little sweetness, balanced bitter notes, followed by crisp finish
Mouthfeel: medium body, smooth
Overall: classic Marzen and puts me in a strong Oktoberfest mood!

Purchased from Total Wine South Beach in may. Pours amber brown with one finger of head. Smells heavily of sweet malt and molasses. Flavor is sweet with a very subdued bitterness profile. A bit of floral complexity on the palate but not a strong sense of hops here. A tasty and good drinker on level with a lot of other beers in this space.

12oz bottle on a dark day

Looks great - orange and lace and all that crap, smells like malt and stank, okay ig. Smooth and easy af to drink, very sweet honey caramel malt, has a bit of heft while remaining very clean, drink it cold, ideal campfire beer maybe. A big mug of this is a top-tier-bier

A frothy one inch of off-white head falls to hold at about one half inch. Spotty lace is left on a Pretentious Glass Company dimpled mug. The Marzen is dark amber, similar to corten steel and is almost clear. Tiny bubbles of carbonation lazily form in random patterns.

Sweet malt has an earthiness of orchard fruit in the background. There is also a light peppery hop aroma, however, it really is all about the malt. Fresh wheat bread comes on strong and grows with warmth.

While well balanced, it tilts slightly toward bitterness. The wheat bread is almost as strong in the flavor as it was in the aroma. Cashews and walnuts come in waves. The finish is simple, mild, and lingering.

A medium body of scratchy woolen texture. Carbonation is modest and fizzy, while the alcohol is as expected. There are slight notes of metallic qualities.

This is just a good drinking beer for after work or watching football.

Poured from an 11.2 ounce bottle into a standard pint glass.

A: Has a wonderful kind of amber to it, nice amber hue. Has some nice lacing on the glass with plenty of carbonation.

S: Smells very bready. Hint of spice on the nose. Malty, bready sweet spice.

T: Spice to it. Some hoppyness in the background. Kind of boozy, tangy, dry. Little bit of bitter, mute overall taste. I’m really not a huge fan of the taste.

M: Really thick, full, almost syrupy.

Overall, not impressed.

Tonight is a new to me beer

Paulaner – Oktoberfest Marzen

5.8% ABV

The beer is listed as a “Oktoberfest Marzen” on the bottle, and “Lager – Marzen” on BA.

The beer was removed from a 45ish degree temp fridge after having been refrigerated for approximately 2 weeks. Beer poured into a HB stein.

First Impression: Looks the part. Pretty. Clear. 4.5

Appearance: This is what I would call a golden amber color. Somewhere between gold and amber. 4.35

Smell: Bier, first and foremost, as I always say. Followed by a small amount of rye spice, bread, malt, There seems to be an almost underlying lemon zest note, almost dancing on the hairs in your nostrils, if you know what I mean. 4.0

Taste: Not as flavorful as some others. A bit more one-note. A bit of bread, a bit of malt. None of the rye or lemon mentioned above. I’m struggling to identify much, as it tastes a bit watered down. 3.75

Mouthfeel: A tad thin. I almost think of most oktoberfests as being almost syrupy in their consistency, but not that thick. That may be odd. I’m struggling to describe exactly what I mean. There’s something about them that is a bit thicker on the mouth than I think they appear. 4.0

Overall: I enjoyed this. I’d have more if I had them, but at the same time I don’t think I’ll specifically seek out more of these compared to others. Very middle of the road for me. 4.00

BA Review Score: 3.921

I’m not normally the guy who writes the Oktoberfest copy for this page, but I think we can both agree this is about the best we have had. We have were served on draft at the Burren in Cambridge, Ma, and also from a bottle and even a can. Every time and out of every vessel it’s great. So smooth, with a strong malty backbone. At the same time it is light and supremely disposable. Thanks for the lovely suds, Paul.

11.2oz bottles, 16.9oz bottles, years of kegs into various vessels.
L: Pours med dark clear honey w/a thin light khaki head which goes to a skin and edge foam, low yet fine carbo, light skeletal lacing.
S: Bready, lightly toasted caramelized malts, a hint of cocoa, lightly earthy, fruity hops.
T: Clean malts, caramel, lightly earthy hops, toasted grains, a suggestion of black tea, has a gentle toasty linger.
F: Bright and extremely clean med-light bodied mouthfeel w/a fast lightly drying finish.
O: A very clean & dry famed beer from Paulaner. Well refined, consistent, EZ drinking and very smooth. One of the best beers in the style you could ever have. If I were in Germany I'd probly rate it much higher.

**
09/23/22
Bottle to snifter.

Look: mostly clear and bright yellow.
Medium white head, sturdy head, excellent retention. Sudsy legs on sides.

Aroma: fresh barley. Grains, light citrus, melon.

Taste: whole wheat or rye cracker, malty upfront. Hoppy, Light citrus and veggie in the back.

Feel: light to medium body. Refreshing. Clean with some subtle complexity.

Another nice beer from Maine.
**

Picked up a bottle from the brewery dated 23AUG22. Another incredibly smooth and drinkable IPA from this amazing brewery. They were one of the first doing it this way and will always remain one of the best.

Pours a nice clear golden color with a nice head and lacing
Aroma has floral and hop hints
The taste follows the nose with a floral and hop flavor
A medium bodied well carbonated beer
A good IPA

On draught at Clinton Hall beer garden, NYC.
L: Lightly hazy, yellow gold with a thin head that reduces quickly to a ring.
S: Pineapple, grapefruit and grape juice.
T: Green and vinous with a noticeable edge of pineapple. Getting some rose water as well. Interesting and unusual.
F: Light body, moderate carbonation, some oily mouthfeel and a bitter finish.
O: A complex but understated, grassy, floral and bone dry AIPA.

Pour yields two fingers of basic white foam with good brightness and average retention, nice thick lacing streaks. Pale, mildly hazy yello liquid, random lazy bubbles an easily be seen. The nose is compact, if not lean, cracker, saline, peppercorns, white grapefruit, hint of pine, edges on metallic, the fruit scents are subtle pineapple, nectarine, peach, overall the elements nicely woven together. Medium-bodied, the dryness and fluffy carbonation increase palate presence and grip. The profile very similar to the nose with even greater emphasis on a mineral, quinine nature. Speaking for myself, finding it underfruited and I am not one for bombastic IPA's. The substantial maltiness keeps the bitterness in check. Deserves kudos for cleanliness, however, I do wish there was just a bot more intensity in the flavor profile. (Bottled 7/19/22)

From a bottle dated 10May22, so not the freshest by mid-August. Looked more like a Pilsner in the glass until a little more sediment arrived with the second pour. Nice citrus notes without the malt tones from West Coast IPAs. Very refreshing on a hot day.

Pours a cloudy, but not completely opaque golden color. Thick frothy white head forms on the beer, lingers for quite a while, and never dissipates completely. Lovely appearance on this one. Aroma has notes of tropical fruits - mango, pineapple, and citrus - along with some light pine, and floral notes. There is a noticeable cracker malt backbone.

Taste has notes of cracker malts providing a strong backbone to the flavor profile. On that are notes of tropical fruits, mango, pineapple, citrus, with an aromatic floral character as well. The hops bring a woody pine character to the flavor with a noticeable and semi-pronounced bitterness. Feel is light, crisp, bright and fragrant. Dry finish.

Overall this is a very nice IPA from Maine Beer Co.. I am always pleased with their beers and this is no exception.

6 oz mini-snifter draft pour at Lures Bar & Grille. Pours a clear light yellow with a small off-white head. Aroma and flavor feature clean malt, citrus and floral hops with a hint of tropical fruit. Very clean and polished overall, juicy but with a dry finish. Definitely leaves me wanting more.
Pours a pale gold, a slight haze. Nose is light, citrus. Taste is the same, solid pithy grapefruit. Nota bad, just not worth the drive/cost, I'll stick to lunch.

16.9oz bottle purchased from the fridge for $7.49. Bottled on 6/28/22, so this is exactly five weeks old.

Look: Pours a nice light golden color with a very faint haze. There was a thick, off-white head with compact to medium bubbles that slowly reduced to a very thin layer. Nice lacing.

Smell: The aromas are intoxicating. Lots of tropical fruits including passion fruit, mango, papaya, orange, and guava. There is an interesting vanilla sweetness on the back end that I tend to get with Maine Beer Company beers. I also get this slightly acidic/juicy citrus note along with an even more subtle green bell pepper note. Allusions of dank pine resin and bitterness on the back end also.

Taste: This is sooooo drinkable! It is super juicy and flavorful, mirroring the flavors on the nose with tons of citrus and orange peel. The malt base is super light with a very subtle crackeryness and some very subtle caramel malt notes; this beer is a showcase for hops. The finish is moderately bitter with lots of grapefruit pith, and lingers long with intense mouth-drying ability.

Feel: Low side of medium body with appropriate carbonation.

Overall: Solid. A very tasty, West Coast Style IPA from Maine. Cool that this beer uses Talus hops. I think that I have only had one other beer that uses Talus hops and that was River Horse Sunset Citrus, which I really enjoyed.

From the website:
Flavor profile: Aromas of mango, pineapple, grapefruit, and pine. Floral notes of rose and chamomile.
Hops: Citra, Mosaic, Columbus, Talus
Malt: American 2-Row, Maine Malt House Pilsner, Blue Ox Wheat, Blue Ox Light Munich

Two plus fingers of airy crisp light khaki colored froth... Excellent retention... color is an exceedingly pale gold with a slight chill haze... Aroma is subtle but quite pleasant... Floral notes lead on the nose... Flavor profile is equally subtle but the malt base is displayed a bit more... Medium bodied... Slightly chewy and lush... Finish has a slightly bitter finish... Enjoyable and slightly unique beer but nothing is overly memorable... Solid execution but a bit understated...

I think I need to pay attention to the different hops that are used in IPAs. There is definitely something in this beer that I do not like. I’m a big fan of Maine‘s Lunch beer but this just has very bitter metallic notes to it. I have it on tap so It can’t get any better. Very disappointing

From bottle (presume it looks like a Maine Beer, but went with my average):

Smell and taste both have a citrus pith lean. The nose leans a little more on the zest where the taste brings in more pith. There’s a candied zest nature in the nose and opening of the taste, but bitterness in the latter is firm and welcome, mostly pith with a hint of grass - both types. Tangerine, peach, orange and a little grapefruit. A great mix of the fruit notes backed by classic hop bitterness.

From the label: "009 29JUN22 09:15:55"

Appearance: The body is hazy but there are no particulates or visible suspended solids. It has a light gold color that has a bit of a lemon appearance. It has a short fluffy white head with a creamy texture. It has good head retention and it has wisps of lacing on the glass.

Aroma: Immediately the nose is struck by lemon zest with a strong garlic aroma. There is a hint of lime and some pine. The aroma is strong and poignant.

Taste: Up front there is peach and lemon with a touch of lime. A freshly crushed grain flavor is also present. Towards the middle of the palate the same flavors are accentuated even more. It has hints of mint and lime zest towards the back of the palate with touches of cilantro. The beer tastes very fresh. The aftertaste is slightly floral which is interesting because there were no floral notes while drinking the beer and there were no floral aromatics. It has a bit of a floral retronasal character after drinking each sip which is very reminiscent of being in a flower section of a garden store. At times it became slightly grassy on the finish. After a while a bit of white pepper flavor also emerged.

Mouthfeel: It is light bodied trending towards medium, with good carbonation. It has a medium pithy bitterness from the hops. It feels bright on the palate.

Overall: The beer is an excellent example of the style. It brings bright aromas and flavors with excellent precision. The beer would pair very well with any dish that might need a little bit of acidity or citrus. This would be great with snapper, salmon, or even lamb. I would definitely buy it again and I highly recommend it.
Overall an average pumpkin Ale. The spices are a little overpowering and need to be toned down. Smells like a pumpkin pie but a little too sweet for a beer.

12oz'er

All nutmeg with a little cinnamon. Just overpowering spice all around... Mild hops and honey malt combine with the spice to make a pumpkin pie type flavor, but it's an 11/10 on the spice and it just ends up overpowering everything else. I can tell this will be hiding in the back of the fridge for months

Poured cold from 12-ounce bottle into a straight-sided 0.3-l mug. I was hoping that this would be a worthy replacement for Pumpkin Batch, but it was not to be. The watery mouth feel leads me to believe that this is more of an apple pie-spiced effervescent cider than a pumpkin ale. Sweet, heavy on cinnamon and clove, and a lingering finish of sour apple. I was rather disappointed in this offering from what I consider to be a usually reliable brewery. Give us another Pumpkin Batch, please.
Tastes like artificial pumpkin combined with a fall spice candle. Overly sweet and rich in the worst way possible, fills you after one sip. Might have to pour this one.

Not really a beer; there supposedly is an ale base to this, but I can't taste it.

Look: Amber, clear, white head that disappears quickly
Smell: Chemical nutmeg
Tase: Soda-pop sweet with chemical nutmeg.

Boston Beer Co. has in recent years made the lion's share of its profits from non beers: alcoholic seltzers, alcoholic teas, alcoholic apple juice. This is an alcoholic soda-pop. There's no beer here: no malt backbone, no hops, nothing. Just a strong chemical flavor that is cloyingly nutmeg-ish. I don't even taste the supposed connection with pumpkins.

This was included in a variety pack of their other beers; BBC needs to just develop a line of alcoholic soft drinks (nice contradiction there) and include this with those. In fact there was such a thing: this "beer," I gather, was originally developed by Traveler Beer co., which specialized in "shandies" (one shudders to imagine how these other "beers" tasted). This outfit was owned by BBC. It went under, but this concoction for some reason was saved and revived by BBC. btw and fwiw: a really nice shandy, or Radler, is Von Trapp's grapefruit "trail beer." This will give you an idea of how it should be done.

Imperial Pint
Look: Slightly opaque dark tan color, pouring a off white head 1 finger in height which dissipated into a thick ring with sheeting
Smell: Light pumpkin freshness entwined with cinnamon and nutmeg. Hint of fresh crisp apples with a light malt note
Taste: Neutral acidity/bitterness. Fresh Pumpkin at the front with light cinnamon and nutmeg undertones. Hint of cloves as well. Finish leaves behind light baking spices and a graham cracker malt note
Feel: med-light body with gentle carbonation and a crisp finish
Overall: Its alright, but overall low complexity. Wish there was more baking spices and a stronger malt presence

Looks a hazy dark golden color. Nice white head that diminished to thin film that faded to just around the edge of a pint glass. Aroma was strong of pumpkin spice, nutmeg, and cinnamon. Taste is a sugary mess that makes pastry stouts taste like a wedge of lemon. No thanks.

Slightly hazy amber, thin off white head, great retention and lacing, though
Cinnamon and ginger jump out of the glass, toasted marshmallow and other pie spices round it out
Actually has a bit of a pumpkin flavor! Pie spice, a bit of biscuit as well
Medium bodied and low carbonation, a little sticky
I don't really like pumpkin ales, but you could do worse

Overall I honestly thought this was relatively good but the flavor was....idk. it wasn't bad but im leaning more towards like the pumpkin from a can and not a fresh one. This is a one and done for me but not too bad

With a light amber color, this has a lot of great warm spices like cinnamon and nutmeg along with subtle warm citrus that goes perfectly with the warm spices, warm toffee and biscuit and a hint of lemon! It’s wonderfully balanced with a slight sweetness and good carbonation, while the aroma and aftertaste matches warm-spiced speculaas cookies like a champ! There’s no pumpkin flavors, but it must have been eaten up by the yeasts in the brewing process. This is a very delicious spiced beer overall! I highly recommend this, along with Ballast Point Brewing’s Pumpkin Down and the Pumpkin Ale from Lakefront Brewery. If you need a stout-filled twist to your pumpkin beer, go for the Dark o’ the Moon from Elysian Brewing!

A pretty mediocre Pumpkin Ale!!! Poured from a12 oz bottle into a pint glass. Small fast fading white head with no lacing topped a nice clear orange color. Aroma and taste feature pumpkin spices.....sort of the beer potpourri that I don't care for. I like rich pumpkin ale with real pumpkin and malt flavor. Mouthfeel is a bit on the light style.. Far from a drain pour, but not something I would seek out again!!!

12oz bottle

Pours a sturdy finger of dense white head into my Boston Lager glass. Retention is wonderful, hardly losing any head after a few minutes. Initial lacing looks decent. Body is a dark copper, low visibility, with a load of nucleating bubbles coming up. Looks very nice so far.

Aroma is pretty damn assertive, and it’s a bit much. Loads of nutmeg assault the nose and it’s pretty hard to pick up anything else. Undertones of pumpkin and cinnamon. Pretty sure it’s safe to say this doesn’t smell like beer, maybe I’ve outgrown this style. It’s…alright all things considered.

Flavor is less intense, but arguably less palatable. It’s actually somewhat watery, so imagine nutmeg flavored water - yeah not that great, definitely gross at times. Like…I feel like you either make a totally bastardized pumpkin spice latte beer, or you make a real pumpkin beer that is earthy, etc. etc., but this is somehow neither. I mean, I’ve had worse, but not many in the pumpkin category, and that’s saying quite a bit.

Carbonation is on the higher side at first, fades with a little time. As mentioned, super watery, and that is true for the body as well. Bitterness is not perceptible with all the spice going on. It’s surprisingly not stupid sweet, only a touch of sweetness, which is one small redeeming factor I suppose. Overall not bad, but the watery thin mouth is pretty hard to ignore.

Appearance turned out less than expected with absolutely zero lacing.

Overall not a very good beer, it’s drinkable, but just barely.

12oz bottle poured into a goblet

A- pours a clear amber color with a one-finger foamy white head that reduces to a ring around the edge

S- smells of cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg and cola

T- initial taste gives an impression of Dr Pepper, which I'm assuming is from the spice additions. Picking up cinnamon predominately. Mid-palate gives some sweet malty notes, the finish gives more cinnamon and cola

M- medium body with medium carbonation leads to a foamy mouthfeel that continues into the finish

O- wasn't expecting this to taste like a Dr Pepper, but it's not bad. It goes down easy, but I probably wouldn't have known it was a pumpkin beer if I tried it blind

Copper to light amber in color with excellent clarity and vibrant carbonation bubbles. There’s a fingernail of brown around two thirds of the rim. The aroma is of nutmeg and cinnamon. I taste nutmeg, cinnamon, and pumpkin pie spice. The mouth is moderately spiced and watery.

Slightly hazy amber with a short but thick and creamy head with good retention, settling into a thin cap and ring, leaving little lacing until I tip the glass, then a thin sheet that breaks up into strings sliding back down.

The aroma is cinnamon. That's pretty much it - cinnamon. Touch of other spices, but the cinnamon dominates. I'm reminded of a guest at our home years ago from England who described American apple pie as "cinnamon pie."

Ah, the taste is much more nuanced. Cinnamon, of course, but also a malty presence and a smoothness that may be from the squash/pumpkin as well as nutmeg and cloves. Actually, this is a very tasty pumpkin beer, if that is your thing. (As I stated, it's not my preference, but this is quite good for what it is intended to be.) The finish is sweet and spicy, with a creamy feel left behind.

The mouth feel is thick-ish, smooth, and creamy, which is worthy of a "well done" considering the low ABV.

Overall, I recommend this one to fans of pumpkin ales (although, caveat emptor... since I am NOT a fan of pumpkin ales, maybe I don't know what I'm talking about.)

Appearance: Medium amber-orange, with a large and dense, finely-beaded head. A thick and unbroken sheet of finely-beaded lacing adorns the glass wall. Fat bubbles drift lazily to the surface.

Aroma: Classic pumpkin pie aroma is very prominent, with nutmeg and cinnamon being particularly notable. Brown sugar is a strong presence, as well. With the restrained ABV of 4.2%, there is no alcohol presence in the aroma. The aroma is overall similar to cold pumpkin pie.

Taste: The taste opens with a good measure of brown sugar and prominent pumpkin pie spices, particularly cinnamon and nutmeg. As the taste carries on, the brown sugar offers a pleasant undercurrent. Midway through the taste, there is a bit of clove. Late in the taste, there is a bit of cola flavor. The finish is rather dry.

Mouth feel: Soft and full, quite pleasant with only light carbonation.

Drinkability/notes: A quite nice example of a pumpkin beer, and at an ABV of just 4.2%, it seems very well suited to moderation. If you like a lot of pumpkin spice flavor and sweetness in a beer with a moderate ABV, this is a great choice.

Presentation: Packaged in a twelve-ounce brown glass long-neck bottle with a pry-off crown, sserved in a La Fin du Monde tulip, at The Lake House.

Had this at a house party in Boston on Halloween weekend (appropriately). Fairly sweet with lots of cinnamon, nutmeg, clove, etc.. Pretty much tastes like a pumpkin pie in a bottle. Not bad for my tastes.
It's easy to fuck up a pumpkin beer but this one is surprisingly solid. You get a blast of spice upfront - definite nutmeg with cinnamon undertones. It's good from a mass produced brewery.
Pours a light amber. Light foam. Light pumpkin aroma. Very sweet. Heavy pumpkin and brown sugar body. Candied yams. If you like sweet pumpkin ales you'll like this one.

12 oz bottle poured into a tulip pint glass. They messed up the spice profile on this beer because rather than a pumpkin spice flavor, it smells and tastes like cola. Not undrinkable, but weird and not at all as expected.

12 oz. chilled bottle poured into chilled mug. Freshness notch of February preset on bottle. Purchased as part of a fall Samuel Adams collection.

L: Dark copper color with small white head. Rather hazy and thick, almost opaque. No visible bubbling. 4.0

S: Rather neutral smell. I get almost nothing from it. 3.0

T: Pumpkin pie spice, cinnamon. I'm normally not one of those "pumpkin pie everything!" people when the leaves start changing, but this is pretty darn good. I don't even really like pumpkin pie... 4.25

F: A little carbonation, wish it had more. Not offensive or harsh. 4.0

O: Easy to drink, a nice treat. I'll buy more of these if I can find them individually. 4.0

A- thin head typical of a pumpkin, moderate copper color

S-A bit muddled. Metallic overtones, malted barley, pumpkin bread

T-Much, MUCH better than the aroma had me prepared for. Vanilla, nutmeg, clove, canned pumpkin pie mix. Extremely pleasant. Not super complex but sweet and solid. It’s a fall day of raking leaves in a glass.

M- Pops, pleasant on the tongue, brings out the spice.

O- smell had me worried but it’s an extremely solid pumpkin beer. Not as complex as Pumpking, or my personal favorite, Alewerks pumpkin beer, but it is a readily available and delicious pumpkin offering.

I guess I'm in the minority here..I enjoyed this beer...

Sweet pumpkin pie flavors abound and I'm ok with that..

I wish the ABV was a little higher but other than that...this is a nice pumpkin ale and I like it more than others....

A- light orange and clove color. minimal head.

S- strong on the clove. no malt

F- clove and and pumpkin pie..not bad but its over dominating.

M- clove and chewy. feels like eating mushy pumpkin pie

O- ok but wouldnt get more.

Appearance: Pours a completely clear, medium but bright orange color with a strong white head. SRM of 10-12. (4.00)

Aroma: Moderate aromas of bread malts, toasted bread malts, some light, smooth caramel underneath. (4.00)

Flavor: Moderate flavors of smooth bread malt, caramel malt. A relatively dry finish.

Feel: A full mouthfeel, but a relatively lighter body and finishes dry. Strong carbonation.

Compared to Revolution Oktoberfest 9/14/22: Pours similar, stronger aromas. More

Compared to Great Lakes Oktoberfest 9/14/22: Pours slightly lighter, stronger aromas. More smooth caramel malt. Flatter, less bread, yeast, carbonation, and honey. Winner: Great Lakes

Overall: A pretty standard Oktoberfest here. Standard bready flavors, smooth caramel malt, Lower carbonation and yeast, but it finishes dry. Nothing out of the ordinary. (Rating: 3.70)

Bottle. White head. Clear golden color.

Biscuit and toasted crackers. Bready malts. Grassy and zesty hops. Faint bitterness. Has a touch of honey. Slightly reminds me of a Maibock. Very smooth, easy drinking, and too style.

Attractive clear bronze body under an average size off white head, Baked bread aroma with light notes of floral hops. Taste starts sweet without being cloying and allowing only modest bitterness. Malts dominate through to the aftertaste. Finishes smooth over light carbonation. Well made and enjoyable.

There is a date that barely appears on the shoulder of the bottle. It seems like it is lightly etched in the glass. It is hard to read when there is beer in the bottle, but after it is poured out it is easier to see: "BOTTLED 07-28-22 4663"

Appearance: The body is a medium-to-dark shade of golden brown. It has very good clarity. The head is short with a slightly off-white color. The head slowly recedes leaving no lacing and only a thin film of bubbles with a small ring around the glass. The color of the beer is very nice.

Aroma: There isn't much aroma but there is a very faint scent of wet leaves.

Taste: Up front there is a mixture of coffee, bread crust, and toffee. Towards the middle these flavors intensify and the bread crust flavor expands the greatest on the palate. Towards the back of the palate there is a very light spicy and herbal character which gives the beer just a bit of bite at the end. The aftertaste is very pleasant with a light tea quality and it lends itself very good drinkability.

Mouthfeel: The body is just at the threshold between light and medium, where it has a presence on the palate but moves on and off the tongue very quickly without much traction. The beer is very drinkability and it has a mild earthy bitterness. It is a very pleasant beer to drink.

Overall: The beer doesn't have much aroma, but that is quickly forgotten when the flavor kicks in. The beer delivers a wonderful complement of flavors and the beer is still light enough that it remains very drinkable. It is an easy beer to have one and just move on to another one. Although the highlight of the beer would be the fantastic drinkability, another element that is very enjoyable is the bread crust flavor which has just a very light touch of sweetness that is balanced by an earthy quality. I would recommend it because although the beer doesn't have much aroma it still tastes great. I would buy it again.

Poured into shaker pint. Not much head, surprisingly. Amber color, medium.

Light sweet malt nose.

Taste follows. Sweet toasted caramel malt and a hint of spice. No surprises.

Feel however is verrrrry smooth. Little carb on this one.

Classically Märzen. A ton of beers like this, but that's true of most styles.

12oz bottle, no date, served in a pilsner glass.

Appearance: Clear copper-amber. Thin white head that died back to a persistent ring with an occasional island of lacing.

Smell: Toasted malt, a little bit of noble hops, and a little bit of apple as well.

Taste: Rich toasted malt, noble hop bitterness for balance, crisp. Very nice in its simplicity.

Mouthfeel: Good carbonation, nice thickness, slick.

Overall / Drinkability: Very very drinkable. Went down really fast as a Marzen should. Simple, but deeply flavorful. Went well with mac and cheese and would pair well with a wide range of foods. I could easily have another one.

Pours a beautiful clear golden/amber with a smallish and short-lived white cap. Minimal spotty lacing. Aroma is bready with caramel and malt. Flavor is sweet and bready, minimally hoppy. Feel is medium bodied and lightly carbonated. Overall, a nice (American) Oktoberfest beer.

Munsterfest from 3 Floyds. 12 oz bottle from Shangy’s, Emmaus, PA, from 18/09/21. $ 2.64 (including tax) ($ 0.220/oz). Stored at room temperature in store and at 40 degrees after purchase. Reviewed 15/03/22. Note that I use DD/MM/YY protocol.
Etched on shoulder “BOTTLED 08-02-21”. Served at 41.1 degrees in a hand washed and dried Jester King snifter. Final temperature 47.3 degrees.
Appearance – 3.5
First pour – Deep Gold (SRM 6), clear.
Body – Pale Amber (SRM 9), opaque. When rear-lite, translucent, and chill haze apparent.
Head – Average (Maximum 1.3 cm, aggressive center pour), floral white, creamy with average retention, diminishing to a 0.3 to 0.4 cm undulating crown and thin partial cap.
Lacing – Poor – just a few random lumps of bubbles.
Aroma – 3.5 – Weak malty/caramel/toffee/fruit, no hops, no yeast.
Flavor – 3.25 – A bit sweet with some fruity/malty taste, maybe some caramel or toffee, weak hops, no flavors of yeast. No ethanol (6% ABV, as marked on container) taste or aroma, no gastric warming. No dimethylsulfide or diacetyl. Ends slightly bitter.
Palate – 3 – Thin, watery, soft carbonation.
Final impression and summation: 3.25 Meh. Another mediocre Festbier.

A - Pours a deep amber with a small creamy white head. Light clingy lacing.

S - Aroma is caramel, toasted biscuit, yeasty bread and floral hops.

T - The taste is caramel, toasted biscuit, white bread and floral hops.

M - Medium body with medium carbonation. Creamy with a nice crisp finish.

O - Solid Marzen.

Brief Review:

O: Been about 7 years since I’ve had this one, back again with the new Michigan distro. I forgot how much on the sweet and malty side this beer is, was expecting more of a hoppy crispness. But I do like this, pretty good balance and very drinkable as a good Oktoberfest should be.

Recommendation: Maybe not a classic rendering by most standards, but this is a nice-drinking Oktoberfest for the season.

Picked up a 12 oz bottle at Half Time Distributors in Poughkeepsie NY. Poured into a pint glass, this beer shows a beautiful copper color, almost crystal clear. The head is slightly off-white, medium size with average to slightly better than average retention. lacing is minimal. Aroma is fairly faint, malty and a little spicy/toffee. Taste is better, I have had more impressive Marzens, but this one is pretty good. Malty, slightly floral with some toffee and spices with a bit of underlying bitterness. Mouthfeel is fairly light but not watery. Three Floyds often nails a style better, but this one is pretty good!!!

Pours a nice amber color. Semi clear. The head is 1 finger, it is decent lasting, but has minimal lacing on the glass.
The nose is pretty light, actually. I get a faint malt/caramel aroma, but nothing too strong.
Taste - This beer has a good deal of caramel in it, and it kicks in on the back. Up front is a buttery, bread, biscuit flavor.
The body is somewhat creamy feeling. A bit bubbly. Smooth.
Not bad. Glad I bought it to try.

Pours clear, light copper in color with one quarter inch head. Taste is fresh brown bread and dry wheat bread. Medium body and carbonation, slightly sweet. Solid Marzen but it is missing something. Decent but I prefer the German classics.

Beautifully clear deep amber just shy of acorn brown with a tall khaki foam head slowly collapsing in fits and starts to a lumpy, sparse blanket.

Exceptionally malty, toasty, and fairly bitter, there's even unexpected hints of phenolic spice. This is certainly a unique Oktoberfest, somewhat like pumpernickel verging into gingerbread, but not quite.

No, it's not a holiday beer. It's not a pumpkin spice beer. But iT's NoT nOrMaL.

It's bolder than your average marzen, in several directions.

Disclaimer. Not my favorite style. But its a lager! Octs always seem to sweet. And they are high abv often. This has some of a aforementioned. But bbn leens full lager and is refreshing ice cold. Low carbonation which is ideal for this style. Paring with indian food and it should work.

Before I start, let me say this beer makes me happy. First of all, all these American o-fests have done what Americanized versions always do, and that is take the basic profiles of a style and turn all the flavors up wayyyy too high and nothing is as drinkable or balanced anymore. On that note...

Munsterfest is everything I want in an ofest. A poundable lager with malty and warm flavors, a whispy head, and beautiful color. You have to pour this vigorously to get the foamy head and lacing.. it might be ever-so-slightly under-carb’d, but that actually lends to the drinkability AND the flavors of this ofest. It has a little red ale in the nose, slightly metallic but not too off-putting, so at first, before the sip, I wasn’t sure. TheN this glorious ofest elixir hit my tongue, and wowza!!!!!

This beer tastes great. Cold, warm, no matter, but i think its better colder than some other versions of this style. Thats not necessarily a bad thing tho.. it slight lack of carbonation and the silkiness that makes it unique. Its very smooth and creamy in the taste despite the low carb and thinner body.. its a thin oil slick of ofest greatness. You have the big flavor spins like Sams or Great Lakes, and I love them both in their own way, but if i wanna pound a great ofest in massive seasion manner, give me Munsterfest. Im putting behind a classic like Ayinger, but for an American ofest, its originality, poundability, and viscosity, make it a bright shining star!!! This beer is fan-freaking-tastic, and more than any ofest in years, has me going back for more and more.. that night.. each week.. until they are available no more..
Pours a light copper color with a finger of head. The nose is grainy and herbal. The flavor profile has some caramel and some nuttiness. The finish is clean and the body is spot on for the style.

12oz can, dated 08.29.2022, poured into a 12oz stemless wine glass.

The beer pours an incredibly deep jet black, massive texture, sludge, oil, tan head, only a finger or so with no real retention nor lacing, just a thin film around the circumference of the glass. The aroma is excellent, massive barrel character, huge spirit heat, charred oak, roasted grain, bittersweet dark chocolate, toasted coconut, stone fruits, heavy vanilla marshmallow and a sea salt kick. The flavors are good, super rich chocolate, dark, bittersweet, big roast, charred oak, coconut, toffee, brown sugar, stone fruits, vanilla marshmallow and light sea salt. The mouthfeel is great, super thick and coating, massive body, creamy texture with a warm finish.

Verdict: An amazing stout from Half Acre. Incredible texture and body, super smooth and balanced flavors that really amplify the marshmallow and the sea salt without losing all the complexities layered underneath.

Canned 8/29/22; drank 9/18/22 @ the Yarchives.

Midnight black appearance.

A rough pour yielded a HUGE, noisy dark tan head (careful pouring!); minimal lace.

Rich vanilla, milk chocolate, mild oak & faint booze heat notes in the nose.

Thick, creamy mouthfeel.

Rich vanilla & milk chocolate flavors up front; mild oak & bourbon heat on the finish. The sea salt isn't present, but likely tempers the sweetness, making this DANGEROUSLY drinkable.

A borderline stunner from Half Acre.
Big and inky black in the glass. Bourbon chocolate salt with hints of vanilla. Not getting too much marshmallow. A nice balance between bitterness and sweetness.

A: pours an orange amber body with a thick, off-shite head with excellent retention and lacing.
S: sweet clove, allspice, nutmeg, cinnamon, coffee smell with notes of vanilla and pumpkin.
T: sweet, clove and black coffee taste; hints of chocolate-coffee notes, nutmeg and subtle cinnamon notes.
M: medium bodied, but a little thin
O: nice feel and taste overall; pretty nice fall beer.
Poured hard from a tall can. Orangey-gold color. Taste is pumpkin and plenty of coffee, with some spices. Too much coffee flavor for my taste, but I suppose it is called a PSL for a reason.
Pours a orange gold. Creamy foam. Pumpkin spice aroma. Big pumpkin spice body. Clove and cinnamon. Slightly sweet. Very smooth. Good flavor. Not sure where the latte comes in but it's pretty good.

13.65oz nitro-can poured into a tulip.

Pours a hazy glowing burnt golden; creamy light khaki head that fades leaving bubbly retention and little to no lacing; great nitro-beer magic with a hard pour.

The aromas have a nice amount of pumpkin spices leading the way. Some caramel. Mild hints of coffee and vanilla. Some veggies. Malts are there.

The flavors follow the nose. More pumpkin spices leading the way, especially cinnamon and nutmeg. More caramel and vanilla. The coffee is on the subtle side, but it's ultimately noticeable. More veggies along with some sweet potatoes. Mild spice notes that linger in the finish. Moderate sweetness. Lower bitterness. Strong malt backbone. Alcohol goes unnoticed.

Mouthfeel is what you'd expect from a nitro-beer. It's on the fuller side of medium-bodied and actually pushing full-bodied with no carbonation. It's watery as expected, but it's actually a bit thicker than expected.

This is a nice pumpkin ale. Nice aromas and flavors. It's bold while not being too over the top. Well done, I really like it.
The beer looks great but it just has this off taste to me. Like it's artificial or something idk, it's getting better to me but it isn't something I'd seek out again at all.

16 oz can.

Pours a hazy orange gold color. Typical white nitro head. Not great retention or lacing for the style.

Smells like ginger and squash.

The ginger dominates the flavor, with some nutmeg, pumpkin, and caramel. Has a bit of roasted coffee on the finish. Cinnamon and allspice cling to the tongue, eventually overstaying their welcome.

The feel is typical of the style. A tad watery. The spices linger a bit too long.

Overall, 3's across the board, i.e. Meh. Not the worst pumpkin beer I've had but far from the best, and this is a style I'm already not terribly fond of.

If you really, really love pumpkin ales then it's certainly worth a shot. If not, don't bother. Just get the stout.
Nice classic German beer. Simple ingredients. Slight bready aroma. Bready malt taste to start, with crisp, clean finish. Medium carbonation. A very drinkable beer.

Poured from a growler purchased at Collective.

Appearance - Pours a clear gold with three fingers of bubbly frothy white head.

Smell - earthy, floral, leafy, and grassy hops, bready and biscuity malts, lemon, and earthy yeast.

Taste - bitter earthy, floral, and grassy hops upfront. The bready and biscuity malts alongside the lemon come through next. The earthy yeast rounds out the brew.

Mouthfeel - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Finishes sticky from the hops with the bready notes lingering as well.

Overall - A very quaffable festbier. I can see why this is drunk in high volumes in Germany on Oktoberfest. This one is quite flavourful as well. Glad I could try one of the official brews of Oktoberfest.

Poured from a bottle into a pint glass. The beer is a clear medium gold color with 2 fingers of white foam. Retention is great leaving a thick cap.
Aroma is medium-low. The aroma has crackery malt, light amount of herbal hops and a very slight yeast smell. It has an overall clean aroma.
Taste is slightly above medium in strength. The taste has light cracker malt, a herbal hop bitterness that's somewhat below medium and a slight yeast flavor at the end.
Feel is slightly below medium in thickness. Carbonation is low. Astringency is somewhat below medium.
Overall, this is my first beer in this style. This one is okay.

Picked up a sixer from TW-Greenville, SC 7-27-22 for $11.99. Presuming 124V is a julian date so bottled 5-4-22; consumed for review 9-1-22.

Beer poured golden with an okay white head.

Nose is emitted notes of white bread.

Taste follows the nose where the malt base is bread forward and the sweetness is balanced nicely by noble hops.

Mouthfeel is light to medium bodied and smooth.

Overall an enjoyable fest bier that hits the style nicely.

vom Fass (on/from Draft)
Consumed on: 17 Sept, 2022
Glass: 0.5 L Fest Mug


Look:
Deep and clear golden yellow. 1.5 finger off-white head dissipates quickly. This could be the result of having the filled w/o rinsing it out from the previous beer.

Smell:
Doughy and bready malts with a light not of floral and grassy hops. Lightly toasted grains pop in at times.

Taste:
Much the same as the nose with some extra spiciness from the hops. The finish is ever-so-slightly on the dry side.

Feel:
Smooth and crisp Body is medium.

Overall:
A very easy-drinking and refreshing Festbier. Very quaffable and definitely a beer that could be consumed in quantity. A solid representation of the Festbier style.



Previous Rating (year old bottles):

3.86/5 rDev +9%
look: 4.25 | smell: 3.75 | taste: 3.75 | feel: 4 | overall: 4

1.5 x 333ml bottles
Date Code: 105U
Consumed on: 27 Aug, 2022
Glass: 0.5 L Fest Mug


Look:
Bright and deep golden yellow with a 2-finger foamy white head. The head fades to about a quarter of an inch of foam. Lacing is good.

Smell:
Sweet bread and biscuits with a touch of floral and grassy hops. Lightly toasted grains pop in at times. The aromas are on the mild side.

Taste:
Light bready (and biscuity) malts start things off and are joined by a light sweet note. Then the hops arrive with some spice and a mild but firm bitterness. The hops linger through the aftertaste, helping to dry the sip out some.

Feel:
Soft and smooth with a mildly dry finish. Body is light-medium.

Overall:
A very easy-drinking and refreshing Festbier. It's alcohol (6.3% ABV) is well hidden. Definitely a beer that could be consumed in quantity. Or after a warm day, which today very much was.

This brew two years ago was OUTSTANDING. But I noticed last year it changed. Like many others it was cheapened, hence the drop in quality and taste. It is still pretty good, (sorry cannot be more illustrative) not bad for the style, but unfortunately it went from arguably the best of the Marzen creed to very average. It use to have a wonderful aftertaste that dangerously incited you to drink large amounts of it, but now, after one or two you're like; meh. And then the despair as you remember what it was like in the recent past. This opinion is not just mine, but shared by a few I know, friends that know this style of beer, to bar managers that order it. They too share my dismay. Sad. For the price of this beer there are others that are better and cost less.

This is definitely rated lower than I would have thought. On my own personal experience I found this really good and definitely an accurate representation of the style. Maybe not greatest in the world but idk I was satisfied.

A clear, golden yellow beer in the glass with a thin, straggly head.

Aroma-wise there's bread and some floral notes that foretell of the balance and drinkability to come.

In the mouth there's a beautiful balance of mild bitterness, subtle floral hops, an ever-so-slight corn note and retronasally soft creaminess that demands another sip.

There's a reason this is drunk all day long in one-litre vessels. The alcohol is hidden, the beer is refreshing and the whole experience synergises into something greater than all of the parts.

Perhaps it's the romance of the style or the aura of the festival that lends this beer its name, but whatever it is, I want another one!

Cheers!

My first shot at an Oktoberfest bier! Pours a rich golden straw colour, a one inch head quickly appears and disappears within a minute. Regardless, it looks very nice in the tall glass. Unlike many pils I’ve had in this glass, the bubbles are enormous, streaking upwards in multiple lines. Would’ve looked absolutely gorgeous with a thick rocky head.

Straightforward aromas of wheat, bready malt, and some sparing citrusy but mostly grassy hops.

Right away this beer hits you with very typical taste profiles, and yet, there is a deliciously subtle and relatively complex smattering of tastes in the background. Up front is grain and toasty bread, a little bit of juicy corn. The malty notes balanced by an oh so gentle bitterness from the hops. What are those notes in the background? Fairly hard to differentiate, but they add up to a mildly savoury character. It’s a little bit nutty, a little bit floral, and a little bit earthy. They coalesce to make a savoury, earthy backing to the grassy grains that are more up front. A little bit of esters on that fruity note.

Tastes quite nice with a mild finish on the palate that is basically just bready malt, there is strong carbonation here that foams at the sip, it doesn’t become too creamy or heavy, but just eminently drinkable. The higher abv% is not noticed whatsoever. I doubt anyone would be able to tell if this was a 4% pils, a 5.5% lager, or the 6.3% brew it is. Medium-light bodied that finishes dry and sweet, this is a tasty drink.

Overall — a really good festbier. If this is a good example of the style, I can’t wait to try more. I’ll admit this was a long wanted find for me. I’ve been hunting the entire Hofbrau line in Canada for a long time. Hofbrau Oktoberfest was only at 4 stores at the LCBO, most having one or two left. I went to all 4.

Nothing. The leftover was just artifacts in the LCBO online system (someone probably shoplifted them). So to my surprise, I found it randomly at a North York LCBO that didn’t even have it listed. I bought all four that were left. Glad I did, you could easily drink all four in a single sitting. The design really draws you in, a nice brown bottle with classy and understated labelling. The Oktoberfest has inviting autumnal tones of orange and a nice scene on the front.

This beer has a little something going for it that is hard to put a finger on. It is definitely unique and does not taste like a typical lager or Pilsner despite having the same hallmark flavours. I really enjoyed this, the flavours are just so well balanced and in tune, it would be easy to mistake this for a general, slightly above average beer. But there’s much more going on!

JUNE 13th DRINK:
Had the last of my Oktoberfest biers, likely the last we’ll see until, well next October! I stand by the review and despite the beer being a few months older now, it’s just as fresh and drinkable. Smell increasing from original 3.25 to 3.5, it smells just fine! Feel increased from 3.75 to 4. It’s crisp and delicious.

I’m going to be as objective as I can but it’s going to be difficult. Rewind back to the halcyon days of 2009, I was traveling to Germany to visit some folks of a friend of mine. I was 20 years old and a year before I joined BA.

Eventually we wind up at the Hofbrauhaus in Munich. Sitting at the giant tables, eating white sausage and getting housed off of 2 liters of beer was one of the most phenomenal drinking experiences I’ve ever had. I will always have an affinity for the brand, but I will try to keep it legit.

My attempt to keep it legit is evident in the appearance. It sucks. It pours a weak straw color with some good head.

Aroma is of oh so smooth caramel malts and breast undertones

Tastes of biscuits, caramel, some dark fruit in the finish with some metallic tones bringing it down a bit.

Mouthfeel is sharp and refreshing

Overall it’s a beer greater than the sum of its parts. It’s a decent beer to drink in the fall season but nothing spectacular.
Light pour going towards yellow with a thin fleeting head. Smells of German origin, with subtle hops-yeast-malt flavor. Nice and drinkable. This would make a good feast beer or festbier. Cheers!

12 oz bottle

Pours clear medium yellow golden, white head. Good head retention. Mild grainy aroma. Similar flavor - a little cracked corn, earthy. Thinner bodied.

What can I say, I've tasted TONS OF BEER! This is a real man's beer. It takes a DEVELOPED PALATE to appreciate this beer. People that love IPA's are probably not going to love the taste of this beer. After all of my beer travels and phases I've gone through over the years. I gravitate back to original beer flavor. THIS IS THAT FLAVOR! Hofbräu has NAILED IT!!

P.S.
Stay away from the metal mini kegs. Beer tastes metallic from those. Brown bottle is best.

This is my current favourite beer. My near perfect rating may be out of step with the others here, but I don't care. For me, this is beer done right. The colour is lighter than you might expect for a Märzen, though I guess we're now making a distinction between Festbier and Märzen, in which case it's about average compared to most of the other Munich Six: clear deep gold, with a frothy white head that has surprisingly long retention considering the high ABV. The smell and taste, however, are "darker" than the colour would suggest. On the nose, the first impression is a very deep, nutty, bready malt, with a hint of caramel, and something spicy. The taste starts the same way, with a beautiful and richly complex malt profile, very distinctively nutty, with the impression of dark, chewy bread, subtle and subdued caramel malt, followed up by a lovely earthy hops that is deep and rich, rather than bright and zesty or bitter, and a gentle spicy pepper hops finish. I can't stress enough how well it all works together. The ingredients must have been so carefully considered to construct such a perfectly balanced flavour profile, which nevertheless has a very distinctive character. The malts are smooth and deep without being too rich or sweet, and the hops profile affirms and strengthens this "middle of the tongue" balance. It's perfection. The mouthfeel is very smooth, slightly creamy, exactly middle weight, not too heavy for a hot day nor too light for a winter night - this beer is Balance in a Bottle, without being boring. The alcohol content is seamlessly disguised, and I mean seamlessly, to the point of being dangerous. You would not guess it's 6.3% as you were drinking it, and if you didn't know that going in, by the time you realised how strong it was it would be too late. Almost a shame, because I would love to be able to drink more than one of these with supper and still be able to have a sober evening, but alas. Overall, this for me is the perfect beer for any and every time, because it is so perfectly "in the middle" of so many ratios: sweetness to dryness, malts to hops, complexity to drinkability. Hofbräu has achieved the Golden Ratio with their Oktoberfestbier, and I say Prost to that.

On tap at Das Beer Garden. Clear deep golden. Smells a little bready with hints of floral hops. Tastes of sweet bread with light toasted notes. Herbal hops, hints of florals in the finish. Light body and very drinkable. Definitely not what I, as an American, expected out of an Octoberfest, but the malt profile is a little deeper than other popular German lagers.

Today is a new beer to me.

Hofbrau – Oktoberfestbier

6.3% ABV

The beer is listed as an Oktoberfest festbier on the label – and listed as “Lager – Festbier / weisnbier” on BA. I have no earthly idea what a weisnbier is.

The beer was removed from a 40ish degree temp fridge after having been refrigerated for approximately 2 weeks. Beer poured into a classic Hofbrau dimpled stein. Consumed over a 40ish minute period while eating a brat with german mustard and barrel kraut.

First Impression: Quite beautiful; pours a wonderful hay/straw golden yellow with a nice head. 4.35

Appearance: Beer is quite clear, but perhaps not as clear as one might hope or expect. Maybe that expectation is unrealistic, but my feelings for a festbier are similar to (approaching) those for a pilsner with it being quite clear. Beautiful color, although perhaps a shade darker than expected. 4.6

Smell: As is always the case for me with Oktoberfest beers, this one isn’t particularly fragrant. I get a very light bready nose, and then something I can’t quite identify. It’s a little sweet. Again (see taste below), I get some Belgian esters that no one else seems to get. 4.0

Taste: Much to my surprise, this is actually quite nice for a festbier. I’m normally not one for festbiers, as I traditionally find them quite pale – and more pale than I prefer. There’s almost no discernable hop presence. I’d argue this is almost like a cross between a marzen and a festbier, but I’m no expert. I still get some of the Belgian esters that others don’t get (specifically some bubblegum and clove). Only a small amount of yeasty, bread, crust flavor – not as much as I’d prefer. 4.35

Mouthfeel: Nothing special. Mostly classic, but thicker than I’d prefer, especially for a festbier. I’d prefer if this were a bit more crisp, which I normally associate with festbiers. 3.85

Overall: Not a lot to add. This is good, but perhaps not everything I would look for in a festbier. Truth be told, I purchased this by accident, since I usually enjoy marzens more than festbiers due to the hop presence. By that metric, I should like this, but it’s just not hitting the spot (both for me personally and for what I think this beer should be). It is going quite well with the brat and kraut, however. 4.0

BA Review Score: 4.161

Clear golden pour with two fingers of white foam, no lacing oddly enough. German yeast dominated nose with malt sweetness in an airy way. Taste is more complex with a bready and mild caramel malt flavor complexion with a kiss of honey, but yeast character suffers. Feel is light, airy, yeasty, but doesn't have any lasting power on the palate.

Bottled 4/5/21

Just as I was complaining that Half Time sent way more Märzens than Festbiers in the mixed pack, I open the fridge and find a Festbier! This one doesn’t really have great ratings, but at least it’ll be a nice change of pace from the overly sweet Märzen I just had from Blue Point. Let’s see what it’s all about

Pours a clear bright gold with 2 fingers of creamy white head that slowly fades to a thin cap and leaves minimal lacing

Well, despite the change up in style, this is still overly sweet in the nose. I’m picking up on aromas of bready malt, earthy hops, toasted grain, sweet caramel, white pepper, and honey

It’s at least saved in taste, where there’s more of a firm bitterness. On the front end of the sip I’m tasting pale malt, spicy hops, toasted bread, white pepper, and a touch of caramel. The swallow sweetens up a bit, bringing notes of overripe pear, caramel malt, earthy hops, and toasted grain

A medium body pairs with moderate scrubbing carbonation, resulting in a crisp and refreshing beer. Finishes off dry but a bit too sweet

I think this one is pretry good. Quite up there in alcohol for the style but it doesn’t feel like it. I could throw back quite a few of these

330ml bottle into a pint glass. Believe it to be this years release.

Mixed look, crystal clean pale golden yellow body. Head quickly disappears, no lacing.

Simple malty aroma.

On tasting, malty, somewhat sweet, a little dryness.

Mouth medium, finish malty with a featherlight bitter note.

Overall, another beer I could have a few of at a time, but not one I would eagerly seek out.

Sampling a cold 11.2 oz bottle poured into my .5L dimple mug. The beer pours a clear golden color, a deep champagne color in the glass. Bleached white fluffy head of 2 cm foams up and fades to a sturdy edge layering. Several streams of active carbonation rise to the surface of my glass.
The aroma is some biscuit malts and light fruit with a bit of white grape and also some mild spicy hops. Generally a mild and clean nose.
First sip reveals a light body with fine and prickly carbonation. Texture is a little watery and totally crushing fast for drinking. Dries out just a bit on the finish.
Flavor is some biscuit and a bit of grain. Not as fruity as the nose. Finish is dry and does have some spicy hop bite that lingers a bit with mild astringency, and then is gone.
Overall this is a very easy to drink beer and has a favorable flavor profile. Glad to have tried this one.

Oh damn this is good. Soooo much dark roasted coffee up front. I also get baker's chocolate, a nice bourbon tingle, and a lingering fudginess. Probably the most coffee forward beer I've had. Absolutely loving this one!

I had this on draft 9/14/22 @ the Beer Temple.

Black appearance.

Small tan head; almost no lace.

MASSIVE dark roast coffee bean, mild vanilla & booze heat notes in the nose.

Thick, creamy mouthfeel.

HUUUUGE dark roast coffee bean flavors up front; chocolate syrup & mild booze heat notes on the finish.

If you're a dark roast junkie this might be manna for your soul; for me it was way too much, and only good for a few ounces.

Oh MY! This monster from the 12 oz bottle pours a murky blackish brown
with a nice head of brown foam that settles to a thin ring with light lacing.....
and with a swirl.....she's got great legs! Nose of rich coffee, vanilla, cream, char,
brulee, dark cocoa, and inviting bourbon with touches of dark fruits and tobacco.
Flavors nail it with dark bakers chocolate, dark roasted coffee in abundance, mellow
bourbon, heavy char, brulee, dark fruits of blueberry and with warmth dark tart cherry.
Tobacco and oak make a play with warmth as well as sherry notes all vying for a pole position
over the driving force of rich roasted coffee. Nice mouth feel; full body, smooth, very coating,
rich, warming from the booze note, faint carbonation, and finishing with a lovely bitter malt
note that lingers long.

Overall----stout lovers, take note, THIS ONE ROCKS!

Cheers

The body pours as black as night. No head. Not much carbonation. Doesn't matter. Doesn't need it. Aged over a year in Willet bourbon barrels, this beer is the big cousin to Lagunitas Willettized stout.

Nose and taste are all about the barrel. Blending wonderfully with the bourbon is a delightful coffee flavor from the addition of Dark Matter coffee. My memory believes this stout is CBS without the chocolate notes.

Mouthfeel is good but not as heavy as one might expect given the ABV.

This is definitely a great stout and I'm glad I like it considering I've been less than impressed with some of their other beers in other styles. This is no frills and exactly what it says it is. It's thick and syrupy due to the abv and the coffee flavor is akin to Big Bad Baptist for example as it's pretty biting. Was worth getting a 4 pack

Got this from @Jzeilinger and Thank You for it.
The bottle pour is into a clear glass goblet and a thick and mostly black color liquid emerges. A dark tan colored head forms and then very quickly disappears leaving no trace of having been there.

The aroma is mostly coffee that has been fresh roasted along with a touch of bourbon. I thought I also caught some vanilla and oak.

The beer tasted like roasted dark coffee with hints of chocolate, vanilla, and bourbon, but mostly coffee.

Overall, I find it to be really good, and a strong coffee-dominated Stout. The high ABV is also a nice touch. Would I recommend this Stout? You betcha!!

Drank from a 12fl oz (355ml) bottle purchased at Craft Beer Cellar, Belmont, MA
Bottled 10-25-21
Served in a tulip

Fantastic label design. 3 Floyds always impresses in this department. As for the beer, it poured a deep brown/black hue and thinner than anticipated. A small cap of saddle brown bubbles topped the body, but it quickly dissolved. There was zero head retention and no lacing whatsoever. An oily sheen floated on top of the liquid.

The aroma was solid initially and improved with time. Rich and malty. Nice melding of roasted and caramel malt notes. Darker roast coffee also came through strong. Good dose of brown sugar sweetness too. There was a punchy booziness, but not much bourbon specifically. As the beer warmed, the nose became sweeter, punchier and more rounded. Some dark chocolate and vanilla notes also came forth.

The flavor profile was solid but not amazing. Malty and robust up front. Loads of roasted malt character. Hint of char. Roasty coffee notes were apparent but definitely not as strong as in the nose. Big boozy notes kicked in soon and intensified as the beer moved along the palate. Brown sugar was also noticeable. Touch of chocolate. More roast, char and booze on the back end and in the finish.

The mouthfeel was rather disappointing. It was somewhat oily and slick but quite thin for the style. The liquid contained a fine, subtle effervescence that seemed appropriate for a beer of this magnitude.

Crushing Mass was an enjoyable coffee stout, but the bourbon barrel presence was unfortunately quite subtle and the mouthfeel much thinner than anticipated. Perhaps the most impressive aspect of this beer was that the alcohol was so well buried.

Brief Review:

O: Ever since GI stopped doing BCBCS, I've been starving for a good BA coffee stout. Prairie's Mocha Noir blew me away last year, and here comes a new one from Three Floyds. This one's pretty decent.
