F: Very smooth & creamy medium-bodied mouthfeel that's perhaps a little bit juicy, almost big and then it's gone. A fast, clean, lightly drying finish. Quite pleasant.
O: A curiously tasty beer that seems to slip between many lines stylistically. It is lovely tasting, unfiltered, full flavored yet semi-light bodied. Quite tasty, fairly bready and a fast drinker. I would buy this again. It is excellent in it's style.

From the can, it pours a slightly hazy amber color with a nice off-white head that soon diminishes to a nice ring. Some spotty lacing. The nose is slightly earthy smelling toasted malt. The taste is malty with caramel notes and some honey.

The color of the pour looks similar to iced tea and it's well carbonated. I agree with there being honey & caramel in the taste which some of the reviewers have already previously mentioned. In addition to, I'm also tasting some brown bread & a mild molasses note. This was the 1st Zwickelbier that I had & it was smooth & easy drinking. Cheers! B

Amber with a 1 1/2" off white head which, lasts. Moderate lacing.

Aroma of bread, light caramel.

Taste is malty, caramel, toast.

Medium body, moderate carbonation. Semidry finish.

A great German beer.

Deeply, perversely curious as to how a brewery as old and established as fucking Warsteiner rolls out a new product to appease us American pigs.

I associate the phrase "Brewer's Gold" with Brewer's Gold hops, which were once probably genuinely used in Ballantine Ale and then became a weird trademark that had absolutely nothing to do with the Ballantine that was on the market by the time I was alive. Accordingly, my idiot brain expected this to be Ballantine-colored. Friends, it was not. It is instead the color of a very nice bock, and even then that blows my mind expectation-wise because this is listed as Zwickel, which I always thought was like pilsenser-colored but cloudy. You learn something every day.

Aroma is great, but light. Smells like an excellent American marzen. Like Staghorn, or pre-takeover Millstream Oktoberfest. only a bit dim. Nutty, rounded.

Tastes quite good. Malt-heavy, and unapologetically so. Toasted bread up front, getting sweeter in the middle, caramel and a bit of honey, drying up near the end but never quit letting the hops shines through because they don't need to. Tastes fortifying. This is the sort of beer that people in the 1800's would have thought was health food.

Appearance: Pours a clear, deep orange color with a strong and lacy white head. SRM of 13. (4.00)

Aroma: Strong aromas of rich bread malts, toasted malt, brown German bread. Caramel, honey. Earthy yeast underneath.

Flavor: Strong earthy flavors of German bread. Rich brown bread loaf. A strong honey and caramel malt flavor in the middle. A malty finish with a lingering earthiness and toasted malt flavor underneath. Finishes malty and leans sweet from the rich honey.

Feel: Heavier-bodied. Moderate carbonation to balance

Compared to Weihenstephaner 1516 8/13/22: Pours a darker color. Stronger aromas. More rich bread, honey. Less delicate lemon and dry grains. Larger bodied, darker, sweeter.

Compared to Summit Twin Pils 8/13/22: Pours a darker color. Stronger aromas. More malty rich bread, honey. Less lemongrass and dry grains and yeast. Larger bodied, darker, sweeter.

Overall: This beer packs a punch and a little darker than most kellerbiers. Rich bread and honey. Rich and toasty like a Marzen lager. Nice rich bready flavors though like a Zwickel. Delectable and fantastic for a German beer, but darker than I expected. (Rating: 4.06)

Slightly hazy dark amber color, with a moderate head. Nose offers a pleasant caramel maltiness. Excellent body, with a delicious taste of malt tending to the caramel, with a very light toasting. Bitterness is present but hops don't really make themselves known apart from a slight floral taste. Solid, drinkable German beer.

Pours an amber color with a nice head and lacing
Aroma has bready malt, honey and caramel hints
Taste follows the nose with bready malt, honey and caramel flavors
A medium bodied well carbonated beer
A good Zwickelbier

330 ml can poured into a dimpled mug.

Hazy copper with over an inch of creamy off-white foam. Nose is malty, caramel, bread grains and a bit of toast. Tasting much the same with some spicy hop flavor coming on the back. Low bitterness, full malt but lowly sweet. Medium body, soft mild creamy feel to open then crisping to the finish.

A pleasure to drink and leaves me wanting another. Missing the “zing” that usually comes with fresh local examples of this style but that’s to be expected. Seems as though this could be an unfiltered immature version of their Marzen.

Got this as part of their 15-pack variety case with the standard Warsteiner, the Brewers Gold and the Dunkel...
Kellerbier is perhaps, my favorite overall style so, very happy to have stumbled upon this...
Not at the level of Weihenstephaner Kellerbier but, for the money, it's quite good and a nice alternative to the standard Warsteiner...

Warsteiner Brauerei "Warsteiner Brewers Gold"
12 fl. oz. can "Best before: ... A0802 2022-12-10" and sampled on 17 June 2022
$2.99 @ Foodery Beer, Phila., PA

Notes via stream of consciousness: After having a few of the softer, less bitter beers from southern Germany I need a little more bitterness and I think this beer from Warsteiner which is in northern Germany will do the trick. It's poured a hazy (it's unfiltered) deep copper colored body beneath a short head of creamy off-white foam. The aroma is surprisingly malty with toasted bread and some caramel. The taste follows suit adding in a touch of honey and a delicate background of dark skinned fruits and subtle spice. A moderate bitterness balances it, and I guess I was way wrong on this one because it's more malty than bitter. Still, it finishes mostly dry as the majority of the malt fades quickly but it does linger with golden and medium-red caramel and a touch of honey and dark fruit. In the mouth it's medium leaning towards medium-full in body and creamy smooth with a moderate, fine-bubbled carbonation. I was really wrong about this one because it's so different than their other beers and I wonder how it's selling in Germany. I saw plenty of advertising for it in October of 2021 but I never found it anywhere. My guess is that it will end up selling better outside of Germany. Anyway, it's a great beer in my opinion and I'm going to keep it on my radar.
Review #8,081

Nice copper color. Nose is cereal grains, malty, caramel. Taste almost follows exactly. I also get some nuttiness, toffy, and toasted malt. It's OK for what it is. I wish they came in 12 ounce cans instead of the 11.2 ounces.

Very pretty hazy copper amber with two fingers of sudsy tan head that fade fast and leave almost zero lacing. The aroma is quite muted - faint caramel and citrus for sure; anything else is too faint to tell whether I'm imagining it or not. The flavour is surprisingly muted for a Kellerbier. Can't taste any yeast esters. I get caramel malt, citrus hops, a nice smooth finish with a bit of flavour, and that's about it. The pretty appearance and the smooth and balanced mouthfeel are all this one has going for it. Compared to the Hacker-Pschorr Kellerbier, this is a bland and boring disappointment. However, taken purely as a lager, it's drinkable and there's nothing nasty about it. Just don't bother going out of your way to try this.

L:
-pours a slightly hazy amber with a small to medium,foamy,offwhite head
-medium carbonation visible
S:
-malty,spicy,caramel,light roast,vegetal
T:
-Follows the nose + grainy
F:
-medium carbonation
-light to medium body
O:
Typical mediocre stuff from Warsteiner.
The advertised Hop variety doesn't change the profile as it's another Noble Hop and at 12 IBUs it's barely noticeable.

A: Amber, hazy, small tanned head which disappeared fairly quickly, left some lacing.

S: Toasted malts and copper.

T: A combination of burnt malt and tangerine gave a kind of malty, zesty bittersweetness.

M: Medium to thick texture, not much carbonation.

O: Not bad for what it was, a Kellerbier/Amber Lager mashup.

Rated 89? I would say yes to this beer. The bottle is metric so it did not fill my beer mug correctly. It was smooth but it was not exciting or bread heavy or that dark. Nice amber color, but the flavor was good for Oktoberfest.

I have actually never tried this. Ich habe drei Jahre in Deutschland gelebt, but I don’t remember it.
If you have ever been drunk in a beer garden, however, you know I could easily have forgotten or overlooked it.
Amber gold with good retention to the last sip.
I’m not being a jerk but the word is lager. Aromas of hearty breads, mineral water, kinda caramel sweetness. A tiny hint of hops.
Definitely “natural” earthy malt flavors with a respectable but subdued (as it should be) hop bite. A few reviews mention minerals and, man, that’s right on. That water… you will never taste it outside of bottled beverages unless you visit Europe.
I’m calling it medium. Easy to take long draws off of this. It’s all marzen, a real feel for the style and I would have guessed the ABV at 5% tops.
This is an excellent beer if you like the style and a pleasant, fun beer if you are kinda ambivalent about it. Nothing world class here but definitely close to outstanding and really makes me pine for October coolness.

Poured from a bottle into a Pint glass. The beer is semi dark clear amber with 2 fingers of white foam. Retention is good leaving a nice cap.
The aroma is slightly less than medium in strength. There's bready malt, a slight hop aroma and a light yeast smell.
The taste is somewhat above medium in strength. The taste has complex bready malt, light caramel, a moderately bitter and somewhat grassy hop flaver and a mineral taste that blends well with the overall taste.
The feel is closer to medium than high in thickness. It's slightly creamy. Carbonation is medium and tickles the tongue. Astringency is slightly less than medium. It's a fairly dry beer with a great mouth feel..
Overall, it's outstanding with a world class feel.

A: Pours a perfectly clear ruby/amber color. A two finger white head forms with good retention initially. That recedes to a ring after a minute with some lace left behind.
S: A biting mineral quality up front in the nose. That I'm pleased with, and leads to a bit of grape like esters. Toasted malts and grains. Light earthy, Noble hops in the finish.
T: Again, that minerality is up front, and I like that. Toasted malts, grains, sweet English biscuits. A Noble hop earthiness. Fairly simple, but very enjoyable.
M/O: A medium body with effervescent carbonation. Crisp, supper clean and finishes semi dry. Incredibly moreish, and I can down this in big gulps.

I'm surprised I haven't reviewed this before, but I have it most every year. A spot on example of the style IMO, and should be expected. Less is definitely more here, and I just want to keep coming back. Well done as always.

11.2oz bottle poured into a tulip.

Pours a burnt golden with great clarity and transparency; small white head that fades leaving solid retention and lacing. Nice color.

The aromas are on the mild side. Hints of bread and caramel. Malts are there. It doesn't smell bad or anything, it just doesn't have much going on.

The flavors are are very clean, crisp and refreshing. More caramel coming through. Some grains. Subtle sweetness. Moderate to low bitterness. Malts do their thing. Finishes clean. Alcohol is well hidden.

The mouthfeel is nice. It's on the lighter side of medium-bodied with active carbonation. It's sharp and fluffy.

This is a really nice Oktoberfest. Besides mild aromas there's really nothing to complain about. The craftsmanship is on point. It's a very smooth, clean, and classic example of the style. Well done.

Anyone who rates this Octoberfest beer under 4 doesn’t know or like Octoberfest beers .
This is one of the gold standards folks .Up there with Ayinger and a few others .

Look: Clear reddish-gold with a white head that dissipated quickly.

Smell: Bready, malts, hints of citrus-y hops.

Taste: Follows smell; pleasantly bitter with rather earthy bread notes up front; more of the hops in the aftertaste. I detected spicy notes, more so once I'd had a few swallows.

Feel: Medium body, normal carbonation, leaves a dry mouthfeel.

Overall: Pleasant, easy drinking. I can imagine really enjoying this even more in autumn, preferably with a football game or a bonfire and a burger or brat alongside.

Bought this one on sale; may be a bit old, but not past expiration.

A: Thin head, nice lacing on the glass, decent carbonation, beautiful gold copper color. Looks like a good beer.

S: Bready, malt, stale hops. Maybe a touch of citrus.

T: Sharp, tangy. Aftertaste of spice.

M: Silky mouthfeel, feel of spice and hops. Pleasant consistency.

Overall, not a bad fest beer. Anything German is a good deal for me. But there are better German beers out there.

Pours rich dark amber/copper (SRM 12-14) and gem clear. Occasional large bubbles of carbonation race upward toward a light almond head. The head briefly forms one inch of foam and leaves no lace on a double-walled pint glass.

The lightly toasted malt tends more toward toasted white bread than malt. While simple, the aroma is elegant.

The flavor opens with delicate white bread and malt. Light sweetness is equally balanced by bitterness. Other flavors include mild Brazil nuts and possibly pine nuts. The finish is mild and lingering. In general, this beer has an earthy, Autumnal quality. Warmth brings out toffee.

A medium body and smooth, warn-cotton texture. There is no hint of alcohol and light astringency is barely noticeable. Carbonation is soft.

This is just a great drinking beer. It would be equally well-suited for the tail-gate party as well as the game. I found it to be exceptionally well-paired with Autumnal weather and aromas.

This is a solid marzen - great dark bock coloration, a slight, distant citrus smell that very lightly translator the tongue. Mouthfeel was astringent with a sticky after effect. Overall, a very good offering of the style.

A-Golden clear straw yellow with a half finger of white head
S-Aroma of lager and wonderful aged lager
M-High end carbonation, with watery mouthfeel with a malt sweetness
T-Malty sweet with a subtle bitterness that is smooth and classy
O-Solid lager.

On tap hundreds of times, bottles, cans. Today: 11.2oz bottle into a .03L mug.
L: Pours clear orange amber w good carbo, a thin off white head w skin retention, spotty lacing.
S: Bready, caramelized malts, brown bread, a hint of honey, lightly earthy.
T: Lightly toasted caramelized malts, light citrus zest, light tea leaf, very gently earthy, flavors drop off sharply in the finish.
F: A little hop bite & snap then pleasantly smooth, fairly clean med-lite bodied mouthfeel w a very gently drying med-length finish. Rather soft feeling water.
O: This is my personal favorite German Oktoberfest Marzen. It is expertly rounded with superb balance and a soft edge. It finishes with a sweet whisper. Extremely palpable, easy drinking and easily pairs with a wide variety of foods. It is world class in it's style.

Nice “American Marzen” beer. This beer is dark amber in color and a rich bready malt flavor. These were made for our slightly hoppier beer compared to a Wiesen Oktoberfest beer in Munich. The malt and hops balance each other nicely and the alcohol is well hidden for 5.8% in a lager. Try some.

Pours light amber. White head. Aromas of floral and noble hops up front. Malt is overtaken by these - some honey like toast comes through as it warms. The taste is maltier than the nose; toast, brown bread, bread crust; finishes with a floral hoppy, moderate bitter bite. Feel is medium bodied - somewhat fuller than others I've had of this style. Overall, a good marzen style Oktoberfest.

Appearance: Clear amber-red with a massive, rocky, tan-colored head, with superb retention. Small streams of minute bubbles rise quickly to the surface. The lacing is superb and Belgian-like.

Aroma: The aroma is classic for the style, with abundant toasted malts caramel, dark bread, and spicy hops.

Taste: The taste begins with toasted malts, dark bread, and caramel. The initial hop presence is spicy, but turns grassy later in the taste. Finishes with slight, lingering burnt caramel, and mineral notes.

Mouth feel: Soft and smooth, with a bit of soft carbonation, just a touch thin.

Drinkability/notes: A pleasant and accessible example of the style, a suitable and pleasing choice for the first full day of autumn.

Presentation: Packaged in a twelve-ounce brown glass long neck bottle with a screw-off crown, served in a La Fin Du Monde tulip.

Oktoberfest brewing season is one of my favorites. The Marzen chase is on; this year I found my new favorite Oktoberfest Brew with Yuengling’s Oktoberfest. The bread and butter seems to hit my tongue and stay there. I usually don’t hoard things, but forget it. I bought a full case.

Poured into a clear pint glass. The pour was a deep golden color with a haze. The head was about an inch thick of a white color that thinned out quickly. The taste to me was good. Overall, this was definitely one I'd drink again.

Pours a gorgeous copper color that is perfectly clear and sports a creamy off white head. Nice caramel and grassy notes on the nose.

The caramel is forward on the taste, with a bit of grass on the back of the palate, leading to a crisp mouthfeel that works really well.

Look: Dark copper, beige head, not much retention.
Smell: Lagerish, mineraly, slight sulfur, a little sweet breadiness.
Taste: What a disappointment, taste like regular Yuengling that they doctored up to taste a little like a Marzen.
Avoid
If you think this is a good Oktoberfest marzen beer. You’re crazy. This tastes almost the same as a regular Yeungling. Not bad at all, but not a go to Marzen.

Bought a bottle of this beer on a whim this weekend.

Poured from a bottle into a tulip glass. Golden amber color with a good initial head and good lacing. Light caramel smell and taste. Bready and overall malty. Just not as flavorful and full bodied as I would like. My wife liked it with our dinner this evening.

poured directly into 500 ml P.U. handle mug. half beer/half head to the top. gorgeous color, almost red if not red. pillowly lasting bone off white head. tastes clean and could easily chug this. the best product they are offering at the moment in my opinion and it's stayed consistent for the short time period its been produced. hopefully doesn't go the way of their once upon a time offered summer wheat.

Absolutely exceptional beer, Yuengling has done it yet again. The absolute most American beer out there and fantastic twists on variations at an exceptionally reasonable price. If you have not tried this, then you should probably be going to the store right now.

Doesn't taste like much but I had tempered expectations on this one considering the source. Overall not bad. Kind of in the Sam Adam's tier for me so it'll be years before I give this another shot. It's cheap beer and that's what you're getting. You already know this isn't the same as other Marzens

12oz bottle
Glass: 0.4L Fest Mug
Temp at Pour: mid 50s F


Look:
Nice clear copper color with a 3" off-white head. The head dissipates to a thin cover rather quickly and then dissolves. Lacing is excellent down the sides of the glass.

Smell:
Lightly toasted bread and grains. Light hops. There is a sweet almost caramelly note. Some esters.

Taste:
Bread dough. Caramel. Surprising but not overpowering hop bite that tamps down the sweetness and keeps things from getting cloying. Finishes dry but a tad sweet.

Feel:
A bit watery. Body is on the thin side of medium.

Overall:
An OK Oktoberfest/Marzen. Very easy to drink. A credible effort by 'America's Oldest Brewery'. I would have this again.
Very dark amber pour, has a dirty smell. Lacing is nothing to talk about either is the foamy head. It’s okay the beer nothing horrible but definitely not good.

Picked up a single from TW Greenville, SC 9-8-21 for $1.49. No visible bottling date; consumed 10-31-21.

Beer poured an orange brown with a smaller white head.

Nose is a toasted malt base with hints of noble hops.

Taste is a mild toasted malt base that is balanced by the noble hops and not sweet in the finish but lacks the zing a good marten finishes with.

Mouthfeel is light bodied and lacks the style crispness.

Overall not a bad beer but nothing special in the beer field marten field.

Poured an orange-tinted golden body with decent head that quickly dies without leftover lace. Smell is basically some dirty, floral hops and a touch of "lagerness". Smooth, easy to drink, not much in the flavor department, just a bit of earthy hoppiness with a dry finish that is balanced with a decent maltiness (a light to medium body). It's not bad, and it's cheap, so nothing special but you could do worse in the oktoberfest beer department.

Poured from a non-freshness dated 12 oz. bottle: this is quite an attractive pour with a bright, deep golden to amber/copper hue with a sustained, off-white, and foamy head.

One thing was quite noticeable in the aroma: this one has an almost syrupy-sweet aroma, unlike the other Oktoberfest beers I have tried this season.

The beer is quite sweet with some surprising bitterness that balances the malt and keeps this one from drifting into cloying territory. It is a very flavorful beer, but it is really not an Oktoberfest in the classic sense - it comes across as a hyped-up version of Yuengling's "Traditional Lager" which is bad as I quite enjoy that one. The mouthfeel is slightly chewy with a short-lived, clean aftertaste. Again, no my idea of a festbier but still enjoyable.

From the bottle, it pours a clear amber color with a modest off-white head that soon diminishes to anice ring and leaves a little lacing. Roasted malt in the nose, Roasted malts in the mouth with a touch of caramel.

Pours a dark, but crystal clear, amber color. Thick, three finger, tan head forms on the beer, lingers, then dissolves.

Aroma has notes of nutty malts, caramel, some light bready notes, a touch of spicy hops, and a slight fruity, estery note,

Taste has notes of bready malts, a touch of caramel, a light nuttiness with a mild sweetness that has some brown sugar and caramel notes.

Feel is light, a tad watery, but easy drinking. Moderate carbonation. Drier finish.

Overall this is a solidly mediocre oktoberfest that is more enjoyable to drink than my review/rating would imply.

See through and copper colored with a thinning offwhite head, looks decent for the style. Sweet malt on the nose with some ‘Saz’ type hops in the back, going pretty well so far. Not bad, a bit light on the flavor but a long bready finish with some slight bite is what I like most about this beer. As far as this brewery goes, this offering is fairly decent. Medium body with above average carbonation. Good.

12 ounce bottle poured into a dimpled mug.

Clear, orangish amber and wearing a three quarter inch khaki cap, it looks like a good marzen. The aroma is light but nice. mostly bread and to a lesser degree, caramel malt with a whiff of spicy hop aroma. Taste is much the same but flavor is restrained and seems overly attenuated. Body is on the light side of medium with medium high carbonation. I find this one rather dry and crisp for style, though a decent enough drinking beer.

Dark amber, totally clear, frothy light brown head that dissipates quickly. Smell is toasted grain with some metallic notes. Taste brings in sweet molasses. Pretty light and easy drinking--it gets the job done decently well for its price point.

Poured into a tall clear pint glass. Appearance is a dark copper body with less than a finger's worth of beige head with small retention and decent lacing.

Aroma: caramel, fresh bread and toast, toasted malts, orange peel, honey, nuts, grain, and pears.

Tasting mostly grain, bread/toast, toasted malts, the nuts, honey, and caramel the best. Body is medium-light.

12oz can filled 7/27/22 into a 12oz mug.
L: Pours almost transparent pure caramel with 1/4" frothy white head, good retention, good carbonation, random spotty lacing.
S: Caramelized malts, lightly bready, earthy, a hint of berries, light melon.
T: Sweet caramelized malts-almost candied, honey, a slight & bright firm hop bite, fruity, some citrus & citrus zest, full flavored, moderately zesty & hoppy. Sentimental & inviting malts return in the finish. It's a wee bit tart.
F: Semi-juicy, smooth, med-full bodied with quite a bit of volume and a med-length moderately drying finish. Overall fairly clean.
O: A mildly assertive and somewhat fruity Oktobier. Flavors are full & strong, fairly hoppy, floral and caramely. It is lightly sweet on the lips and it is excellent in it's style.

2022 Review: They may have changed the recipe this year to a more malty version, but it's definitely not as good as their original Oktoberfest. This one used to be great! (2022 Rating: 3.71)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Appearance: Pours a clear, but bright orange color that resembles fire. A strong white head. SRM of 13. (4.00)

Aroma: Moderate aromas of earthy honey, flower, bread, grass and lemonflower. A predominately honeyflower component. (4.00)

Flavor: Holy Honey! Follows with a strong earthy honey and a sweet white bread component. Some light grass & flower on the end, but finishes with a glazed honey sweetness. More pale rather than caramel malts. Not dry. Pale and sweet witha slightly flowery finish. (4.25)

Feel: Medium-bodied. Low to moderate carbonation. Finishes sweet and leaves a smooth honey consistency on the palate. (3.75)

Compared to Breckenridge Brewery's Oktoberfest 2020, 10/11/20: Pours a lighter, more orange color. Milder aromas. Aroma/flavor has more earthy honey. Less caramel and toastiness. More honey smoothness and less bitter.

Compared to Paulaner Oktoberfest 2020 10/28/20: Pours a lighter, less bronze color. More honey/flowery aromas. Less authentic German bread malt. More lemoflower.

Compared to Great Lakes Dortmund Gold 11/8/20: Pours a similar color. Stronger lemon, German white bread on the aroma. Less earthy and resinous honey and forest floor. More Munich malt and bready flavors and less honey. Similar sweetness, but more pale. Similar to Dortmund, but more bready. Overall, extremely similar.

Compared to Bells' Oktoberfest 9/6/21: Pours slightly lighter. More honey and lemonflower. Less toasty and bread malts. Hoppier and lighter, but stronger flavor.

Compared to Pearl Street Lederhosen Lager 9/17/21: Pours an identical color. Similar aromas. Slightly more honey and lemonflower. Less orange and toasty/bready malts. Silghtly more pale, but more similar than I expected.

Compared to Utepils Receptional Oktoberfest 11/14/21: Larger head, similar color. More citrus and flower upfront. Less toasted bread malt. More toasted pine and caramel on the finish. Winner: Surly
9/12/22: Larger head. More bread and floral notes. Less citrus spice. Slightly dryer and cleaner. Similar.

to LiftBridge Oktoberefst 11/21/21: Pours a lighter color with a stronger head. More orange/citrus and honey. Less toasted bread malt and bread.

to SN Oktoberfest 2020: Pours a lighter color. More rich and sweet bready flavors. Less oxidized pine and caramel.

to Sierra Nevada Oktoberfest 2021 12/15/21: Pours a lighter and clearer color. Stronger aromas. More hoppy orange, lemon, flower. Less caramel malt. Less oxidation. Winner: Surly.

to Ayinger Oktoberfest Marzen 4/26/22: Pours a lighter color, stronger head. Similar aromas. More lemonflower and sweet biscuit malt.

to Utepils Pils 6/22/22: Darker but similar smooth honey malt flavors.

to Fulton Festbier 9/7/22: Pours slightly lighter, milder aromas. More bread malts, yeast, carbonation. Less sweet honey. More carbonation and dryer.

to Oliphant Festbier 9/16/22: Pours a lighter color. Similar aromas. More smooth honey and flower. Less bread crust, toast, and caramel.

to Earth Rider Festbier 9/16/22: Pours a darker color. Milder aromas. More smooth, sweet honey and golden malt. Less honeyflower and citrus notes. Heavier and sweeter. Winner: Earth Rider

Overall: Quite a good Oktoberfest lager. Classic Surly Lemonflower hop and yeast flavors with sweet honey here. A more pale and traditional festbier, on par with the festbier style rather than Americanized Marzen. Almost drinks similar to a Dortmund Gold or Surly Hell on a bit of steroids. A fantastic beer here and I'm glad Surly went with a traditional festbier style this time. (Final Rating: 4.13)
2022 Update: This one really fell off this year. Lots of sweet honey, but the rest of the components are not there.

12oz can. Poured out a clear, golden orange color with a small, off-white head of foam. It left sudsy trails of lace on the glass. It smelled of biscuity malt, caramel, toffee and floral notes. Sweet toffee taste with caramel toasted malt and a mild bitterness.

This is a solid Oktoberfest, nothing remarkable but well made and nicely balanced. At 6% it's just a touch high for the style, but I suppose that's more a nod to American style than what you'd get in Germany. I'd try other beers from this brewery if I see them in my area.

Oktoberfest pours a clean amber color, with a long lasting larger head. Aroma is a tad weak, but a nice spice. Flavor is dry, lots of autumn like spices, not strong, just enjoyable. Good body and feel. Overall, very nice and solid beer, very drinkable.

Can. White head with lace. Clear bronze color.

First fest beer of the season and it didn’t disappoint. Malty. Bready, toffee, biscuit, caramel. Earthy and spicy hops. Even a faint bitterness in the finish. Really solid. Good job surly.

Too hoppy for the style.
Too fruity, tastes more like a pale ale than a lager.
In my opinion, there are way better options in this style out there.
It was good to try, but wouldn't seek it out again.
The 6.5% alc is a plus.
What is it with American breweries hopping the shit out of European beer styles?
Stop it!

12oz can into a pint glass. Canned 8/16/21, so 3 months old.

Looking very nice in the glass. Slightly hazy pale golden yellow body. Small white head shrinks to a fat ring and covering, leaves rings of lacing.

Aroma is on the floral side, nicely malty.

On tasting though, it's more on the fruity side of things. Light hoppiness still present. Quite sweet as well. A little drying right at the end.

Mouth above medium, a little sharp. Finish a drying light bitterness.

Overall, pretty nice festbier. Would be interesting to try a fresher one to see if the usual Surly hop profile overwhelms. As it stands though, a tasty sessionable fall beer.

Bought in one of two Binny's Pick Six, conveniently putting O-fests on three shelves for my easy preparation for the BA three week O-Fest thread. (Of which I made three entries and, generally, thought it worthwhile to study my O-Fest habit.)

Surly is a third generation crafter (basically, those that got their start in this century's first decade) that specializes in using hops, too many for my malt-head mouth. So I am not surprised that Surly's marzen is, well, hoppy for this malty style. Probably only in its third release, I'd hope (but don't expect) its fourth release will use hops to achieve balance instead of prominence.

From a 12oz can:

Appearance: Clear gold, good head.

Smell: Mild sweetness, toast.

Taste: Very tasty combination of sweetened bread and light grassy hops. A good drinker, easy to have a few.

Overall: Been on a Octoberfest kick, so picked up a 12 pack of Surly's version. I don't think it's a marzen, more of a weisn. Nice sweetness balanced by a grassy hop that is not too much for the style.

The pour is copper colored with a steady flow of carbonation. The taste is brown bread crust & caramel. This was not a bold tasting Oktoberfest beer but it was not that bad & quite session able. Cheers!

12 oz can poured into ein Stiefel (glass boot)

Three finger solid rocky big bubbled foam cap crowning a clear golden liquid with lazy streams of carbonation, good retention

Aroma is bready, malty, grassy

Taste is bready, slight sweet, slight nutty finish

Low sudsing, clean, crisp, ever so gentle hop nibble dries the tongue

Good beer

12oz can. Can bottom is stamped 'CANNED ON 07/21/21'.
Mostly clear, deep gold colored body. One finger of white, tiny bubble head, which persists. Leaves rings of lacing on the non-drinking side.
Aroma of toasted malts. Grassy hops.
Taste is is light caramel, grassy and mildly spicy hops. Slight fusel. Dry in the aftertaste with the malts.
Medium mouth feel. Very good carbonation.
Slightly sweet and balanced. Would work for a session beer.

Pours from can a holden yellow, 1" head with a moderate ring that hangs around. nose is a bit of corn, sweet malts, and as it warms, a whiff of alcohol. Taste is on the sweet side (lighter, more reminiscent of sweet corn) and without much grain character. Mouthfeel is thin but with a refreshing carbonation.
12 oz can pours a glowing orange-amber color, foamy white head. Soft roasted malt aroma, starts sweet, some flavors of toffee and caramel, medium body, Not bad for the style.

Clear, pale amber hue, slim white head.

In the nose: Cool and malty. Noble hops, with a floral touch. Slightly spicy.

In the mouth: Clear and crisp, with a zesty edge. Earthy malt flavors, boards the palate and hangs out at the back. Twist of fruit, kiss of hops, rich and malty turning clean and refreshing. Ends on a lightly dry note, a bready finish. Just enough malty flavors meets just enough easy-drinking to keep the celebration going.

Do I like it better than the beer it replaced, SurlyFest, which was not in the least a traditional märzen? No. SurlyFest was too unique and special not to love. Do I like it more than other Oktoberfests? It falls squarely in the middle. Short answer: good märzen and you can drink it. Nothing wrong with that. Nothing great about it, either.

Pours medium gold and chill hazed.

Mild caramel malt and grassy hop with a touch of bready yeast.

The flavors are similar. Well balanced sweetness and hops but very mild.

Great feel and weight. Very drinkable.

I’ve seen more domestic fests this year. Like many this one is ok. But nothing more.

Clear amber body, cream head. Smell is pretty basic but solid: caramel malts, toast and slight brown bread, faint. Taste is pretty much the same, more caramel forward than anything. Body is malty yet light, crispness lacking, just a generic feel for a oktoberfest. Not bad beer, no glaring weakness just bland

Pours a mostly clear copper color.Smell of baked bread spice and malts,thou light . Taste is same as smell with everything light, it is still tasty would have liked more hops,malt and spice. I miss Surlyfest.

Deep gold with excellent clarity; one finger of white head; good cap retention, solid ring; sudsy lacing; excellent streaming carbonation. Nose is lightly toasted malt; also a very light spicy hop presence. Taste is lightly toasted malt; a scōsh of hop bitterness; more baked bread and very little sweetness. Medium body, moderate minus carbonation; no warmth from 6% abv; very light creaminess in the feel. Overall I liked this fest bier more than the German (HB) just drank; Surly was less sweet and very drinkable.

12-oz.can (Canned on 8/13/20) into a 16-oz. mug. A moderately strong pour yields a finger of creamy light beige foam with long retention and spots of lace. Clear amber-straw color, yellow-gold in sunlight.

Bready malt, toast, dough and cracker greet the nose with very faint floral hops.

Neutral taste with low bitterness, toasted malt shines. Apple, attempting to be sweet is the only taste other than malt and faint hops. Cracker and toasted malt stand out over bread and dough. The finish is quick, crisp and clean and on the dry side. Bitterness builds to average during the lingering aftertaste.

Medium light bodied and perfectly carbonated. Alcohol is very well hidden. Smooth and session-able, balanced and true to style. Not as dark and sweet as Beers labeled Marzens, not as hoppy as many Festbier. Right in the middle.

A: The beer is crystal clear yellowish amber in color and has a light amount of visible carbonation. It poured with a narrow collar of white bubbles and some specks of bubbles on the surface.
S: Light to moderate aromas of toasted malts are present in the smell along with hints of spicy hops.
T: The taste follows the smell and has flavors of toasted malts along with a bit of associated sweetness and faint hints of spicy hops.
M: It feels nearly medium-bodied and very clean on the palate with a moderate amount of carbonation.
O: I liked the aromas and flavors of toasted malts in this Oktoberfest, which seemed a little lighter in body and easier to drink compared to other beers in the style.

Serving type: can

Bottled on: 4-25-22

A - Pitch black pour with a soliud layer of creamy caramel colored foam.

S - Chocolate char, oak, Bourbon, and some light vanilla on the nose.

T - Big chocolate roast with some char, Bourbon, vanilla, and oak. There's a big lingering oak/Bourbon presence after the sip with a little bit of chocolate char in the mix. (There's a tad bit of cherry poking through as well.)

M - Medium body with a little bit of thinness around the edges and some alcohol warming in the back of the throat on the first few sips.

O - Needs a little more chocolate roast and less Bourbon presence.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter
Appearance – The beer ours a deep brown, nearly black color with a one finger head of brown foam. The thickness of the brew can be seen when swirling the beer in the glass. Thick sticky fingers of beer cling to the sides of the glass upon swirling, with the slowly receding to the bottom of the snifter. The head that was present upon pouring fades rather fast, leaving a light level of lace on the sides of the glass.
Smell – The aroma is massive of a rich roasted and toasted malt smell that is accompanied by tons of chocolate and sweet caramel and molasses. Along with these aromas comes a nice bourbon and woody smell that has notes of leather and smoke mixed within. Other sweeter smells of prune and plum as well as a good showing of vanilla.
Taste – The taste starts out with a semi sweet cocoa and heavily roasted and toasted malt flavor. The sweet upfront is mainly of the brown sugar and molasses nature but has a little bit of a dark fruit flavor of raisin and prune. There is a nice presence of a smooth vanilla flavor as well, that compliments the sweet rather nicely. Right from the start, the bourbon and oak can be appreciated as well, both of which get stronger as the taste advances forward on the tongue. Along with the bourbon getting stronger, so too comes a bit of bitter coffee and some char flavors. At the end the bourbon, oak, and char surge and are accompanied by a bit of leather, leaving one with a nice rich, not too sweet, but nice and warming taste to linger on the tongue.
Mouthfeel – The body of the brew is thick and creamy with a carbonation level that is low. For the mix of dark, roast, booze, and sweet the feel is great and makes for one nice pleasant sipper.
Overall – A rather nice bourbon barrel aged stout. Rather balanced, as it is not too heavy in any one of its flavor attributes. Overall, very nice.

Its quite odd to see a barrel-aged series beer from Avery to be so light, ordinary and normal. Simply an Imperial Stout aged for only six months in those barrels, this mere 12.7% stout shows quite the restraint.

Very dark brown and flirting with blackness, Imperialis kicks off with a light tan skirt of froth. With a roasty, toasty, spicy and cola-like scent, the beer's aromatics hinge on chocolate, booze soaked oak, dark fruit, vanilla and caramel. Similarly in taste, its early impressions are robust and sweet with caramel, vanilla, toasted coconut, chocolate and dry molasses.

The spices quickly take over the sweetness as the dark ale embarks upon the middle palate. Malt dominance dries to a coffee, cocoa and cola nut character for a taste that backs off of the heavy and robust char of espresso or campfire. Moderately bitter in a late and woodsy impression, the oak tannins and booze flavors leave a late taste of vanilla, cola, roasted red grape and lacquer on the tongue.

Full bodied but not as heavy as those that we have become accustomed, there's a relaxed sense of drinkability that comes with the slightly lackluster stout. Finishing nutty, spicy and with a long Kona-like coffee flavor, the ale is basically a beer's version of affogato in a glass.

bottled 4/25/22. drank 8/13/22
Pour is black with about a finger of khaki head. decent retention. fades to a little cap on the glass. Some lacing.
Nose is cocoa, oak, vanilla,
Taste follows. chocolate, vanilla, coffee, fudge, subtle bourbon becomes more pronounced as the beer warms, a bit of roasted malt. light alcohol heat. Hint of dark stone fruit? Cherry?

Not my favorite Avery stout, but a good bargain and about what I expected for the price. The nearly black color and brown foam is quite enticing. The taste is mostly oaken bourbon and vanilla and cherry, with roasted malts and char, ethanol, slight sweetness, and a hint of chocolate. Its a bit boozy and has some rough edges. Addition of something like cherries or chocolate would probably take this over the top, but as is it is quite nice and grows on you as you drink it.

Deep, dark brown body, opaque; thick and densely spongy head, light khaki color; thick, sticky sheets of foam curtain the glass. Rich, dark chocolate and cocoa aroma; very light char note. Rich dark malt flavor; baker's and milk chocolate plus cocoa; bold whiskey presence; low bitterness; moderate alcohol phenol presence; very light oak note. Heavy mouthfeel yet soft and velvety on the palate; huge boozy heat offsets the residual sugars.

This is a very likeable barrel aged imperial stout. The base beer is righteous while the bourbon barrel character cuts through like a healthy neat shot of your favorite straight whiskey. Maybe a little hot on the palate, but I'm thinking some judicious bottle aging will mellow this one out for the better.

Pouring temperature: 51 °F; bottling data: APR 25 2022

Poured at fridge temp into my SBG glass, it's a cola-esque light/deep brown and settles into dark black..like every good stout.
Smell and taste is delicious cacao, coffee, perfect barrel to base taste ratio, vanilla,oak, dark fruit and dark malts. All this comes together very well and i hope they do more of these 20 dollar 4 packs.
I love this beer . I'll keep buying this over and over.
This is a single i got for 5 dollars, still have 2 from the 4 pack i purchased last week.

Another winner from Avery

L: Deep mahogany body with a small khaki head.

S: Pumpkin pie— nutmeg, clove, vanilla. Also picking up some Hefeweizen-esque notes of banana bread and bubblegum

T: Cinnamon dominates. Sweet potato/pumpkin, light vanilla.

F: Full bodied

O: I don’t like pumpkin beers, but this one is above average. The taste just doesn’t live up to the nose and is too heavy on the cinnamon. I think this would benefit from letting the bready malt qualities shine through.

One of the best Pumpkin Beers!!!! I poured this from a 12 oz can into a pint glass. Features a beautiful very slightly hazy amber color and a big frothy light tan/off white head. Good head retention and lacing on the glass. Avery good looking beer. The aroma and flavor are malty (rich caramel malt) with a lot of fresh pumpkin and a well controlled amount of pumpkin spices. Cinnamon is the lead spice, but there is nothing over the top!!! Very tasty beer. Mouthfeel is rich, slightly sweet and as smooth as you could expect from a beer that weighs in at 8.80% .abv!!!! Another winner from Cigar City!!!!

Canned on 8-1-22. 12oz can poured into a tulip.

Pours a glowing auburn with some haze; fluffy light khaki head that falls leaving solid retention and lacing.

The aromas have some interesting Belgian characteristics leading the way. Some banana and bubblegum coming through which I wasn't expecting. Some caramel. Some veggies. Not much pumpkin spice going on. Malts are there.

The flavors are pretty unique and bolder than the nose. Some cinnamon sugar coming through. More banana and bubblegum. More caramel along with some hints of cocoa. Some sweet potatoes. There's a pretty solid earthiness and bitterness to this one. Decent sweetness. Solid malt backbone. Mild warmth in the finish, but the alcohol is ultimately well hidden.

Mouthfeel is full-bodied with moderate carbonation. It's thick, fluffy, creamy, and slightly sharp.

This is truly a unique pumpkin ale. I'm not sure that I've ever had one quite like it. I can understand why this is a beloved pumpkin ale.

Mouthfeel

Poured out of a 12 oz. can dated 08/01/22. Sampled Sept. 4, 2022.

Attractive reddish-amber appearance underneath a modest. fading off-white to light tan head.

I pick up a lot of cinnamon and nutmeg on the nose with a much lower bread and biscuit profile. Some herbal notes like sage. No booze.

The mouthfeel is smooth and well into the medium range.

Overall, the flavor is sweet, vaguely malty but burning with cinnamon and nutmeg right up to the finish. Booze isn't so bad.

Cigar City brews have never blown me away but this one is a notch above their other offerings.

12 oz can.

Pours a clear deep copper color with a finger of frothy khaki head. Good retention. Leaves a nice ring of lacing.

Has strong aromas of cloves and cinnamon, with plenty of notes of nutmeg, freshly baked pumpkin pie and caramel malts.

The flavor follows the nose: Lots of cinnamon and clove up front, followed by notes of nutmeg, squash, pumpkin pie, and caramel.

The feel is full bodied with soft carbonation. Creamy and very smooth. The alcohol is extremely well-hidden.

Overall, definitely one of, if not the best example of a pumpkin ale I've had to date. All the spices mix well together and create a beer that is very nicely balanced. This one is definitely a sipper.
If you are a fan of pumpkin beer this one hits the spot. Pours a solid golden orange and taste like squash and pumpkin pie. Perfect mouthfeel and carb.

Pumpkin beers used to be something I was into but the allure faded fast. That being said this is about as good a pumpkin beer as you could expect. Nice high ABV, good body, nice spices, and solid flavor. It's a sip on a cool evening beer and for that it's great. yb

From a can, it pours very dark with a nice foamy head. Nice pumpkin/yam aroma with hints of cinnamon and nutmeg. The taste is overwhelmingly cinnamon with a malty backup. Very heavy with the cinnamon and nutmeg continuing to linger. Not a great example of this style.

I just had the Saint Arnold Pumpkinator a few days ago and this concoction by Cigar City sits right behind that gem at #2. I think that ranking is fair. This brew is interesting with the cloves, cinnamon, vanilla and all spice creating a beautiful medley for the pumpkin to nestle into. This is an 8.5 ABV beer which hides it very well. I like this beer a lot. It is complex and has a much greater depth than most pumpkin beers. Cigar city is a fine brewery and they hit this one on the mark! Happy Thanksgiving to me!

Poured from a 12 oz. can, which says 8.8% abv. Has a pretty auburn color with a 1/2 inch head. Smell is mild, some pumpkin. Taste is of pumpkin, subtle spices, some brown sugar, a touch of alcohol is present. Feels medium bodied in the mouth and overall it ain't bad, but I was expecting much more than it delivered.
Pours a copper color with a minimal head that disappears quickly. Aroma is a mixture of spices. Taste is like a spiced pumpkin pie and is quite boozy. Different than most pumpkin beers out there.

DATE: November 8, 2020... OCCASION: wrapping up a great four-day weekend with a beer I have hoped to taste for a while now--great to see Cigar City here up in Jersey... GLASSWARE: Maudite snifter... a foreboding, brownish purple body that shows lively bubbles swelling into an uneven haze of off-white head--this pumpkin looks like it has more of a Halloween attitude than one of Thanksgiving... rich punch of cinnamon, nutmeg, sharp brown sugar, candied clove and all spice evoke a dessert-like aroma.... not much in the way of maltiness suggested by its aroma... first sip is rich, creamy, buzzing at the teeth and the throat, with a boozy finish that lingers warmly... in fact, it stays so long between sips, it seems like one long drink, commanding with a whiskey's confidence but drawing without heat or penalty.... what a beautiful experience this is--the cinnamon and nutmeg explode atop a brown ale's malty base, with clove and light citrus also in the mix... in fact, the late citrus makes this almost read as a whiskey with bitters... big, bold but accessible, I will look for this again next year, and appreciate having CC in Northeastern distribution--this works quite well as a holiday dessertif or a nightcap....

My can reads 8.8% ABV, for whatever that's worth. Pours dark red with a rather large tannish head which laces up nicely as it recedes. Looks pretty nice. Smells of lightly singed brown sugar, booze, gourd (duh!) and the requisite spices, none of which particularly stand out. They're all there, though: cinnamon, nutmeg, clove, allspice and cumin (I kid). Tastes quite delightful, if mildly boozy. I mean, this is a hacky thing to say, but it's pumpkin pie in liquid form. I taste some vanilla, too. Don't know if that's listed as an ingredient, but it's definitely there on the tongue. The spices kind of linger a bit; perhaps too long. Your mileage will certainly vary. Pretty well full-bodied with a dry finish. I'm less crazy about this style with every passing year, but I like this one quite a bit.

Absolutely terrific pumpkin ale...Schlafly is the standard bearer but this is really good...

Lots of pumpkin pie spice without being annoying about it...it tastes like a good slice of pumpkin pie...and as far as I'm concerned that's is a good thing.

Creamy and smooth...terrific finish...not boozy at all...

I will grab some of this for Thanksgiving....

Canned on 7/13/20

Pours a deep maroon-mahogany body with just a touch of clarity and topped with a finger of rocky, semi-creamy foam; great head retention recedes slowly to some spotty islands of cap, a firm, creamy ring of collar, and a comprehensive, webbed array of lacing clinging across the glass.

Aroma features a quieted, raw boozy aspect introducing more subdued seasonal notes; soft pie spice, fleeting sense of roasted cloves, squash, allspice, and vanilla for a thinly veiled sweeter quality; light tones of pumpkin comes in waves, balanced by brown sugar into the close.

Taste opens a touch bready, with hints of caramel reinforcing a light malt profile as notes of squash/pumpkin chunks and brown sugar become increasingly prominent over the mid-palate, while nutmeg and cinnamon fade with a boozy finish.

Mouthfeel offers a medium body with an expansive, rounded carbonation trending slick across the mid-palate and with a crispness that tingles into the back end; a smooth yet weighty finish highlights a minor pang of booziness and distant vegetal acridity that had been advancing across the palate, though in pleasant synchronicity with the beer's softer elements.

There's extensive balance beneath the subdued profile and overarching booziness, but not quite prominent enough to see this one through; a roller coaster of a pumpkin ale, with heavy promise but a contrastingly weaker execution leaving a drinkable though unimpressive final impression.

a: rich, dark cherry and brown color with hints of dark amber and mahogany. pours a nice frothy solid 2 finger tan head that settles around 1/2 finger

s: pumpkin & squash aroma upfront. cinnamon, clove, coriander, sweet potato. some vanilla, pie crust, and pumpkin pie filling. some nice brown sugar in here as well

t: tons of brown sugar, pie crust, cinnamon, clove, and cardamom in here. extremely rich. brown sugar, pumpkin & squash meat. pumpkin pie filling. lots of nutmeg

m: fuller side of medium. carbonation is medium

o: a very nice Pumpkin Ale. it's pie-like, but not overly sweet or spicy. very rich, yet not tough to drink. really good stuff, could use a bit more out of the aroma though

Four ounces served from an can into an Erdinger Oktoberfest stein during my second decennial pumpkin beer tasting.

Banana and assorted pumpkin spice nose. Long coffee finish with that signature Cigar City heavy mouthfeel of their Imperial beers. Balanced sweetness to scale with the imperial concept.

Ths is a super pumpkin ale I sampled first last night with my brother outside on my parent's porch until the wee hours. Obviously the beer was delicious,as my brother had promised it would be. I am rewinding tonight with the one surviving beer.

For me, the spices hit more or less perfectly, the cinammon and nutmeg staying on your tongue well into theftertaste. The rest is incredibly complimentiary, understated, and balanced. The bright, satisfying maltiness is only elevated by the pumpkin flavors. This doesn't mash you on the head with heavy sweetness and become riddled with booze flavors like some of the better, more "traditional" pumpkins. Hard to believe its packing so much alcohol. Just outstanding.

Upon pouring, my first thought is, this beer is perfectly coordinated with the can as if they were wearing matching outfits. The tan head with etchings of tawny mimics the top of the can. The liquid itself, however, is more cinnamon/copper than anything close to a vibrant orange. I'd call it syrupy looking maintaining a certain seasonality.

What makes one pumpkin pie better than the others? Crust, spice mix, sweeteners, binding agents, quality of pumpkin. First thought on aroma, this doesn't remind me of a pie. More like a pumpkin cake (your typical muffin nowadays) with a brown sugar/butter/cinnamon streusel top. More like a pumpkin crumb cake I'd have with a cup of coffee in the morning.

Will the taste depart from the brown sugar/cinnamon? Somewhat. Brown sugar is the main sweet element. Pumpkin is there, and helped by a hopping with subtle notes of citrus, black pepper and nutmeg. Tastes a little like raw pumpkin smells...a bit bitter. Coffee grounds, clementine, lavender. If that doesn't sell you...it ends up tasting down a like a slightly watered down Captain Morgan Black with a dollop of pumpkin cream; so, really outstanding in terms of a pumpkin beer.

Medium body with a little chewiness in the middle. Rather dense impression followed swiftly by tart elderberry.

Excited to try this highly rated beer. Deep copper see through color to this brew with a good sized tan head. Head fading quickly but a nice look none the less. Initial nose is sweet with some pumpkin and related spices. A further scent of the can really brings out a rich deep nose. Ok, really like the balance and smoothness of this brew. The evenness allows the spices to take center stage before the bite pulls it away with a drying finish. This slightly vanilla sweet yet bitter brew has a medium body and enough carbonation to keep me happy. I’ve got to admit, this stuff is pretty good here.

I was a bit disappointed by this beer which has excellent reviews.

There is definitely the pumpkin flavor, the spice, nutmeg and cinnamon in the taste profile.

None of the flavors are pronounced. There isn’t a richness of flavor I’ve experienced in other pumpkin beers- especially Pumking.

Excellent beer, but not a standout in the style for me.

I am a huge pumpkin fan, and am having trouble finding some familiar favorites in this Covid-plagued year. So, knowing Cigar Citys' reputation, I bought a case of Good Gourd, without even tasting it. This beer met my expectations.. a great purchase! It pours a gourgeous, dark copper, with a bit more head than your average pumpkin. The carbonation level was ample.. the taste, wonderful. The tyical autumn spices are all there, and they are proportioned superbly. They create a slightly bitter presence, which is nicely offset by a noticeable vanilla sweetness, which forms a distinctly sweet caramel note. There is nothing rashly scientific or groundbreaking here.. simply a blend of fine ingredients woven together by a brewer that works their craft superbly. This is a great addition to my yearly pumpkin haul, and I strongly urge you to giver it a try!

Appearance - Pours a golden amber with three fingers of bubbly white head.

Smell - citrus, earthy, piney, and floral hops, grapefruit and citrus peel, lemon, bready malts, caramel, and earthy yeast.

Taste - citrus, earthy, piney, and floral hops upfront although it's predominately citrus and piney hops, bitter pine resin and grapefruit and citrus peel come through next. The lemon is there but is overpowered by the hops. The bready malts, caramel, and earthy yeast round out the brew.

Mouthfeel - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Finishes sticky with the pine resin and grapefruit peel lingering.

Overall - A solid example of a true West Coast IPA. The pine resin and hops are spot on in this one and the ABV is well hidden. A pleasant recommendation from Stacey; one of the owners of Collective here in Cowtown!

Appearance: Pours a golden color with pale hues when held up to the light. Medium to high carbonation, with a thick white foam head.

Aroma: fresh citric hops. Lemon and grapefruit. Lemongrass, and some caramel malts.

Taste: A bitter punch of citrus peel up front. Some piney Notes, and grapefruit in the back. The finish is not exactly clean but it doesn't linger too long either. Simple and well balanced.

Overall: this is a nice, clean, simple brew of commendable quality. I found it to be quite refreshing and enjoyable. It is significantly drinkable, despite the bitterness.. which I actually find to be pleasing on the palate. This is my first run with this beer, and it's definitely not gonna be the last.

Clear amber color wsith a decent foamy white head that retains well and produces some nice lacing.
The aroma is lemon and grapefruit with some hint of caramel malt.
The taste is lemon and grapefruit with caramel malt and a dry lingering pine resin finish.
The body is medium, moderate carbonation, smoothly drinkable.
Altogether this is a really enjoyable example of IPA, the lemon gives an extra nice kick, a good level of bitterness to make you want more.

19.2 oz can purchased from American Market ( used to be Capital Market) in Salem OR.
$3.49
Pours a semi darker golden colour with a lovely thick and frothy white head.
Aroma is hoppy. Mostly citrus/grapefruit. Simple and clean.
Taste also bitter..but its like a bitter orange creamsicle thing..very good.
Mouth feel is medium with medium to high carbonation..giving a rather "brisk" drinkable feel. Nice. Clean .
Really nice citrus IPA

Oh no, a gluten-free beer? Ugh totally didn't notice that on this 19.2oz can. Pouring in a pint glass. Crystal clear and medium golden brass in color, with a nice white foam. Flavor is incredibly crisp with a pleasantly sharp citrus pith bite, evoking lemon and grapefruit. Beyond that flavor profile there's no additional bitterness, and it finishes remarkably clean considering. Malt body is vanishingly thin which is not a surprise for any number of reasons.

Dated 04/04/22 enjoy by 08/02/22.

Pours a golden amber in color with minimal head and lacing as you drink. Carbonation looks average. Reminiscent of a Stone IPA, but with less head.

Aroma is not overly pungent, perhaps I should let it warm a bit (the malts come through a bit more as it warms, but otherwise much of the same). Picking up notes of citrus and tropical fruits with some earthiness, spice and a hint of bubble gum in the background. Alcohol is slightly detectable at 7.7% ABV.

Flavor is very predominantly hops across the full spectrum. Starts off with a little bit of balance with the toasty, biscuity malts and quickly climaxes with a pine resin and grapefruit rind hop avalanche that coats the tongue. I'd imagine the malts are a bit subdued due to the gluten reduction process. This is certainly a palate wrecker, but it's pretty tasty.

Mouthfeel is on the heavier side of medium bodied with smooth, zesty carbonation and a ton of chewiness. She thicc. The hop oil definitely coats the tongue after the swallow. I would not want to drink more than a few of these for fear of a hangover, but I quite enjoy the mouthfeel otherwise.

Overall this is a powerfully hoppy, reduced gluten brew. If you're not into hops, this is definitely not for you, but if you are, it is has a very fresh and pungent hop flavor that is sure to please. I think I prefer the Stone IPA over this one, but I definitely wouldn't turn it down if offered. Even with the high hoppiness it feels pretty gentle on the stomach. Another good one from Stone, cheers!

A medium dark golden amber is immediately noticeable upon the pour. Medium sized head formed with some lacing remaining. This is definitely a lemony, citrusy IPA. It's more like a floral lemon than a grapefruit citrus, but it is noticeable bitter to the point of being resinous, as there is an IPA bite that is bitterly refreshing with a full bodied carbonated feel which borders on syrupiness. There is a noticeable lack of maltiness between the hopiness, which could be a result of the gluten reduction, but who knows. It's very boozy, you could feel the booze hit you on the first sip. Overall it was as described, but the lack of malt may have deprived some padding from bitterness. A purveyor of hops would enjoy. Bottled 9/27/21 and consumed on 4/14/22 with an "Enjoy By" of 1/25/22.

Canned 2/14, consumed 4/7/22. Nearly, but not perfectly, clear gold color, 3-finger initial head after vigorous pour into a tall tulip glass, giving way to a thin film, (lots of lacing in the most recent pour of Sept. 2022 canned on Aug 8 2022, but no real lacing when first sampled in April). Almost no detectable smell, perhaps some hoppy citrus. Very hoppy/ quite bitter, somewhat citrusy taste. Moderate body , clean finish. Overall a nice beer at the price point and a nice 12 oz can offering

L: Pours a clear orange, eggshell colored head fades quickly and leaves so,e nice Lacing.
S: Nose gets a bit of citrus.
T: Kind of a funky stale taste.
F: Thin and flat.
O: It says gluten reduced on the can, maybe that's why the flavor is off. I did not like this beer all.

LOOK: Pours a very hazy and very light orange with an all white head with good retention and side glass lace.
AROMA: Sour, lemon peel pine resin.
TASTE: Pine resin, quite sour to the point where the citrus notes take a back seat. Hop bitterness is strong. Very dank.
Didn't care for this one.

12oz can. Can bottom is stamped for canning date as '05/16/21' and best by date of '09/16/21', so canned about five months ago. We will see (bought at a single).
A little cloudy, pale gold colored body. Three fingers of white head upon pouring, which retreats to a partial cap. Leaves some short strings of lacing.
Aroma is quite malty sweet, with some orange citrus hops.
Taste is quite hop spicy, and the lemon candy flavor is somewhat there. Less malt expression in the taste than in the nose. A bit of bitterness in the aftertaste.
Medium mouth feel, with a dry finish. Good carbonation.
I get the gist of what the prime of this beer was, and based on that, the beer is kind of old school and resin enjoyable.

12oz can into a pint glass. Appears to have been canned in August 2022, best by February 2023.

Looks very good, glassy golden yellow body with a persistent white head leaving spotted lacing.

Light aroma, mild hop and malt notes.

On tasting, clean, crisp, faintly bitter.

Mouth medium, finish clean, no aftertaste at all.

Overall, easy drinking czech pilsner, paired with sweet and cracked pepper cheese, from the recent DFH 12 pack.

It's a beer. I tried the same brewery's 90 Minute IPA (an easy almost-all-fives beer) for the first time right before this one, so maybe the bar is just too high now, but this is... it's a beer. I feel much the same way about this as I do Blue Moon and all the Samuel Adams beers: It's by no means bad, I get why it's on the shelf, and it is what it says it is. But I find myself yearning for something more, and especially with Dogfish Head, I've come to expect something more.
Straw-colored with disappointing head and no lacing. Smells sweet, tastes sweet. Fruity, almost, but not quite- something in my head goes "strawberry?" but then goes "huh. no". No comment on the malt. It's there. More malt character would be nice. The flavor is fine, but one-dimensional, and then there's an indescribably funny aftertaste. I was hoping for layers, and I did not get them. Mouthfeel's a mixed bag. It's nicely carbonated. I wish it was lighter.
A very middling pilsner. I'll finish the can, but probably won't buy it again.
A very sessionable pilsner with nice malt character. Saaz hops provide flavor and a bit of balancing bitterness. This beer isn’t going to blow you away, but it is well crafted.

A: straw yellow with a lighter notes. Small white fizzy head. Could use a it more head

S: clean crisp grass, lemongrass, grains. A touch of sweet citrus, and some earthy hops. A bit more sweetness on the end. Nice aroma

T: a bit muted in comparison to the aroma. Some sweet grains and lemongrass. A touch of earthy hops and faint sweet lemon. Finish is clean, and sweet

M: light mouthfeel with strong carbonation

O: this one feels a bit below-average to me. A bit too sweet. Not bad but there are better

This beer pours a clear golden/amber color with a moderate head. It is quite effervescent with low head retention.

The aroma is very malty and sweet.

The taste is most notably malty and slightly bitter, with a hint of tropical fruit. Its smooth and refreshing with a pleasant aftertaste. The mouthfeel is a bit syrupy.
Poured out a golden color with a thin white head. Smells of malt and possibly barley. An okay beer and not one I would seek out over all the others out there.

been some time since i had a new dogfish head beer, this is a cool pils, done with delaware grain, not sure i knew that was a thing. its a pretty basic beer, especially for these guys, but it is supremely well made and a real drinker, a good addition to their lineup and one that should stick around, a smart and appropriate entry point sort of beer for these guys. golden in the glass with pretty good clarity and an average height but fading white head. it smells awesome, somewhat more robust than a lot of these, and still kind of european on the grain even though it isnt, it has deep earthiness, even some german sort of dustiness to it, and to me seems fresher and higher in minerals than a lot of these, bold but still not heavy, if that makes sense. the yeast is also a little bit european, obviously a lager strain and obviously patiently worked, and the taste and mouthfeel confirm what the aroma suggests. the hops are pretty reserved, especially for these guys, they seem noble but maybe a little piney thing there too, all on the swallow, and still well behind the contributions of the grain and the yeast, even the water chemistry. i think the grain fits for the style but also brings something a little unique, call it terroir, to this, and they were smart to not dry hop over it or anything. i like how dry this is too, and even though it might feel just a touch watery, there is a lot to like about the texture too. nice four season pils here, just unique enough, infinitely drinkable.

I just wanted to preface by saying this was on sale, maybe closeout? I didn't want to charm it by looking at the age, so I'm not sure about that. In any event, this is pretty good, not sure why it's received so many mediocre reviews. I just finished the work week, prepping some dinner stuff and this is good. First sip really reminded me of the opening of JA's Sunny Ridge (which is literally perfect). It sort of plays simpler from there, there's a noble hop bite, a good malt body. It's hazy, not sure why? Maybe a really short lagering so it's not fined or perhaps it's just a zwickel in a sense. In any event, easy drinking, rounded, great option if you're a lager person. If you're into DFH and only really drink their hoppy offerings/stouts, maybe this won't resonate, and that's perfectly fine, just like the beer.

Give it a try. It's (surprisingly enough) a great beer.

So I bought a twelve pack of this last week and put in the main fridge, not the beer fridge. I didn't get to it last weekend but have been slowly hitting it up as the week went on and wanted to review it while there were still a few left. Not much for head but these sure go down easy. Love the bread note and the noble hop note and texture are not far off from the real thing. Not perfect or anything, but certainly will wet your whistle as we head for the summer.

Pours a pale gold with a white head.

Citrus and floral hops with nutty whole grain bread and slight dry wood notes.

Whole grain nutty malty bread with citrus/pine, floral hops - finishes dry with some slight wood character.

(12 oz can, JUN 2022; purchased single off shelf... poured into a 14 oz mug)

L: clear, yellow-gold liquid; perhaps a mild hop haze; Jackson crest of sudsy white foam... the head looked like it might hold, but it recedes to a thin collar and laces little

S: typcial craft pale lager / pils, floral-perfumy, honeyed cereal malt-kissed aromas... spicy and spot on

T: weird, it actually tastes like a mildly hopped-up European import... lingering herbal, spicy bite... dry aftertaste with peppery, leafy bitterness humming; little round malt remnants, maybe just a mellow toasted grain, a touch of dough... burped, and citrus blossoms

F: sharp and subtly prickly... delicate caress of plush curves midway; faint residual resinous dusting... back end is wonderfully, frictive, and crisp... ultra light on the palate

O: good enough for a summer swill... wish it had more malt character... kind of a clone of most of the other craft pilsners around (1875)

12 oz can with a March 2022 date stamped on the bottom.

I'm guessing this pilsner is designed to appeal to students and fans of the University of Delaware (the Blue Hens). It probably works fine for this since it is neither bold nor to far from a typical US macro brew. There is a more generous hop load, as becomes obvious in the bitter, grassy aftertaste.
Unlike almost all other brews from Dogfish Head, this will have limited appeal to craft beer aficionados.

Dogfish Head Craft Brewery "Blue Hen Pilsner"
12 fl. oz. can coded "MAY 2022 D 315 1 0005 11". Sampled on 24 MARCH 2022
$2 @ Wegmans, King of Prussia, PA

Notes via stream of consciousness: Blue Hen Pilsner... that name sounds familiar. There used to be a Blue Hen Beer Co. that contract brewed out of the Lion in Wilkes-Barre, PA but I'm not sure they ever made a Pilsner. That was way back. Well, good for Sam to take up the state bird again! It's poured a surprisingly hazy golden body beneath a short head of white foam. Why would they not filter this? I doubt it's dry hopped. Anyway, the head doesn't hold up that well but we'll see how the lacing turns out later. The aroma is clearly of rich, grainy Pilsner malt and grassy, spicy, herbal, and floral hops. The malt is lightly sweetish and there's a touch of an apple and citrus-like fruitiness to it. On to the taste... as you may have expected it tastes just like it smells but stronger and with an added bitterness. The malt is rich without being overdone, sweetish, grainy, and grassy. The hops are spicy, grassy, floral, and herbal. There's a delicate touch of lemon to it. The bitterness is median, and it finishes dry and hoppy. They've certainly nailed the Pilsner style here, and this is better than a lot of the Pilsners that I've had in Germany and the Czech Republic. This is, of course, a Czech style Pilsener but there are plenty of German breweries producing the style as well. In the mouth it's medium bodied on the lower side, and it's crisp with a fine-bubbled, standard carbonation. The drawbacks then? The slight haze, the lack of head retention, and what's turned out to be limited lacing as well. Otherwise this is a great Pilsner that I'd turn to all of the time if the price was right.
Review #7,839

12oz can best by dated June 2022 into a pilsner glass.
L: Pours almost crystal clear pale light yellow w/a tall 3+" white head w/very good retention, a sturdy center cap & good carbonation. Random sticky lacing.
S: Bread dough, grassy hops, floral, grains, yeast.
T: Pale malts, smooth, clean, lightly sweet, lemony bitterness on sides of the tongue which lingers slightly, light caramel, a hint of brine.
F: Subtle crispness, smooth, moderately drying light bodied mouth feel w/a clean finish.
O: A very easy drinking and sort of pale tasting pilsner that is refreshing yet not very interesting. It is good in it's style.

L - Poured from a can into a Sam Adams Perfect Glass at around 45 - 50 degrees. Pale straw color. 1+ finger head on aggressive pour. Faded to a soapy looking film. Not really any lacing. Opaque Hazy when looking through. The look isn’t very appealing.

S - Smell is more appealing than the look. Grain scents. Light malt. Faint citrus. Cereal scents as well. Still very light scents overall though.

T - Taste follows scent. A little bitterness from citrus. Even a little floral. Very light grain malts. Not too complex. Those are the flavors. Actually. More lemon comes through as it warms up.

F - Some carbonation. Soapy consistency. Thin.

O - This is an okay beer. Not offensive, but doesn’t wow you. Perfectly fine for camping or drinking after working in the yard. I wouldn’t put this in my regular rotation though. It came in a variety pack with Dogfish Head 60 Minute IPA, 90 Minute IPA, (and the Slightly Might which I haven’t tried.) 60 Min and 90 are great beers, and I’m not really a big IPA fan. This Pilsner is a pass.

Blue Hen Pilsner has a thick, off-white head, a somewhat hazy, bubbly gold appearance, and minimal lacing. The aroma is off faint white bread and grass. The flavor is of cracker and moderate, grassy hop bitterness. Blue Hen has a medium body and a mostly-dry finish.

RJT

Best by 12/21

Well, it's clearly past December, but this one was given to me for free. It was supposed to be a variety pack exclusive, but it seems all the stores around me were breaking up the packs to make this one available in single cans. I think that's a good mood personally but I doubt DFH would be fans of a move like that

Pours a hazy pale yellow with a finger of white head that fades to a ring and leaves minimal lacing

There's still some bite in the nose despite the age, and it's quite nice. I'm picking up on aromas of lemon zest, grassy hops, toasted grain, crackery malt, white pepper, and a touch of honey

Taste wise it's a touch too sweet for me. I know that's basically the distinction in this style of Pilsner, but I think this one overdoes it just a tad, even if only up front. On the front end of the sip I'm tasting honey, bready malt, grassy hops, and light diacetyl. The swallow brings notes of lemon zest, pear skin, crackery malt, herbal hops, toasted grain, pepper and light honey

A light medium body pairs with gentle carbonation, resulting in a crisp and biting beer. Finishes mostly dry with a decent balance

I'm a bit surprised by the lower ratings on this one. Despite the sweetness I already mentioned, it's pretty damn solid, even out of code. I'll have to try it again fresh

My son brought these back from UD in Newark, DE. Beautiful gold hue on the pour, slightly cloudy with thin head but ample lace. Aroma is a whiff of malted barley. Taste follows nose. Crisp and refreshing finish. A very nice pilsner from the folks at Dogfish.
Picked-up as part of a mixed twelve-pack at Luke's in Plymouth for about eighteen dollars. My sixth brew from these guys. Stamp of Jan 22 on bottom of can. Mediocre

Pours a dark brown color with ruby edges and over two fingers of fluffy head. The nose has notes of both soy sauce and molasses. The flavor profile has fairly strong notes of alcohol that overwhelm the other flavors.

12 ounce bottle - Stout Bros. Woodstock Beer Market - Woodstock, Georgia.

Best By: 02/25/23.

Appearance: Pours a very dark brown body, minimal head formation,

Smell: Light chocolate, moderate toastiness but a big drizzle of molasses. Sweet-smelling vanilla sugar with a milky twang about it and a persistent raisiny tone.

Taste: A rather sweet albeit unsurprising commencement with notes of toasted dark breadcrust, subtler roasted malts, bitterish chocolate powder, Grandma's molasses and vanilla followed by a little glug of whipping cream. Port-soaked raisin clafouti through the smooth, glossy finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium-light carbonation. Slick, lightly sticky mouthfeel.

Overall: Not bad, though one long bottle is more than plenty for me.

I am a brewer and have been for 25+ years now. An important note;
Karl Strauss was my friend and he taught me how to critique a unique brew.
I am not easily impressed, I would like to say that Coffee and Milk Stouts are my personal loves in small batch brews.
Mr Strauss recommended one of my milk stouts to the LA Octoberfest an number of years ago. I would very much like to meet and shake the brewer or brewers hands who created this wonderful dark liquid concoction. The color is deep, the bouquet is amazing, mouth is a tiny bit light for me but very quick to finish and the flavors of the double milks are superb.
I am not ashamed to say this Milk Stout rivals all of mine. Bully! for you I say...
Thank you Brewers of Left Handed Double Milk Stout of Longmont CO. Your efforts, ideas and work are top notch.

Cheers to you
Jozph

Look for no head on this brew. Even though I tried.
Smells and Tastes like milk chocolate.
Feels flats from lack of carbonation but bumped the score up a little because 10.5% ABV counts for something.
I'd drink again but there are way too many other milk stouts to try.

Drinking it in a stout glass.
Pours a nice black-brown with only a thin tannish head.
Strong smell of chocolate and cinnamon.
Smooth, velvety chocolate taste.
Minimal bitterness.

Really like it. Its almost like a dessert/pastry beer without the fuckery. Just an honestly made sweet beer. Still a nice roasted malt aspect to it. The feel is wierd. Its thin, almost flat feeling, but crisp and dry like a lager. Doesn't really last long with you for a 10% beer and drinks dangerously light. This is giving me deep flashbacks to sam adams cream stout which is arguably the beer that got me into craft 13 years ago.

Overall this beer is much, much better than I anticipated.

12oz bottle. Poured out an opaque, jet-black color with a small, light brown head of foam. It left sudsy trails of lace on the glass. It smelled of rich, milk chocolate, toffee, caramel and molasses. Sweet chocolate taste with hints of vanilla, toffee and caramel.

The beer pours a nice creamy tan head that dissipates fairly quickly. The beer itself is a dark chocolate dark brown that looks very nice.

The beer has a nice smell. It isn't anything too crazy and good. It is a mix of chocolate and cream with a moderate note of brown sugar and lactose.

The taste is good. It has a moderate chocolate note mixed with lactose and coffee in the finish.

The feel is good. It's a medium-heavy body with a velvet texture to it and biting carbonation.
