Overall, it's a good beer. It isn't anything crazy but definitely hits the spot for a nice stout.

Poured a black body with minimal head and no lace. The aroma has some mild coffee notes with touch of vanilla but really just get a bunch of chocolate. Smooth, thick, touches of vanilla and coffee bite are minimal and in background of a large light-chocolate sweetness and then the beer finishes slightly boozy.

Smooth, silky and dangerously drinkable, Left Hand Brewing slides its double-digit alcohol percentage nicely behind the malts, milk sugars and gentle roast to tease their beer drinking audiences with a taste that's chocolate milk for adults.

Generally black and layering patiently into the glass, Double Milk Stout releases a classic dense froth of slightly tanned hues. Holding firm throughout the session, the bubbles host a scent that's creamy, roasty, chocolaty and vanilla-like. Similar in its early sweetness, the taste is soothingly sweet and malted with chocolate, toffee, caramel, honey and a general nougat character.

As the sweetness slowly retreats, its roasted elements increase to form an impression of smooth espresso roast, burnt toast, roasted nuttiness and a turn from milk chocolate to something more of the bittersweet variety. Soft and woodsy bitterness decorates the late palate and hits that notion of dark roast coffee home.

Smooth, creamy and warming heading into finish, a late spice of broad and woodsy bitterness offers a taste of char with kahlua spice, warm cream and a long linger of sweet, chocolate-like roast for a savory, velvety session meant sipping but you've got to watch yourself. This beer is super drinkable.

Best by 2/25/23
L: black body off white ring for head.

S: like the regular milk stout and a bit of alc.

T: rich dark chocolate and a little dark fruit on top of the original milk stout taste. Basically as advertised and then some.

F: medium-heavy body with nice creaminess but the carbonation is a little annoying, makes it a bit spritzy. Would prefer a little more rugged mouthfeel while staying in the dessert stout range.

O: basically their original milk stout with a stronger darker flavor and a similar body with an obnoxious amount of carbonation in it. I suppose letting it aire for a bit would solve the problem but maybe it’s there to keep you from crushing it. That didn’t work for me, but who knows. I wanted to like it more, but it was just solid overall and not a home run hitter.

Not what I expected. More coffee than I expected. Like a coffee milk stout with plenty of molasses and brown sugar notes in the sweetness, but unmistakable coffee and char/ toasted notes dominate this stout.

From the neck of the bottle in yellow text: "BEST BY:08/19/22"

Appearance: It has a black body with a short, creamy textured, light tan head. The head is short, about half a thumb, but it stays up nicely. Some spotty lacing.

Aroma: There is a light aroma of malt and a slightly stronger scent of alcohol.

Taste: Up front it tastes like alcohol, burnt caramel, raisins, and brown sugar. The middle of the palate is full of dark fruit characters like raisins, plums, and dates. All of these comingle with a light toasted flavor and a touch of brown sugar character. It tastes a bit like a Belgian Strong Dark Ale but without some of the sweeter notes, and a slightly more toastier character.

Mouthfeel: It is medium-full bodied and slick. It is a sipper given the obvious presence of alcohol.

Overall: The label states that this contains "Ingredients: Rocky Mountain water, malted barley, lactose, dextrose, flaked oats, hops, yeast." It also states that this is "10.5% ALC/VOL." It is a simple beer with a lot of complex flavors, however it also shows the high alcohol content. As a whole the interesting flavors and the complexity make it worth recommending at least a sample or a single bottle, but I wouldn't recommend more than that until you've made up your mind. I probably wouldn't buy it again but it was worth trying out.

From the 12 oz bottle in a snifter. This solid little brew pours a dark
brownish black with a very nice head of kahki foam that settles to a
fat ring, thin dusty layer, and sports some nice lacing. Nose of dark
sweet chocolate, rich cream, brulee, char, and some subtle dark fruit
notes. Flavors surpass the nose with rich dark chocolate, rich cream,
dark coffee touches, roasted nutty malt notes, moderate char, deep
roast, dark molasses, and dark berry hints of blue and blackberry.
Nice mouth feel; full body, smooth, moderately slick, coating, rich,
moderately warming, and finishing nicely sweet and well balanced
for a desert brew.

Overall, a solid little brew.

Cheers
Not bad-tasting. But -- for what's essentially an imperial stout -- it's sugary and bubbly. I'd acquired a single bottle at Woodman's and deigned to pour out half.

Best by 8/16/22. 12oz bottle poured into a tulip.

Pours almost black; small light khaki head that fades quickly leaving little retention and lacing.

The aromas are malt forward. Hints of cocoa and marshmallow. Malts are there. They open up slightly as it warms.

The flavors are on the sweeter side. Lots of milk and milk sugars. Lots of marshmallow. Some vanilla. Lots of heavy cream. Some cocoa and milk chocolate. Strong malt backbone. Mild warmth in the finish, but the alcohol is ultimately well hidden at 10.5% ABV.

Mouthfeel is full-bodied with active carbonation. It's sharp, spritzy and slightly fluffy.

This is an alright brew. There's something about it that I'm not personally crazy about and I can't quite put my finger on what it is. It's still not bad at all though.

12oz bottle
best by 09/10/22
L: dark brown body; very thin khaki head
S: chocolate, lactose, grain, brown sugar
T: sweet; brown sugar, lactose, chocolate, vanilla, coffee
F: fuller body, very smooth while maintaining sweetness, lower carbonation, alcohol is non-existent, sweet finish with a latte-like taste lingering
O: this didn’t meet expectations; too sweet for me

Bottle poured into a Mountain Rambler Brewery snifter

A: Pours dark brown, basically black, with a creamy tan head that settles to a thin layer and laces very nicely.

S: Roasted malt, milk chocolate, a touch of coffee and char, vanilla, brown sugar, a touch of spice, light earthy faintly herbal notes, and a hint of dark fruit.

T: Milk chocolate, vanilla, big dark sugar, a little coffee, earthy roasted malt, a touch of spice, and a hint of dark fruit.

M: Medium to full body, moderate carbonation, creamy smooth, with the faintest warmth.

O: Pretty much exactly what you'd expect from an imperialized version of the venerable Left Hand Milk Stout. Sure it's on the sweet side and not overly complex, but it's impressively smooth and rather enjoyable, though most days I'd probably rather have 2 pints of the original instead.

"Best by 8/13/22"; drank 11/26/21 @ the Yarchives.

Brown/black appearance.

An even pour yielded a small tan head; decent lace.

Cream, cocoa powder, mild fresh earth & faint raspberry notes in the nose.

Creamy medium mouthfeel.

Sweet cream & faint fresh earth flavors up front; cocoa powder & faint raspberry notes on the finish. No booze heat.

Pretty damn sweet, but what do you expect? This one's worth a quaff.

Pours Mahogany with a 1/4" tan head, which dissipates fast. Minimal lacing.

Aroma is chocolate, coffee, roast malt.

Taste is chocolate, coffee, molasses.

Medium body, light carbonation. Semisweet finish.

Lack of a head cost it points but, very good otherwise.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter
Appearance – The beer pours a super dark brown, nearly black color with a small head of tan colored foam. The head fades almost instantly, leaving a light level of foamy lace on the sides of the glass.
Smell – The aroma is big and inviting, with lots of milk chocolate, crème, and coffee like aromas. At the same time there is a nice dark roasted malt smell as well as sweet vanilla and caramel smells. Aromas of a warm boozy smell mix in, along with a bit of brown sugar, char, and raisin, giving rise to an overall sweet and warming smell.
Taste – The taste begins with a rather sweet milk chocolate latte flavor that has a strong backing of brown sugar and cola, with some light fruit sweetness of cherry and raisin. Upfront there is also a bit of char and roasted malt, but these are rather subdued in light of the heavy sweeter flavors. As the taste moves forward however, the roast and char become a bit more pronounced, while the milk chocolate fades a bit. At the same time the sweeter cola flavor gets more pronounced, and with a bit of a boozy rum like taste, and a surge of a vanilla marshmallow like flavor, one is left with a warming and sweet taste to linger on the tongue.
Mouthfeel – The body of the brew is on the thicker and heavier side with a carbonation level that is on the low side. For the rich flavors and style the feel is good and makes for a dessert like sipper.
Overall – A rather potent and sweet stout. A little unbalanced on sweet:roastiness ratio, but overall not bad and one to at least give a try to.

This is a strong double stout, clocking in with a double-digit ABV, but the good news is you won't get overwhelmed by the boozy flavor. You can actually taste the notes of brown sugar and vanilla as the label promises. It's not quite in Avery territory as far as "knock you on your arse", so you can drink a bottle of this and not feel hung over. This was part of their Milk Box sampler 12-pack, which features four different versions of their famous Milk Stout.

A - Pitch black pour with thin dark cream lacing.

S - Light chocolate cocoa with a delicate char background.

T - Light to medium chocolate roast with light char on the backside and some lactose to smooth things out.

M - Medium body.

O - This is a flavorful, really easy drinking Milk Stout with a well hidden ABV.

12oz bottle poured into a stein

A- pours a clear deep amber color with a one-finger foamy white head that reduces to a thin film on top

S- nose is a bit muted at first but eventually opens up with some caramel, dry leaves, toasted bread crust and a hint of floral hops

T- sweet and malty up front with notes of caramel and toasted brown bread. Mid-palate gives some floral hops before finishing with a hit of sweet caramel that lingers long after

M- medium body with moderate carbonation leads to a foamy mouthfeel that continues into a semi-sweet crisp finish

O- full flavored and well balanced

Appearance: Pours a clear, dark amber, almost copper color with a moderate off-white head. SRM of 14-15. (4.00)

Aroma: Moderate aromas of brown bread malt, rich caramel, some scotch and booze with darker fruit mixed within. Rich and boozy.

Flavor: Moderate flavors of brown bread malt, rich caramel, booze, scotch, and some dark sweet fruit undertones. A sweet, boozy finish.

Feel: Medium bodied. Moderate carbonation, somewhat appreciable. Soft, but boozy-like flavor lingers.

It's too boozy, not unlike Bitburger's Festbier without the authentic German flavors.

Overall: A decent Oktoberfest here. Brown bread and caramel malts mixed with scotch and booze. Sort of reminds me of a light Dirty Bastard from Founders. Enjoyable and flavorful, but I think it sort of misses the style a bit. (Rating: 3.63)

Attractive appearance (as I believe most O'Fests are). Clear deep amber, bordering on copper, with a large off white head and a fair amount of lacing. Aroma dials up a solid, if unspectacular, rendering of a marzen: malt focused, lightly hopped, crusty bread. Taste also hits all the right notes with toffee, dark bread, and herbal hops all contributing. Modest bitterness as the hops become more assertive. Smooth, medium bodied, moderately carbonated mouthfeel.

Oktoberfest (2021) from Brooklyn Brewery. Picked up at Shangy’s, Emmaus, PA. $ 2.11 (Including tax)/12 oz bottle ($ 0.176/oz) on 18/09/21. On room temperature shelf at store, stored at 37 degrees at home. Reviewed 25/06/22. Note that I use DD/MM/YY protocol.
Smeared dating in yellow ink on shoulder of bottle. Served at 40.1 degrees in a hand washed and dried Jester King Snifter. Final temperature 48.0 degrees.
Appearance – 3.5.
First pour – Deep Gold (SRM 6), clear.
Body – Medium Amber (SRM 12), translucent. When rear-lite, clear with moderate effervescence.
Head – Average (Maximum two cm, aggressive center pour), antique white, high-density, short retention, diminishing to a 0.2 cm bubble ring and a large thin island.
Lacing – None.
Aroma – 3 – Weak malt. No hops, no yeast.
Flavor – 3.5 – Begins slightly sweet with malt. Hops add a refreshing bite. No ethanol (5.5 % ABV, as marked on label) aroma or taste. No gastric warming. No dimethylsulfide or diacetyl.
Palate – 3 – Thin, watery, lightly fizzy carbonation.
Final impression and summation: 3.5 Actually a tasty Marzen, one that could easily be consumed all day. The hops mediate the malt sweetness and leave a refreshing twist on what would be otherwise a chore to drink more than one.

Served on tap into a 16 oz (473 ml) conical pint glass at The Taphouse in Tuckahoe, NY.
A: Pours a crystal clear, bright copper color with a one finger, wheat colored head, low retention, and little lacing.
S: Aromas of caramel malt, sweet hay, maybe a touch of citrus.
T: More semisweet than semidry. Malty with light caramel and tangerine or orange citrus. Minimal bitterness -- very well balanced.
M: Light bodied with no more than moderate effervescence. Drinks very smooth and clean.
O: Surprised that I have never had this delicious Octoberfest beer before. Will certainly have again.

Poured into grip shaped goblet: color is copper, head is off white/light tan and presents 1/2 inch thick and dissipates quickly to nothing, no lacing.

smell is light caramel, toast, bread, light earthy hops.

taste is light caramel, toast, bread, herbal/earthy hops, lingering maltiness. Malts are mixed, maybe more munich base and light caramunich for sweetness.

Mouthfeel is moderate carbonation, moderate sweetness, low bitterness - fairly true to style, lingering sweetness and crispness.

Overall a neutral base malt, light caramel like sweetness, herbal hops make for an average american oktoberfest.
Pours a clear copper, small off white head that fades to a ring, no lacing. Aroma of warm bread, some hops. A bit thin, needs more carbonation, its flat. A minor disappointment.

Can brewed at FX Matt in Utica. Poured into clean and rinsed pint glass. Zero head, zero lacing. That is the biggest weakness for me. Taste was fine, a bit on the sweeter side. The lack of any sort of head or lacing killed the appeal for me. Would not buy again.

This is a honey-colored brew, capped with an off-white foam. From an aluminum can, it is a solid Oktoberfest. Bready, lightly malty, drinkable, and full. It is flavorful and has a nice hefty body. Wonderful.

From a 12oz can best by 1/2022. Dark amber color with big, foamy head. Caramel malt smell. Medium body. Rich caramel malt flavor with some sweetness. Darker and maltier than some Maerzens but very tasty overall.

This is a 12oz. bottle poured into the 20oz. weizen glass. This is a dark amber, clear, with carbonation leaning to the heavy side. The head is a one inch finger, off white, that settled down but never completely left, the color is a very light tan. This looks nice, lets see how the rest goes.
The aroma is very noticeable from the time the cap was removed. Sweet malt and fresh bread are very noticeable.
The flavor starts with a little hop spice and light bitters quickly giving way to the nice caramel sweetness and bread dough flavor.
This has a medium mouthfeel, missing creamy by a little.
This is a tasty brew, easy to drink, one I would not turn down.

12oz bottle. Bottle neck is stamped 'BB 01/2022'.
Clear, dark amber colored body. Brief off white head. No lacing.
Aroma of slightly sweet, bready malt, and green apple.
Taste is dark bread malt, slight apple sweetness, and hop bitterness that includes some spice.
Full body. Okay carbonation.
An enjoyable Marzen, with good balance and tasty flavors. Kind of dry in the aftertaste. Session workable.

"Best by January 2022"; drank 9/6/21 @ the Yarchives.

See-through golden appearance.

A violent pour yielded a HUGE eggshell head; frothy lace.

Roasted corn, mild caramel & faint hop bite notes in the nose.

Creamy, medium mouthfeel.

Roasted corn & a faint hop bitterness in the flavor up front; mild caramel notes & a hint of caramel on the finish.

Robust, yet easy to drink; perhaps a touch too hoppy but overall a good brew.

Bottle. White head. Some lace. Clear autumn golden color.

Biscuity and malty. Toasted malts, nutty. Light toffee. Has an odd spice or flavor to it that I can’t pinpoint. Maybe like a dried apple or pear note.

Not my favorite festbier, seems to taste much different than a lot of the others I’ve had.

Pours an amber with off white head. Some caramel and toast on the nose. Maybe a little bit of a fruity note. Getting a lot of bread crust, lots of caramel. This isn't what I want from a Märzen as it doesn't really get into that malty nutty character I enjoy, but it isn't bad to drink by any means. There is enough hop character to keep this from getting cloyingly sweet.

Pours from the bottle a dark amber, thin ring of head. Nose is well developed darker malts, toffee, burnt sugar. Starts slow on the palate with slight malty sweetness, but develops with some tannic elements, almost like a dark tea. Mouthfeel is full, slight carbonation.

12 ounce bottle poured into a tumbler style pint glass.

Clear and copper with one finger of khaki foam that fades to a ring inside of a minute but leaves a small amount of lace. The nose starts full and malty, bread and toast, but changes to an overpowering iron mineral aroma. Taste is better, starting bready, with a hint of malty sweetness and finishing with an herbal/floral bitterness. It is light, refreshing and crisp, easy drinking but lacks creaminess . OK, the mineral aroma is a distraction.

Ive probably had this beer 100 times and never reviewed it. so here we go.
Pouring at cellar temp into my .5L dimple mug. the beer pours a crystal clear chestnut hue. A fluffy eggshell white head of 1.5 cm foams up and rests lightly on the surface. This foam fades to a wispy surface layer and leaves some dense lattice when I swirl the mug or take a sip.
The aroma is rich toasted malt and light caramel with a bit of breadyness to it. Seems a little sweet on the nose but does have a bit of spicy hop scent too.
First sip reveals a light crisp textured body that is very easy to drink and i find my glass getting empty fairly quickly.
Medium carbonation that gently rolls across my palate only adds to the easy drinking here.
Flavor is caramel and bready malts, with some light toasted grains too. I do get a little spicy hop on the finish to balance the malt sweetness. Beer finishes with a little dryness. Very easy drinking brew with nice malt character. COuld easily drink several of these in a session.

This version is 5.5%

Pours an effervescent copper with plenty of tan head, thanks to an aggressive pour. Below average lacing & head retention

S: Brown bread, pears, toastyness, great nose

T: Brown bread, leaf hops, pears up front, plenty toasty as well. Toasty, dry with leafy hops as this warms. Finishes dry, toasty with woody hops

MF: Medium body, restrained carbonation

Drinks fairly easy, a little more maltyness would've helped, but solid

12oz can
BB 01/2021
L: taller, foamy, tan head caps a slightly hazed amber Märzen bier
S: herbal, spicy, grassy hops; sweet caramely malt
T: well balanced; caramel, toffee, toasty grain; spicy, herbal, earthy, grassy hops
F: medium body, ample carbonation, sweeter finish
O: excellently drinkable, a tad on the sweet side and it could be a touch drier, otherwise a great example of the style

12 oz. bottle, looks like it was bottled May 18, 2022, expiration August 18, 2023. My first beer from this brewery, and my first beer listed under the style of Festbier, which according to BeerAdvocate is the modern day equivalent to an Oktoberfestbier, so that's what I'm expecting.

Poured into Brasserie D'achouffe stemware.

A - Pours a coppery amber orange body, some ok clarity, and little over a finger's worth of frothy khaki head. Looks pretty good.

S - Nose brings in some crisp bready malts, with slight notes of mineral water & coppery metallics. Soft notes of cream, earth, green apple come through. Pervasive mineraly well water type aroma throughout. A little dusty.

T - Taste brings the same; some crusty bread malts, green apple, herbal earth, mineral water. Notes of cream & green apple linger on the finish. The bottle does say this was brewed with hop extracts in addition to actual hops, but any fresh or piney, or i guess "American" hop flavors are absent. Typical taste per the style I'd say.

M - Feel is smooth, medium-light in body, easy drinking. Apt carbonation. I just burped.

Overall, an easy drinking beer from this German brewery, I'd be interested in trying more from them, and also in trying more beers listed under the Festbier heading. A nice intro the this style.

Allgäuer Büble Bier Festbier -----3.5/5

12oz bottle into a pint glass. Bottled 5/10/22, so 4 months old.

Looks nice enough, clear golden amber body with a decent white head. This persists in lesser form throughout leaving scattered lacing.

Malty aroma with a touch of old bread.

On tasting, clean, slightly sweet, smooth, mostly malty with a fleeting hop note.

Mouth above medium, finish slightly drying.

Overall, while not unpleasant, and quite clean, it doesn't have the character of the better festbiers.

From the bottle, it pours a clear amber color with a nice white head that slowly reduces as it is being replenished by a nice stream of bubbles from the bottom and leaves lacing. The nose gets as dose of light malt. The mouth gets the same, an easy drinking malty brew.

Simply speaking this is a very nice Festbier, and in such it’s a nice alternative to endless Märzen that are presented to us as Oktoberfestbeer. In recent years (meaning: decades), beer style at the actual Oktoberfest, at other fall beerfests such as Stuttgarter Wasen etc. have shifted from the heavy, dark and sweet Märzen towards the more easily drinkable Festbier style. In Germany at most of these events, Festbier is what everyone drinks. Märzen has become a niche in that regard. My personal preference is (by far) the Festbier style, and not the Märzen.
If you want to compare to understand what that difference actually is, get a sixer of Paulaner Oktoberfest Beer and a sixer of Oktoberfest Märzen. Both good, I just happen to line the non-Märzen better. Allgäuer Büble Festbier is a very nice example of this style.

A nice amber color that seems to be hazy like an IPA but without the bite back of a hoppy bier. It keeps a foamy head and has a smooth taste. In keeping with fest style biers i recommend drinking a liter glass...or two!

Allgäuer Brauhaus AG "Allgäuer Büble Bier Festbier"
12 fl. oz. brown glass bottle "Best before: P.02.06.2021 E.02.09.2022 L0206031425" and sampled on 17.06.22
$2.79 @ Foodery Beer, Phila., PA

Notes via stream of consciousness: It's poured a clear deep amber body beneath a finger's width of off-white foam. The aroma is gently malty with bready notes and a touch of caramel backed by softly herbal hop notes. On to the taste... it's fuller than the aroma suggests but it basically follows suit. The malt is lightly sweet, grainy, bready, and softly caramelish and the hops are softly herbal and spicy. A moderate to median bitterness balances it and it finishes with just a dollop of sweetish malt lingering amidst spicy, grassy, and herbal hops that eventually fade to leave just bitterness behind. In the mouth it's medium bodied and smooth with a moderate, fine-bubbled carbonation. The lacing held up well and it's left some nice lacing with wide patches surrounded by smaller streaks and spots. It's readily accessible and highly quaffable because it straddles the fence between being delicate and being satiating.
Review #8,080

Purchased as a single bottle from The Blue Door for $6.00. Poured into a proper glass mug.

L - One-finger pale white head follows a clear copper pour. Head goes away pretty fast.
S - Corn flakes, biscuit, and a sweet floral note.
T - Strong honey on the start. Light earthiness. Dry, almost fruity finish.
F - Refreshing. Clean. Not filling at all, and easy-to-drink. I could easily drink twelve of these in one sitting.
O - Not the most interesting beer, but super drinkable and inoffensive. Tasty, too. Would make a fantastic lunch beer. Would definitely buy again. Give it a try.

12 oz bottle, poured into a weissglass at ~40 degrees F.

L: Poured a pale honey gold, and formed a thick, fluffy white head with excellent retention. Spotty lacing, with noticeable rings.

S: Crisp, clean, straw and biscuit with a light floral tinge.

T: Also crisp and clean, very subtle on flavor. Biscuit malts, light pear, faint white grape, a suggestion of honey.

F: Very light-bodied, almost watery but not quite.

O: Not bad. Not a standout, but quite refreshing.

Poured from a brown 12 oz. bottle. Has a dark golden color with a 1/2 inch head. Smell is mild, some bready malts. Taste is the same as the aroma, some caramel is present, light hops as well. Feels medium bodied in the mouth and overall is a pretty good beer.

12 ounce bottle, packaged 02.06.21, best by 02.09.22 stamped on the back label. Possible it was packaged in June 2021 since European brews sometimes goes day/month on their packaging but I'm not 100% sure of that. Thanks to Brutaltruth for this! Served in a dimpled mug, the beer pours a clear dark gold color with about an inch white head. Head retention and lacing are both good. Aroma is nice, it's a sweet smelling brew that smells mostly like biscuity/bready malt, along with some honey and floral/earthy hops. Taste is pretty much just like the aroma, but there's also some caramel noticeable too. Mouthfeel/body is light/medium, it's smooth and easy to drink with a good amount of carbonation. Typically I like Märzen style Oktoberfests more than I do Festbiers, but this one is good! Definitely worth trying if you get the chance!

12 oz. bottle from the packaged 2/6/21 release.This is the first time I noticed the Festbeer in our shops.
Clear copper color with three fingers varied cream head. Full lacing curtain and longlasting cap.
Strong honey bread, corn, floral hop aromas.
Well balanced spicy hop, caramel, light grape flavors.
Substantial body, dry finish, good bitterness. Easy drinking.
This has been a good year for distinctive festbeers appearing on tap and store shelves. Hope the trend continues.

From the bottle in a snifter. This excellent fest pours a clear
light amber / brass color with a fantastic head of white foam that
settles to a thick ring, thin dusty layer, and shows some excellent
lacing. Nose of floral hops, honey sweet malt, toffee, and light breaded
malts. Flavors exceed the nose with a fine presentation of light
breaded malts amongst some floral and light herbal hops amidst
light toffee and caramel malt notes. Nice mouth feel; medium light
carbonation that is nice and soft, medium light to light body, and
finishing lightly dry, faintly herbal, and lightly sweet.

An excellent fest, not sure what the hate is about, I'm on my
3rd six pack of it if that says anything!

Cheers

A new one for me. Have had other Allgäuer beers before, but the Büble Fest is a new one.

12 ounce import -- interesting. Packaged 02.06.21, Expires 02.09.22. Poured into my tall Becher.

L -- Clear, deep brassy gold with a dense, firm white head that leaves good lacing.

S -- Mellow herbal hops with light DMS and a bready malt backbone -- even some melanoidin showing.

T -- Good blend of herbal hops and bready melanoidin with the first swallow. There's a dry yeasty character very reminiscent of Paulaner Amber Märzen. Finish is spicy bitterness and nice melanoidin character in the aftertaste. The hop bitterness is bolder than the malts, but it still invites another gulp. There's also an underlying white grape note, common in German beers using good malts and a good mash.

M -- Mouthfeel is soft to slightly syrupy with a crisp, dry finish. Body is light-medium to medium.

O -- A little different take on Festbier with its hop note being a bit more prominent than usual -- maybe a bit too hop-heavy for my tastes in Festbier, but it's a great drinker and doesn't stunt the palate. A Fest/Märzen hybrid with its color and body. Worth a try for its good malt character.

Perfectly clear bronze body with tow fingers of frothy white head. This was the highlight of the beer. Nose has skunkiness atop caramel malts, sweet corn and sweet grains. Taste is worse, euro macro malts, corn, sickly sweet caramel notes and light herbal skunk on the finish. Feel is thin, watery, malty, skunky, flat, and short lived on the palate. It's a bad festbier, pass on it

12 ounce bottle poured into a dimpled mug.
Bottled 2/6/21

L: Clear, amber, no visible carbonation, one finger antique-white head fades to a thin cap in under a minute
S: Small skunk aroma from the bottle, bready malt and no skunk after the pour, then a more clean aroma with white cracker
T: Briefly malt forward and lowly sweet to start, honey and cracker, floral/herbal hop flavor rising to the finish, very low bitterness, increased but mildly bitter aftertaste, sharp and dry overall
F: Lightly crisp, builds a little frothiness in the middle, has a slight tongue coating feel
O: OK, seems overly sharp for a Festbier and perhaps leans toward a Marzen.

Poured from the bottle into a Libbey style pilsner glass.

Beautiful looking lager, with a brass gold and chestnut hued clarity for the body appearance, maybe even a faint touch of red squeaking out in the darker areas. Capped with a great looking cream top, nice white not yellowed and not bright bleach like either. This 2 finger top sits nicely with slow settling and some good spider legs of lacing too.

Aroma seems different. A very noticeable ester of banana getting into more of a hefe clove quality. Clean, with light touches of crisp toffee also. The banana seems misplaced but not in a bad way at least.

Palate continues more of this banana flavor but still provides fest character. Clean mid palate, quite fruity actually somewhat with a toffee mix and almost banana and berry sweetness. Mild sensing hop, a bit of hinting pasty sticky lager flavor just by a hair in the finish. Mild sense of spicy herbal classic hop in the mix.

Interesting festbier, kind of sticks out uniquely, but the fruity estery nature of it I find just a hair distracting.
Pours clear, gold in color with one quarter inch head. Taste is mineral, brown bread and honey. Light bodied, sweet with high carbonation. Nice Octoberfest beer. Plenty bread, sessionable.

Bottle poured into a tulip

A- pours a clear golden color with a one-finger foamy white head that reduces to a thin film floating on top

S- slightly doughy malt with undertones of caramel, floral hops and honey. Hints of cracker

T- light floral hop and doughy caramel malt up front. Mid-palate has a strange tartness before giving more caramel into a semi-dry finish, lingers of grass and bread

M- medium-light body with moderate carbonation leads to a foamy mouthfeel that continues into the finish

Pours a clear dark yellow that settles out with a thick ring of head, moderate lacing. Nose is leathery malts, almost smoky. Taste leads with mild baked bread notes and toast, balanced sweetness, and none of the smokier notes that are present on the nose. Mouthfeel is full with a light carbonation. Overall, a very tasty offering.

Poured into a Celebrator pokal. Pours a medium golden amber with a half finger white head with good retention and light lacing. Aroma of caramel malt with a little biscuit, sweet bread and a little grassy malt, similar to a Märzen. Flavor is caramel biscuit malt with some graininess, wheat bread and grassy hops. Slightly astringent, but moderate bitterness in the finish. Medium bodied with light creaminess. I guess these Festbiers are a mellowed out Märzen style. This one smelled like the latter to me. The flavor has less of the sweet caramel and more grainy biscuit. Grassy continental hops are traditional. The finish on this was a little too grainy and starkly grassy bitter. A satisfactory Octoberfest style lager, but I think I prefer the old fashioned Märzen better.

I've had only two beers from AllGauer and the first was its O-Fest. Having covered them for one season, I prefer its Festbier... in part because this only my 3rd in the style. (Indicating I'm, like, back in the 20th Century.)

This Festbier is good for malt-heads like me. Pretty in my tall weizen glass, this golden brew stays bubbly and creates a nice lace all the way down. Smells are average, almost entirely malt. (At least gimme a grassy hop.) Tastes are the same, but it never gets sweet. Balanced. Soft in my mouth, somewhat like wheat.

Fancying myself as a traditional drinker, I want to like Allgauer. But they may be too traditional even for me to warmup to. I went on their website for a second time (two years later than reviewing their O-fest) and for a second time I could not find the English button. Their product is good enough to be exported, but the language flexibility needs to be improved.

product_name: Fellowship IPA, The Lord of the Rings
product_review:
12 oz. can, best by date of 12/16/22. My first new beer from BrewDog in quite a while. Brewed by BrewDog in Winchester, Ohio. Acquired this can of Lord of the Rings beer as part of a mixed six pack at the local Binny's.

Poured to a La Fin Du Monde tulip.

A - Pours a pale juicy yellow-orange body, About a finger of bubbly soapy white head that dies out quick. Leaves behind a beer that is flat in appearance.

S - A nice soft aroma, more biscuity than anything I'd say. Hop content is there, but not juicy or bursting. Earthy, twiggy, leafy, skunky. Smells like fresh, but indistinct dry-hopping.

T - Taste is pretty light for the style, but right for the abv I suppose. Again, earthy leafty dry-hopping lends a bit of a skunky sort of hop flavor. Not particularly piney, resinous, or bitter. A bit of a peppery, rye malt flavor lingers near the finish.

M - Feel is smooth, crisp, clean, light-bodied, & easy drinking stuff. The 5.0% abv is nice.

Overall, an easy-drinking and inoffensive beer, but short on hop character if you ask me, especially if you're gonna call your beer a New England style IPA. Not entirely sure what this beer has got to do with Lord of the Rings, or if this beer would appeal to fans of the books / movies / series. A strange brew all around.

BrewDog Fellowship IPA (The Lord Of The Rings) -----3.5/5

product_name: Fellowship IPA, The Lord of the Rings
product_review: This is another hazy IPA. It’s a pale yellow color with a thin head and considerable cloudiness. The aroma has a little hops, some earthiness, and a little underlying malt. All in all, though, it is understated. Balanced in taste, and drinkable. This one is okay, but not outstanding.

product_name: Fellowship IPA, The Lord of the Rings
product_review: Straw in color. Little to no head. Nose is very citrusy. Taste is brilliant citrus with a spark of bubbles on the palate. Nice Hazy beer even though the ABV is low.

product_name: Fellowship IPA, The Lord of the Rings
product_review:
Teaming up with the HBO producers for Lord of the Rings, Brewdog meets the occasion with a fruitier, hazier and softer IPA that's simply fellowship waiting to happen.

Pale gold, hazy and floating a stark-white foam, Fellowship IPA makes sensory introductions with a citrusy, tropical and stone fruit perfume leading to a sweeter cereal-laden taste of honeysuckle, wafer and angel food cake.

Continued sweetness stretches across the middle palate with a firm and sweet breadiness and a smooth, nearly vanilla-like spice. As the hops rise to meet the occasion, a citrusy take on tangerine and pink grapefruit provide a racy balance while a sweeter and more succulent pineapple and passionfruit character adds support and complexity. Trending lightly spicy and herbal with hops, a late taste of fresh spruce, cedar and fresh cut herbs take on a slight hemp character nearing finish.

Lighter, crisper and refreshing, the beer is off-clean and citronella-like in a medium length finish and a gin-like aftertaste. Hints of peach and hemp lead the way in retrospect to an overall impression that's not pump or rounded enough to be hazy, but still not quite crisp or bitter enough to be traditional American IPA.

product_name: Fellowship IPA, The Lord of the Rings
product_review:
12 ounce can poured into a tulip glass. Enjoy by 12/16/22, so plenty fresh.

L---Lightly hazy, light, bright golden color. Medium white head faded quickly to a ring and left very nice lacing.

S---Tropical fruits. Strong pineapple, Mango & papaya.

T---Citrus adds to the tropical notes from the nose.

F---Light/medium bodied with good carbonation.

O---Good, not great.

product_name: Fellowship IPA, The Lord of the Rings
product_review: Decent beer, though no point to go into the ratings as its a taste I haven't had dozens of times before from this company or many others. I often wonder if companies repackage these beers and simply release them under new names from time to time...

product_name: Fellowship IPA, The Lord of the Rings
product_review: A very solid Hazy IPA. Not mind blowing, but good. Nice citrus aroma, with a smooth citrus taste. It was a little thin, with a finish that ends quickly. Overall I liked it and would drink it again.

product_name: Fellowship IPA, The Lord of the Rings
product_review:
A nice juicy session style hazy ipa. Gives the right lacing and mouthfeel to enjoy the experience. The juiciness isn't obnoxious though. It has a nice citrus, hop experience. The can is awesome, nice feel and look with the LOTR franchise collaboration.
I have a pic on my phone of the very cool can as well as my beer in a glass, but the limitations on size can't be met and transferring to the PC is more than I care to do.

Picked up a four-pack from TW-Greenville, SC 7-27-22 for $16.99. Best by 08-2023; consumed 9-16-22.

Beer poured blond with a near perfect white head that has some great hang time.

Nose is pilsner malt forward and very yeasty.

Taste is a very light pilsner malt base which the yeast lends light pear and apple to. Finishes very balanced as the hopping is nicely handled.

Mouthfeel is perfect; very light and crushable but you want to relish each refreshing sip as it dances across my palate.

Overall a wonderful blonde, almost a Tripel lite!

Poured from a 11.2 oz bottle into a tulip-like glass; best before 8/23 stamp. Pours golden yellow with plenty (2+ fingers) worth of foamy head that slowly recedes. Tastes of banana like esters (?) with good carbonation. Good.

Had on tap. Got to say this is one hell of a beer! (Ba bum tss!) Essentially take duvel but endow it with more lemon, esters, and a hint of light resin, still get the grains, flowers, and orange. Feel is much wetter and slightly heavier, but still bright and full with higher carbonation. Not better than the orignal but fun

16oz draft pour at Gerst Haus served ice cold in a shaker pint... Hefe-hazy yellow with nearly white head. The head falls to a thin ring and single layer of bubbles. The aroma is vaguely fruity. The taste is mild with barely tart pear, apple, banana and a hint of wheat & barley malt. Negligible bitterness. The mouthfeel is thin to medium bodied, a bit watery, with average carbonation and a mostly dry finish. Overall, ok. Not my favorite from Duvel.

From a 320 ml. oz. stubby bottle with an 08-2023 best by date. Sampled Aug 13, 2022.

The appearance is golden with modest clarity and a modest cream colored head that slowly diminishes.

The aroma is a feat for the nose with sensations of grain, white bread, biscuit, clove, coriander, Belgian yeast, orange, banana, and pear.

Light to medium mouthfeel.

The flavor is alive with sweet grainy malts and fruit as well as an herbal and dry finale. I like this one but I am partial to Belgian-style abbey ales.

(330 ml bottle, best before end 09-2023; purchased single off shelf... poured into a 0.3l Rastal tulip)

L: sunny-yellow liquid, fine speckled sediment; tight, steady, coral-dimpled white foam... decent retention, but broke and chunked up, leaving buckshots of lace

S: musky, earthy highlights upon a spice, lemon meringue foundation... freshly-washed skin, wet cottony towel; urinal?... little potency or depth; all overtones

T: strange hoppy blend with an interesting flavor sequence/development... lemon-peppered, everything-seasoned cracker... grassy, yeasty middle... dandelion tea (flowers, roots) aftertaste... dry, water biscuit thing... 6 hops?! - now I'm curious... the orange addition expresses as a fragrant essence, but is it also contributing to the bitterness?... the bitterness is very Duvel: leafy, herbal, peppery, spicy

F: quintessential extra dryness for a Duvel... fleecy-soft texture, light, airy body

O: an interesting twist on Duvel... arguably a bit more color (flavor nuance) than the OG, but only marginally... can't say I'd crave another, but perhaps it pairs well with some buttery seafood? (1985)

On tap at 101 Beer Kitchen in Dublin Ohio.

Appearance. Clear golden body with a short head that has relatively large bubbles and a modest retention.

While the aroma features a complex and spicy yeasty base the flavor features hops. Lively carbonation in a suitably light body.

Brouwerij Duvel Moortgat NV "Duvel 6.66"
11.2 fl. oz. brown glass bottle "Best before end: 08 2023 L20708 1732"
$17.99/4-pk @ Wegmans, King of Prussia, PA

Notes via stream of consciousness: This is a lighter, and lower alcohol version of Duvel at 6.66% ABV as opposed to the usual 8.4%. It's also quite different. Right off the bat it's poured a hazy golden body as opposed to the usually perfect clarity when properly poured. The full and fluffy bright white head is the same, and be careful when pouring or it might try to rise up out of the glass! The head is made up of many very small bubbles giving it an airy and pillowy appearance.
It looks like a warm marshmallow that's just about to melt. The head retention and lacing are both quite good (I've already sampled three out of the four I bought). The aroma is bright with flowers, soft fruit (apples, orange, hint of lemon, background banana), candy sugar, sweet malt, delicate crushed black peppercorn, and a touch of spice. The flavor follows, and it's surprisingly rich. It's sweet and sugary but also floral, peppery, gently spicy, malty and subtly woody and earthy. A firm bitterness breaks through mid-palate and it starts to dry, eventually finishing with some earthiness and lightly spicy hop flavors. It lingers with some residual malt, crushed black peppercorn, earthiness, and those delicately spicy hop notes. It's impressively balanced with a fresh hop presence and bitterness that dances amongst sweet and sugary malt character. This isn't necessarily more hoppy than the original Duvel but the additional citrusy and floral character gives it a greater depth of character. Missing is the very well hidden snap of alcohol of the original Devil but the hops make up for it. In the mouth it's medium bodied with a gentle caress on the tongue that can sometimes be a little bit more bristling although it always softens to become quite smooth and airy. This version has less bite than the original, and yet I'm not really sure that it's really that much more drinkable - hence the original name, Duvel! It is remarkably enjoyable, however, and even more drinakble in terms of alcohol.
Review #8,193

special version of this, a little lower alcohol but quite a bit more character than the single version, its hoppy in a delicate but distinctive way, has a beautiful ferment on it, and is still similar to the original from a yeast standpoint, really high quality and gorgeously refined belgian blonde here, shocked it does not have higher ratings, what more do people want from this style? golden straw colored and not quite clear from the little stubby bottle, high rising white head with great retention and undeniable effervescence. it smells rather complex, but also extremely cohesive, noble hop spiciness through a good portion of it, unique yeast esters from ripe banana to lemongrass, black and green peppercorn, and even rubbed sage or something truly herbal. there is a lightness and a brightness to this, a simple belgian pils type malt base, and really excited carbonation, seems super dialed in to me. the flavor is great, yeast forward, classically belgian, light pear and gum esters, cool spiciness super compatible with the hops, clean citrus, but the flavor is tied up intimately with the texture, and this fizzes and pops like no other before a rapid dry finish, its so refreshing and vibrant, tidy for a belgian without a long linger, and the higher hop content bringing some late bitterness to help snap it up further. lightly floral late, warms up peachy and clovey, but to me stays delicate and easy, very jovial and springy, and the hops do a lot for this. overall super impressive beer, again i am surprised to see it scored this low here on BA, its a winner. neat to see some innovation from duvel! i could drink a dozen of these.

Poured into a Duvel tulip glass. Looks a lot like classic Duvel, including the massive head, with a couple of differences. The color is a bit lighter here compared to the classic, and the head is slightly less dense, but still stays around for a while.

Smell is classic Belgian, malty and yeasty up front, with a healthy mix of fruit, I am picking up mainly apple and pear and a hint of lemon.

Was not near as hop heavy as expected. Fruit really dominates for me, mainly pear and apple. There is a decent amount of peppery heat at the finish, leaving me with a slight burning sensation. Actually a pretty nice blending of flavors.

Feels nice and solid to me, quite a bit of carbonation. Really makes my tongue tingle.

A different but very nice variation on a classic. My main complaint with classic Duvel is it leans a bit heavy on the hops, this version feels more like some classic Belgian ales. This one really screams summer beer to me, drinking it on a 90 degree day, and really hits the spot. Highly recommended, really can't go wrong with it.

Poured from 330mL bottle into my BeerAdvocate teku. Best by 8/2023.

Appearance: nice medium-golden hue with a moderate haze and a huge, pretty, and inconvenient head of about 3 thick fingers of frothy ivory foam. Lovely!

Smell: light, sweet malt, with a lovely apple-pear orchard-like aroma, topped with a light but notable dose of noble hops. Again -- lovely!

Taste: sweetly malty, with a share of that lovely pear character from the aroma. There's something here, whether it's the light booziness or the clash of the hops and the peary malt character, that makes it not quite as good as its aroma. Still, it's delicious -- just not quite as delicious as I want it to be.

Mouthfeel: medium body with a big carbonation and a good creaminess.

Overall: quite a tasty treat. Not perfect, but really enjoyable.

330ml bottle.
L: Hazy gold colour with a few streams of carbonation, one finger of white foam and spotty lacing.
S&T: Chalk, cloves, lemon rind and fresh pineapple.
F: Medium/light body with moderate carbonation. Finishes spicy and dust dry.
O: A delightful, modern version of the classic. The normal spicy, Belgian yeast is complemented by fresh & zesty citrus hops.

A: Pours a clear medium yellow in color with moderate to heavy amounts of active visible carbonation rising/streaming quickly from the bottom of the glass and moderate pale golden yellow + bright yellow colored highlights. The beer has a four finger tall dense fizzy sudsy foamy bright white head that slowly reduces to a large patch of thick film covering a little more than 80% of the surface of the beer surrounded by a large patch of medium thick film covering the remainder of the surface of the beer and a medium thick ring at the edges of the glass. Light to moderate amounts of lacing are observed.

S: Slightly stronger than moderate aromas of spicy Belgian yeast (white pepper + coriander) over the top of moderate aromas of pale + wheat malts with a light to moderate amount of light fruit (pear + white grape) sweetness. Light aromas of floral + herbal + grassy + citrus/lemon hops.

T: Upfront there are moderate flavors of pale + wheat malts with a light to moderate amount of light fruit (pear + white grape) sweetness. That is followed by slightly stronger than moderate flavors of spicy Belgian yeast (white pepper + coriander). Finally there are light flavors of floral + herbal + grassy + citrus/lemon hops which impart a light amount of bitterness which slowly fades away leaving lingering floral + yeasty flavors.

M: Medium bodied with slightly heavier than moderate amounts of carbonation.

O: Easy to drink with well hidden alcohol and a very pleasantly mouthfeel which is quite refreshing. Very enjoyable classic Belgian Blonde flavors and aromas. I could easily have a few of these.

Poured from draft at the Duvelorium in Bruges. Pours opaque orange with a considerable amount of white head. Dissipates, but tons of remnants remain. The nose is full of citrus peel, wheat, orange, wet grass, and honey. Really smooth. The taste follows the nose. Vanilla, slight hops, malts, toffee, orange, wheat, and a bit of leather. Mouthfeel is light and a bit dry. The aftertaste is fairly sweet. Overall, this is a fantastic beer!

A large number of hop varietals without being too hoppy. Is that a good definition of balance?
Poured into my Duvel 150th Anniversary commemorative glass, 6.66 ABV Looks quite inviting: rocky head, mostly clear body until the last pour. Blondie Smells more modest, 6.66 could fling off more fruit. Tastes are balanced; much like its higher ABV parent, yeast and spices and malts all play nice. Cleansing and quite full in my mouth... which is masterful at 6.66 ABV.

This will be a better table ale than I expected, particularly for summer fare. Glad I bought a 4-pack.... and may want another.
Duvel is also my most favored brand manager among crafters. Duvel lets its brands loose to create... but it does that because Duvel knows itself how freedom, properly directed, can create.

6/21/22 On the summer Solstice when light is most prevalent, I am glad to report that 6.66 plays pretty darn nice with Bob's World-Famous Ratatouille. This complement is usually won by saisons, but 6.66 is a true premium Blonde. I'm keeping count over at UnTappd.

Pours a very clear golden color with a very generous head and lacing
The aroma has generous citrus and floral hints
The taste follows the nose with a citrus and floral flavor
A medium bodied beer well carbonated beer
A very well done Belgian Blonde Ale

Bottle. Golden slightly hazy with long-lasting head and a little lace. Beautfil yeasty herbal subtle complex aroma and a hint of citrus? Light grassy fruity apricot sweetness with very dry mild herbal and fruity finish. Medium light body soft carbo. Fantastic.

The beer of the devil is now available on the shelves for us all to enjoy. Spicier, drier and fruitier, this beer makes one hell of a debut.

Light chrome, racing with carbonated streams and building a fluffy white crown, Duvel 6.66 teases the nose with a sharp and spicy scent of citrus zest, dried fruit, vinous spice, grassy and botanical perfumes. A low lying sweetness grazes the early palate with the lightness of wafer crackers, light bread and a hint of fresh dough.

As the flavors unfold on the middle palate, the malts retreat and the fruits begin to shine. Pear, apple and lemon all seem branch-dried in nature while the more spicy flavors of orange, lemon, grapefruit and lime zest play out partly fruity but partly spice. Those spices lean into the briskness of coriander, white pepper and vinous tanginess precisely. A late taste of bitterness is herbal, pleasantly grassy and herbal with lemon balm and sassafras.

Light, crisp and highly refreshing, the beer is plagued slightly bite the fruit tannins that amplify the hop bitterness and give the beer a decidedly bitter balance in finish and aftertaste. A quick fleeting malt presence leaves behind a long and spicy aftertaste.

Released 9/3/22; drank 9/12/22 @ the Yarchives.

Mostly opaque dull brown/orange appearance.

A slow pour yielded a minimal, noisy khaki head which quickly dissipated; no lace.

Caramel, dill pickle, oak & bourbon heat notes in the nose.

Thick, sticky mouthfeel.

Smoked caramel & dill pickle flavors up front; oak, bourbon & fig notes on the finish.

This has major barleywine vibes; not really an Oktoberfest beer in its current form, but if you like over-the-top barrel aged barleywines, you'll enjoy this. An interesting experiment that they should probably not make a habit of.

Appearance - Pours a deep amber with two fingers of off-white head.

Smell - earthy and spicy hops, whiskey, cherry, some char aromas from the barrel, caramel, biscuity and toasted malts, and earthy yeast.

Taste - earthy and spicy hops upfront then quickly goes into the whiskey and char. The cherry is subtle but comes through next alongsdide the caramel. The biscuity and toasted malts accompanied by the earthy yeast rounds out the brew.

Mouthfeel - Medium to full bodied with moderate carbonation. Finishes sticky from the malts alongside a pleasant alcohol warmth from the whiskey.

Overall - An interesting brew that is not for the faint of heart. This one is meant for those who like whiskey forward brews. They definitely did a good job on that. The ABV is pretty hidden in this one making it a dangerous sipper. A pleasant tipple on this fall-ish evening here in Cowtown.

L: Amber body, thick creamy head.
S: Deep, alcoholic, sweet. Caramel at first, then oak and cherries, and hint of orange and whiskey.
T: Follows the nose. More bitter than expected, with upfront oak and caramel backed by hops. Cherry is quite present, and whiskey is pronounced on the finish.
F: Wet mouthfeel, noticeable booze.
O: Much stronger than I expected, almost to the level of an American barleywine. Quite good for a cold day.

Poured from a 16 ounce can into a snifter.

Look- Amber brown, light brown frothy head, moderately hazy, no visible particulate, below average head retention, average lacing.

Smell- Oak, whiskey, vanilla.

Taste- Vanilla, whiskey, oak.

Feel- Medium body, average carbonation, mildly creamy, smooth, mildly mouth warming.

Overall- Pleasant flavor and bouquet, but body was thinner than expected.

Dead 'N' Dead pours a clean, darker copper color, with a small, lacing head. Aroma has hints of earth, and whiskey. Flavor has a good amount of whiskey, oak, a hint of earth. Good body and feel. Overall, a beer for the whiskey lover!

I am trying this beer off the tapper at The Daily Growler in Powell, Ohio. It poured a slightly hazy copper with thin white head that is leaving some lace. The scent had caramel malt and rye notes. The taste was nicely balanced and easy to drink with sweet malt base that had rye and typical Maibock profile. The mouthfeel was medium in body and had good carbonation. Overall it is a great beer.

Pours a slightly hazy light reddish brown with a small fluffy tan head and light lacing.

Smells of roasted malt, oak and whisky.

Tastes of roasted malt, caramel, whisky and orange with a slightly bitter, spicy, boozy warm finish.

Medium light body with light carbonation. Clean dry mouthfeel.

This is a nice malt forward European style beer and a nice contrast with IPA's. It's like a light winter warmer sipper.

750ml bottle poured into tulip.

Pours a lovely deep ruby amber with two fingers of khaki head that leaves some ropy lace as it recedes.

Smells fantastic. Roasted grain, singed citrus peel, orange and apple stewed with spices, a stiff whiskey and coke, boozy oak, candied sultana raisins and an intimidating touch of alcohol.

Tastes of grainy roasted caramel malt, spiced citrus and pomme fruit, dark toffee, more strong whiskey and coke, dried vanilla, barrel wood, sugary cafe au lait, raisin tarts and warming alcohol.

Feels slow and fat. Full bodied with tepid carbonation. Finishes chewy.

Verdict: Vigorously recommended. A big loud fun beer with a boozy kick, good for a long movie.

Bought a single 16oz can $4.50
128 days old
Amber color
Smells like whiskey and coke
Medium mouthfeel
Low-medium carbonation
Taste of whiskey, some sweetness that reminds me of flat coke, light bitterness, alcohol aftertaste
Overall it delivers on what it says it is. The whiskey makes it a sipper to enjoy. Not a complex flavor like some BBAs, but good for what it is.

Look: Bright clear orange with brown undertones. Pours with a 2 finger tightly bubbled head. After 5 minutes the head has faded away leaving some lacing.

Smell: Oak and toasted pumpernickel malts. Plenty of vanilla and a slight floral character of wildflowers.

Taste: Hot and boozy, with the oak barrel, and whiskey tones dominant throughout the whole sip. I did pick up some hints of plum and cinnamon, almost like a fruit cake. Toffee sweetness was noticable mid sip to the end. This would likely go great with Christmas dessert around a fire.

Feel: Medium bodied and sharp. It finishes with a syrup like quality that you often find with higher ABV beer styles.

This would be up the alley for those looking fora whiskey beer experience. It earns a solid B.

Tallboy can from the LCBO; dated Jul 28 2021 and served barely chilled. Always nice to see a new Rogue beer, as their presence around here has been spotty in the recent past.

Pours a foggy orange-amber colour, crowned with nearly an inch of smooth, creamy, off white-tinged head that gradually seeps off. Within five minutes, it has been reduced to a thick, creamy collar and filmy cap, with a gorgeous curtain of lace left clinging to the glass - a beautiful glass of beer. Plenty of bready malt and toasted grains on the nose, with vanilla and toffee also coming through pretty clearly; also some subtler hints of oak, plum, apple and booze.

It's a fine strong ale, boasting a firm oak-iness on the back end. It starts off with bready malts, toasted grains and toffee sweetness, with hints of whiskey and vanilla developing quickly. Suggestions of herbal hops, spiced & stewed plums, apple and a touch of raisin are quickly overtaken by oak chip/'wood tannins', which linger through the finish and into a moderately warming aftertaste of whiskey and malts. Medium-full in body, with middling carbonation that gives a gentle bite to this bock's smooth, satisfying texture. Fair drinkability - I was getting a little tired of the oak chips by the end of the glass, but finishing the can was no challenge at all.

Final Grade: 4.04, an A-. Much like its older, lighter brother, Dead 'N' Dead bears only a passing resemblance to the style Rogue has chosen to market it as - though I suppose in this case, the whiskey/oak chip treatments made that practically inevitable. If taken strictly as a German maibock (I'm not), there is ample opportunity for criticism - but as a strong oaked beer, I think it's quite enjoyable. In truth, I'd probably take regular Dead Guy over this... but then again, I've never been gung-ho about either oak or whiskey, so folks who happen to be really big on strong oaked ales might enjoy it even more than I did. Either way, give it a try it you have the chance.

Hazy, deep amber body, building a sandy bubbly head that crumbles down within a minute.
Sweet malty aroma of caramel apple, faintly of warm spice and vanilla, dash of maple syrup; pretty mild.
The taste follows suit on malt side of things - caramel notes, warm, a touch of toffee - and finds that well balanced by prominent, and clean, bittering hops. There's also whispers of oak, and the alcohol is noticeable to a small degree. Fine, medium carbonation, medium body, all in all a pleasant feel.

A nice drink, if nothing much above average. Would be a good choice to put down while at a bar.

This one smells incredibly malty and sweet. There are scents of vanilla, wood and booze but malt is definitely the predominant aroma.

The taste is wooden and has some vanilla but like the nose the malt dominates.

It's medium bodied with a small amount of carbonation. The finish is clean and sweet with grains as the last note left.

It's good. I give it a 5 out of 6.

Canned on 7/29/21. 16oz can poured into a tulip. Pours a glowing amber with solid clarity; small off-white head that fades leaving solid retention and lacing. Nice color. The aromas are malt forward. Some caramel, toffee, cherries and dark fruits. The flavors are bold. Lots of sticky caramel and toffee. Lots of dark fruits, especially raisins. Hints of cocoa and vanilla. Lots of oak. The wood chips definitely come through and give this one depth. Subtle whiskey notes. Very solid bitterness. Low sweetness. Solid malt backbone. It finishes a little warm. The alcohol is noticeable, but it's not hot or boozy. Mouthfeel is nice. It's full-bodied with moderate to active carbonation. It's sharp, fluffy and smooth.

This is a really nice brew. It's a nice imperial take on their classic Dead Guy Ale. It's big, bold and fun to drink. The craftsmanship is on point. Well done. I really like it.
Decent beer but pretty overpriced for what it is. I had a chuck of solid sediment in mine and it is way too thick. Wouldn't buy again but it was different.

Beautiful Golden Hue with Fuzzy white head.

Smell is a bit acetal on the nose...which is weird but I also pick up fresh wood and a hint of vanilla. Maybe I'm smelling vanilla extract? I dunno.

Taste is very reminiscent of base DG with some nice woodsy/mushroom/caramel/vanilla/cinnamon/barrel char etc...I dig it.

Overall perhaps not an improvement but definitely something different and very nice. I'd buy again for sure...especially at a bargain $12 bomber price point

A: pours an orange amber body with a. Small white head with ok retention and lacing.
S: sweet, orange smell with sweet whiskey alcohol notes with some vanilla and toffee notes
T: sweet, toffee mantles with some light orange cremasicle notes; burnt caramel finish
M: a little light but smooth BA Nd pretty refreshing.
O: decent beer; I definitely like how the whiskey barrels rounds it out; for a 9.5% beer, alcohol isn’t in very noticeable in the taste.

From the 22 oz bottle in a snifter. This solid little maibock
pours a chill hazed deep amber with an excellent head of off
white foam that settles to a thick fat layer with excellent lacing!
Nose of faint oak, booze, light bourbon, pine touched hops, and
sweet honey malts. Flavors follow the nose with pine and herbal
hop notes awash in light bourbon that is pretty hot, subtle raw
oak, and notes of honey and caramel malts with touches of
vanilla. Excellent mouth feel; medium body, smooth, lightly crisp,
medium light carbonation that is brisk, and a herbal and pine hop
laced finish with hot bourbon elements.

Overall, solid but need some maturation. That said, I can not
say much negative about this brew or this fine brewery which
inspired so many.

Cheers

2018 release and this is the first time I have seen it.

Pours a deep amber with a small but persistent head of foam.

The nose is of whiskey, vanilla, lightly boozy, heavily malty.

The taste has the not so subtle whiskey, vanilla, mild malty sweetness, more whiskey though it doesn't reach a super boozy state.

Pretty light bodied for a brew of the abv. Gets thin at times.

So, this was aged for me...I didn't ask for that. I would have preferred finding it fresh and then making my own decision whether to cellar it or not.
As is, it's not too shabby.

2018 vintage

Being a massive fan of OG Dead Guy, I knew I had to get this when I saw it. Hopefully this expands upon what I love about the original

Pours a turbid, hazy copper with just a cap of off white head that fades quickly to a ring and leaves no lacing

The nose is quite sweet, but almost artificially so. I get layers of vanilla, honey, and caramel with very mild pepper to back it up. The barrel doesn’t really do much aroma wise other than contributing the vanilla notes

The taste is more of the same, yet not as exciting. To start things off, I get caramel and a light whiskey tingle. On the aftertaste, this translates to a decent oaky sweet bourbon with hints of honey and a touch of chocolate

This has a medium body and almost no carbonation, yet it still drinks pretty light, especially for the abv. This is probably the biggest saving grace of this one

Well shit, here’s an instance where the base beer is better thab the barrel aged version!! It could be a freshness issue, as I noticed this was pretty much a malt bomb when compared to the delicate balance of the original. Regardless it was not a bad beer, but I know what I’ll be reaching for first

A special treat on the porch! Bourbon and honey malt aroma. The taste is full of rich, sweet raisins and honey and a lasting malt flavor. It leaves a nice tingle on the edges on the tongue and the classic, yet slight, bourbon burn on the way down.

6-pack from Jungle Jim's
Deep golden color with a finger thick white head, fair retention.
Caramel malt aroma.
Taste follows the nose with a low bitterness and a pleasant sweet finish.
Like it.

12 oz can. Canned on 7/11/22
Pretty amber/gold in hue. Bountiful off-white head pushes 2 fingers with pretty solid retention.
Nose is instantly on the sweeter side. Fruit and caramel malt. Slowly a hint of breadiness comes in, but it's struggling to be noticed, chasing the spotlight but never getting a chance to shine.
Flavor is slightly closer to balanced. The caramel malts are not as dominant here, the bready note finally gets a moment, but just a moment. A mild herbal spice also takes its turn.
Mouthfeel has good carbonation, decent heft, and an almost balanced finish (a tad sweet still) with a tad of bitterness.
Overall, a decent offering but not outstanding.

This beer has a very nice crisp malty finish that makes it stand out.

Poured from a can into a tulip glass. Orangish golden yellow color with good initial head but little lacing. Sweet malt and fresh bread smell and taste. Medium feel. Overall a nice Octoberfest beer.

12oz can poured into a pint

A- pours a clear amber color with a one-finger foamy white head that reduces to a film on top

S- fall leaves, caramel chews, toasted bread crust, raisins, light floral hops

T- sweet and malty up front with a bold caramel note, followed by some dark fruit notes of raisin and fig. Mid-palate gives some bready malt, with toasted crust notes. The finish gives more sweet caramel, along with a hint of floral hops, malty linger

M- medium body with low carbonation leads to a slightly foamy mouthfeel that continues into a crisp finish

O- the caramel sweetness with the toasted finish makes for a highly drinkable okto, well done
Kind of hard to detect the olir at dusk,Appears to be a foggy orange, small white fades quickly. A nice aroma of fresh bread, flavors abit more robust. This is, IMHO, a very good Oktoberfest.

This is a beer that simply “exists,” you know? It’s kind of like when you walk by a plant that is just a “plant.” Something that doesn’t make you stop and stare in wonder, yet something that is still necessary and good in its own right. And that’s what AleSmith Oktoberfest is to me - something that is just nice in its own right.

Maybe take a breath and contemplate thought before your next move, my minions. I don’t know, just go with what feels right.

Packaged on July 11th, consumed on August 24th, 2022 - poured from a 12oz can into my Moonlight shaped pint glass.

Carrot orange/butterscotch body, clear, with a half-finger of ivory cream. Average retention; thin soapy lacing, faint legs.

Faintly toasty malt-forward aromatics, sweet yet restrained.

Sweet, creamy palate entry, malty with hints of corn-bread and whipped cream. Vaguely earthy, medium finish - low bitterness throughout. Clean lager/yeast profile.

Soft, medium-light bodied with moderate carbonation.

Weakly hopped (13 IBUs), and a bit sweet for the style - still, a pleasant, malty, agreeable beer.

Cloudy amber pour with a billowing white head. Immediate aromas rise up of caramel, sweet bread, german yeast, and a hint of orange. Taste has big traditional caramel malts as the first wave and german yeast as the second wave, sneaky toast, orange slice and date poke through here and there, a different take that I quite enjoyed. Feel is bright, malty and yeasty with a striking balance ending in a crisp finish.

Canned 6/18/21; drank 11/13/21 @ Midsommar Phoenix.

See-through dark orange appearance.

An even pour yielded a big off-white head; frothy lace.

Dill pickle, faint caramel & mild hop bite notes in the nose.

Medium mouthfeel.

Dill pickle, caramel & cucumber (?!) flavors.

Odd, and frankly gross. Not one I'll ever pick up again...

Can poured into a flared pint glass produced an amber gold body with a quickly dissipating head. Disappeared fast with no film or lacing. A very nice aroma of malt, bread and sweetness. Taste was the same, with a brief bitter hop aftertaste. Mouthfeel was a medium weight, which was surprising based on the color/appearance of the beer. Carbonation was on the lighter side. Overall a very nice domestic Marzen

This beer makes me think of the "Chicken Dance" and outdoor Octoberfest celebrations. Pours a rich caramel color with very active carbonation and a loose, thin head that leaves no lacing. Smell and flavor are both caramel, toffee, fresh warm wheat bread. Mouthfeel is a bit heavier than I anticipated based on the active carbonation in the "thin-ish" appearance. Easily my favorite version of this type compared to other domestic marzen/fest biers.

Poured 2 12 oz cans into a big stein

Cloudy, copper appearance, yields a thick sudsy head on an easy pour. Bready, buiscuity nose, touches of honey and grass frame the bouquet. Notes of honeyed bread, carob, and toffee spearhead punchy flavors. Floral hints of grass and citrus rind round things out. Finishes bready sweet with lingering honey-malts on the palate.

A quaffable but distinctly flavored Marzen. One of my favorite stateside interpretations of the style.

12oz canned on 07/30/2021. Sample from the brewery.

Bright, clear, light amber in color with a thin foamy lace that quickly dissipates. Some toasty and caramelly malts in the nose. Medium-bodied, lightly carbonated, and a bit flat on the palate. Malty, toasty, and bready with a dominate caramelly profile that's quite sweet. Hint of spice and faint bitterness, but the malty profile shuts that down. Finish is a bit dry with toasty bread crust.

Aleschmidt Oktoberfest is a pretty average, and somewhat one-dimensional, Märzen that doesn't look good in the glass.

From the can, it pours a clear amber color with a modest head that slowly diminishes, leaving some lacing. The nose gets a bit of malt. The mouth gets the same, decent oktoberfest with modest caramel, roasted malts and overall a pleasant taste.

Poured from fridge temp. Pours an absolutely gorgeous murky orange with white head. The nose on this is incredible. The crisp malts jump out immediately. Refreshing caramel follows. Figs, grapes, freshly-baked bread, and a bit of earthy grass. The taste is where this one really shines. A sweetness bites the tongue immediately. The depth of the malts really smacks the back of the mouth. Toffee, wheat, bread, raisins, prunes, wood, grass, and maybe a distant citrus peel bitterness on the back end. This one really hits all of the right boxes for a fantastic Märzen. The mouthfeel is medium bodied and, again, comes with a fantastic aftertaste. I would buy a bunch of this in a heartbeat. In fact, that's what I will do tomorrow! A great beer!

Poured from a can into a pint glass
Appearance – The beer pours a clear orange amber color with a small head of fizzy white foam. The head has a light level of retention, fading to leave a bit of foamy lace on the sides of the glass.
Smell – The aroma of the brew is strong of a toasted bready smell mixed with aromas of caramel. Along with these aromas are some light notes of harvest fruits of pear and apple as well as a touch of grain and herb.
Taste – The taste begins with a caramel and harvest fruit sweetness (apple, pear) along with a medium light toasted bready malt body. As the taste advances these flavors persist, while some light herbal and earthy tastes join in. The mix of flavors takes the taste to the end and leave one with a sweeter lightly toasted taste to linger on the tongue.
Mouthfeel – The body of the brew is average in thickness and creaminess with a carbonation level that is on the average side as well. For the sweeter malt flavors of the brew the feel is good and makes for a nice easy sipper.
Overall – A rather nice very easy drinking Oktoberfest.
It's smooth, very mildly sweet, crisp, refreshing. I tried it warm and cold since it is a German beer and cold is significantly better. There's no butter taste to this beer.

Poured from 12oz can into a mug. Canned 7/21/21.

Appearance: good golden-orange hue with a tiny touch of haze and a thin layer of fizzy white foam. The color is outstanding but the head dissipated too quickly.

Smell: richly malty with notes of dark bread and molasses. Perhaps a tad sweet, but still, very nice.

Taste: bready, a bit toasty, and a bit biscuity. There's a light but balanced bitterness; the overall effect seems very autumnal to me (as one might expect). I'm not usually a fan of the biscuity character in malt, but here it adds an appropriate dimension to a beer of this style.

Mouthfeel: medium body with a decent level of carbonation and creaminess.

Overall: a good example of the style, I think. Not sure what caused the head to die so quickly, but other than that, it's a good quaff.

From the bottom of the can: "CANNED ON 07/30/21 5511"

Appearance: The body of the beer is a medium shade of copper towards the middle and a lighter shade of amber at the edge. It has moderate clarity with some light haze. It has a short white head that fades out to a medium white ring and a film on the surface.

Aroma: There are notes of cherry and a light oak character mixed with crushed acorn and walnut.

Taste: Cherry comes through with a light bit of caramel up front. In the middle there is a light roasted nut character with a hint of toasted bread. The back of the mouth has more of the same nuttiness that the middle does. Aftertaste has a light caramel sweetness.

Mouthfeel: It feels medium-light on the palate and watery. Very light toasted bitterness. It doesn't cling well to the palate or have much of an impact on it. It has a light bit of slickness which feels off for the style.

Overall: It feels like the average attempt at an Oktoberfestbier but it lacks texture, complexity, cohesiveness, and it doesn't look the greatest in a glass. It's drinkable and I probably wouldn't turn one down for free but it isn't something I'd likely buy again or recommend.

12 oz can. Pours amber with tall, long-lasting, fluffy white head and soda-like carbonation. Aroma is of grassy hops and caramel malt. Body is full and crisp. Grassy hops and caramel malt nicely balanced on the palate, hint of spices. Finish is long and dry. Nice brew.

Pours a clear beautiful golden color however with not much head or lacing not good on that. Smell is baked bread malts some fruits and hops ..not feeling this one. taste is better grainy fruity malty with some hops nice malt back bone . Mouth feel had a mettalic taste it had low carbonation. Wow tough to finish from such an esteemed brewer , not even close to style a mess IMO

Canned on 07/08/21 and consumed mid-August 2021. Pumped when I see any new Oktoberfest and since it’s from AleSmith, I didn’t even hesitate grabbing a 6er from the shelf. Gorgeous amber color. Drinks so well, perfectly executed. Deliciously grainy, bready, and finished with caramel malt. Stellar!

Pours a beautiful clear amber orange with a rather short lived smallish cream colored head. Aroma is bready and caramel malts. Flavor follows the nose sweet roasted caramel malt, some European hop, and rye bread. Feel is medium bodied, and adequately carbonated. Overall a fantastic beer albeit at a premium cost.

Type: 12-oz. can
Reviewed as: Marzen / Oktoberfest
Glass: Gordon Biersch .5L Stein
Price: $1.67
From: From: Trader Joe’s in College Area (San Diego), Calif.
Purchased: Sept. 25, 2020
Consumed: Oct. 1, 2020
Misc.: Canned on Sept. 3, 2020

Grabbed a can of this, a bunch of other stuff and a 6-pack of something else on a recent trip to Trader Joe’s. AleSmith does almost everything well (except hoppy beers to me, but everything else), so I was looking to try this. Was actually surprised that I hadn’t reviewed this before, let alone checked into it on Beer Advocate. Back of the can read, “This German-style Marzen Lager is our take on a classic Oktoberfest offering. AleSchmidt Oktoberfest is characterized by a clean, elegant, and toasty malt character. Prost!”

Poured a dark amber clear color with 3-to-4 fingers of khaki white rocky-to-frothy head, which dissipated quickly. Lots of bubble streams coming up from the bottom of the glass. Bad watery, spotty lacing. Average retention. (Sight - 3.25)

Smelled Outback bread, honey, wheat, sweet grain, mixed nuts, toasted malts, chewy caramel, toasted biscuit and graham cracker. Not quite as good from the can but got some earthier malts with some leathery toffee notes. (Smell - 4.00)

Tasted a little better than the nose but followed for the most part. A very clean beer. Got Outback bread, honey, wheat, sweet grain, toasted malts, chewy caramel, mixed nuts, Wheat Thins, toasted biscuit, leathery toffee, hints of tobacco and graham cracker. (Taste - 4.25)

Medium body. Creamy texture. Average carbonation. Long, toasty finish. (Feel - 4.25)

This was an excellent Oktoberfest beer, something I would expect from AleSmith. (Overall - 4.25)

4.13 | 92 | A-

Lovely coppery amber color with a handsome pile of foam in the Leute Bokbier glass. Quite malty and fragrant with roasted grain. Odd gummy flavor that seems to be a feature of some of these Märzen style beers. Hint of apples, even candy apple as the malt is quite sweet.

Plenty of raw flavors and the grainy finish. I don't rate this with my favorite Oktoberfest favorites. There is a bitterish metallic aftertaste that I don't find very appealing. Still it's well made and quite quaffable. From the 12 oz can.

12 oz can poured into a pint glass. The AleSchmidt pours a clear copper with a thin cap of foam. Decent bubble formation from the bottom of the glass but retention is lighter than hoped for.

Nose is slightly malt forward for the color yet not so much as for most American versions of the style. I think festbier is quite different than Marzen in style. This one is squarely in the middle. Offering some complex malts but without the easy and quick blast of gringo marzen/oktoberfest beers with a 2row base and a sloppy caramel malt boost. And that I appreciate. Still I'm not picking up the pils/munich I seek either. Does offer a decent finish but the muddled malt notes trounce the cleaner malt and hop notes this dude seeks. Better than many. Go to Munich for festbier
A good German beer, but I prefer something more bready. So for extra characters, this is a good German beer that is delightful to drink but not worth the cost.
